reviews.review: Oasis in the city's heart. Beautiful oasis and spot to forget the time right in Sydney's heart and only a few meters away from Darling Harbour.

Beautiful gardens with wonderful activity for primary school aged kids. We went to the gardens this morning and I was pleasantly surprised to find they had a Chinese zodiac themed activity for the kids to have a focus while I enjoyed the beauty and serenity of the feng shui designed gardens. Inexpensive, relaxing, and right near an amazing playground too in Darling Harbour. A lovely morning out with the kids.
Beautiful. Beautiful and lovely garden. Not too busy on a Friday morning and people are lovely and friendly as the garden title suggests

An oasis amid the city madness. This place is a must see area of tranquility,Wonderful pools, waterfalls, plantings. Huge Koi carp and much visiting wildlife.
Reasonable cost $6 stay as long as you wish.

Peaceful spot to spend an hour in the city. You can spend a peaceful hour or so here in this lovely garden in the middle of a busy, busy city. If you're with children keep an eye out for the Chinese animals marking each year (signs of the zodiac).

Serenity in the center of the city.. While traveling with family to Sydney, AU, in July, 2016, we visited the Chinese Friendship Garden. It was oh so beautiful, filled with Chinese architecture, Chinese landscaping, complete with signage explaining each highlight. It was quiet and restful in the Garden, even though we were in the midst of the city. This is a don't miss point of interest in Sydney.

Tranquil & Peaceful. Great place to visit for all ages to relax & enjoy the wildlife while taking in the beautiful gardens. There are seats placed around the gardens for you to sit & just take in the view. Not expensive for the entry & well worth a visit.

A peaceful retreat close to the CBD. A green & peaceful retreat where one can meditate and lose themselves in this beautiful oasis. Take the time to visit; take timeout to just sit and contemplate - this is a world away from the hustle & bustle of the rush and madness of every day life. Just watch that the Ibis's don't drop a message from the sky !!

great place to unwind and relax for a while.. we loved the wild life that makes the gardens home, the tranquility of the gardens, and that we could sit and relax and enjoy the gardens after a long day.

Such a beautiful oasis. The gardens are always so beautiful and well maintained. There is abundant animal life and it's such a tranquil and peaceful oasis. I've been here several times and it's great value for money. I always leave felling lighter than when I arrived!

So tranquil. What a perfect place to retreat to after a busy day around Sydney, so well designed and a different vista around every corner. A must see if you enjoy garden design or just enjoy piece and quiet.

Fav Place in Sydney City. Absolutely stunning. Definetely take your time and soak in all of the picturesque scenery. Great photo opportunities from all angles. Resident lizards :) for a fee, you can dress up in chinese silk outfit, lots of fun. Could spend hours there. Must see if you want a place away from the hustle.

Tranquil oasis in the middle of Darling Harbour. We had lots of fun with Emperor's Quest. And enjoyed the peaceful surrounds of the gardens. Everyone in the gardens we saw was enjoying their time in these gardens including those who were dressed up in the costumes available.

Pleasant place to visit. Had a walk around the gardens on a recent visit to Sydney and Darling Harbour. It is cheap to get in and the gardens are really nice and provide a nice break from the busy area of surrounding Darling Harbour. There is also a cafe for a refreshement when you finish having a look around.

Beautiful sight to see: rain or shine. While on a gloomy rainy day, we pushed ourselves to see the Chinese Garden of Friendship - and it was beautiful despite the weather! Ornate buildings and beautiful history await you. If you get there by 11:30a, you can participate in the daily koi fish feeding (BIGGEST koi I have seen in my life, could swear they eat steaks for dinner lol). Was a bit bummed we couldn't do the costume dressing exhibit (it's closed on rain days), but it's simply a stunning zen place to visit!

Chinese Garden of Friendship. If you want tranquility go through the Chinese Garden of Friendship located at Sydney Harbour. It is a beautiful place that although is surrounded by a road, other buildings and people passing, once you enter you leave the world outside. You become immersed in the spectacular views and peace consumes you. There is plenty of places you can sit and just watch the birds and time pass. Unfortunately there is a negative, the little cafe they have although is gorgeous inside with so many wonderful displays we found that the cakes were not wonderful, a bit dry and on the stale side, however have a lovely cup of tea and sit and watch the fish. The views surround you, go and enjoy.
Chinese garden. This was a beautiful peaceful trip. Wish we had more time to enjoy it but will definitely go back again!

Peaceful Serenity in the Hustle & Bustle of the CBD. Decided to visit the Chinese Garden of Friendship before even heading to Sydney as it was a cheap type of entry and was in Darling Harbour area, boy were we not disappointed. There is so much packed into such a small area. Honestly if there is one thing to do outside the normal touristy things to do this is it. Do yourself a favour, take in the greenery, peace and quiet of the gardens. On the day we visited it was very overcast and a slight misty rain, but there is plenty to see and plenty of undercover places to wait until it is dry....also keep an eye out for the chinese characters....tiger, rat, dragon etc.... hidden and fun to find.

chinese eden in the heart of the city. if you looking for a refreshing place to hang out in the middle of the city this is the place to goyou don t have to be a chinese culture lover to go there .Just enjoy the perfection of the garden with the waterfall the chinese pavillion and before leaving take a nice cup of tea with a pastry to make you feel so far away from the crowdy street of sydney .Finally 2 hour in a quite place surrounded of exotic tree and architecture ... it s not so bad to relax !

An oasis of calm in a busy city. Another must have C hinese experience in Beijing. The garden is calm and beautiful witha timeless quality amongst all thehuslt and bustle outisde. And there is a sweet little hire shop right in the middle where grown ups and children can hire tradional costumes to wear walking around the garden which adds to the feeling of stepping back in time. The garden and it's wildlife also provides some great photographic opportunities..
Beautiful!. Absolutely beautiful gardens and loved exploring the gardens with our kids. Was reasonable priced too.

Beautiful. Its only $6 each to get in and is 100% worth it.
Recommend going on a sunny day, you can get some amazing pictures and the whole experience is so relaxing.

Tranquil, Beautiful and makes you forget where you are.. Escape the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Transport yourself across the world to china, walk leisurely throughout this delightful place. Every time we come here, it makes you fell at rest. See the water dragon lizard and Ibis/crane. Sit down and relax, contemplate your life and what is going on in the world.
Worth it. Amazing that this place is in the middle of sydney, very peaceful, worth the entrance money for sure.

Stunning haven of tranquility in the middle of the harbour. A beautiful place full of charm, history, ornamental buildings, ponds and waterfalls, there is even a chance to dress up in authentic Chinese clothes. There are lovely tea rooms where you can have lunch or just tea and a light bite, it's very popular with school children on an educational level, there are a few places that are a little difficult for the disabled but the charm and surroundings of these gardens give plenty of enjoyment.
WOW!. What a find in the middle of Sydney! Having just returned from China, we found the garden to be both beautiful and authentic. What a great place to visit.

You'd have trouble believing this is in the middle of Sydney!. Very peaceful and tranquil with abundant with bird-life, lizards and fish. (might be time to relocate the Ibis though they appear to be taking over) We took our time meandering and the paths and checking out all the garden had to offer, it was well worth the $6 dollar entry and recommend it as a nice time out area, with no time limit.Nice touch was the Chinese Horoscope displays popping up all over the garden.

Calming location in a busy city. Even during the school holidays this garden is a peaceful location and a cool one on a warm day. Lizards bask on the rocks in the sun never far from the water that flows through the garden. There is even a waterfall which can be viewed from both the bottom and the top as you make you way round the paths and up to the ornamental pagoda. It only takes an hour to work your way around the garden but it is easy to linger for longer as every corner gives a different view of the gardens. Near the end of the path is a tea room where you can sit a while longer and enjoy the pond view.Keep your eyes open and you will spot a few visiting birds sharing the gardens with you. A must see for keen gardeners and those wanting a calm place to rest a while.

Peaceful. Really enjoyed this quiet little oasis in the CBD and it is well worth the modest entry fee. It was marred by the abundance of ibis poo. I'm not sure how this can be rectified, however it is a problem with them roosting in trees.

Very tranquil. A wonderful way to spend an hour or so in the morning. Admission was $6 and you can spend as long as you'd like. Lots of wonderful photo opportunities. Even if it gets crowded, there are nice little nooks where you and sit and be contemplative. Highly recommended. i wish it were bigger so i could spend more time there!
Simply stunning!. An oasis of tranquillity in the middle of the city. I was stunned by the beauty as I wandered around the garden. The Eastern Water Dragons were fun to see too!

a beautiful place. my friend and I wanted to visit the Chinese Garden when visiting from interstate and were not disappointed, it is beautiful, serene and bigger than we expected. Ibis abound along with other birds and a beautiful little family of ducks. Could have stayed there for ever!

An oasis of calm in a busy city. Enjoyed a few hours in this exquisite garden. Not a large area but cleverly laid out with beautiful vistas at every turn. Chose the entry option which included tea and dimsum, which proved an excellent way to finish our visit.

Nothing Really Chinese About This Garden. It's a good place to unwind and enjoy the greens in the middle of the city. Other than that, I really do not find anything Chinese about this place. Nevertheless, it's worth visiting at least once when you are in Sydney,

Tranquility Base in the City. Do not miss visiting this little island of calm and tranquility in between Darling Harbour and Chinatown. There is a small entrance fee but the visit will stay with you longer than the coffee you might have bought for the price. The pagodas and water features are serene, and so are the long-necked turtles, ibis and lizards who populate the rocks, themselves specifically chosen to resemble wild creatures. Costumes are available for hire if you need to get totally into the Chinese theme but really, just go, walk around and feel the peaceful pace, away from the bustle of Sydney outside.
Peaceful and serene. A surprisingly peaceful and beautiful spot in the middle of Sydney. Magnificent gardens and surprising views really make this a worthwhile place to visit.

An island of tranquility in the middle of one of the world's great cities. Situated close to Darling harbour, I booked into a hotel for a couple of nights that offered a complementary view of the Chinese garden.I was at this time quite unaware of what this was (a small garden in the hotel grounds?) but intrigued, set out to discover a little more.Very surprising then to find this lovely little island of peace and tranquility at the heart of a bustling (and one of the world's finest) citiesA couple of hours can easily be spent here wandering around the twisting paths and up and down the small steps as well as taking a seat and a little personal time to contemplate on the juxtaposition of such tranquil beauty nestled inside the tower blocks of the Syndey harbour area.Read a book, take a coffee or let the kids play (fairly quietly, one would hope) for a while and erholen sichNice.

Worth the (inexpensive) price of admission. It's charming and serene. Many great picture opportunities abound; they even have an option to dress up in Chinese garb, which I saw many families taking advantage of.

Western influence. We love this place. Beautifully laid out with lots is slave to lose yourself and find some peace. Great for children and also solo. I only wish the food met the scenery. Very Western influenced.

Beatiful gardens. Though we went on a cold and rainy day, these gardens well worth a 1 or 2-hour visit. Located next to Darling Harbour and Chinatown, the gardens are beautifully maintained and it's ideal for a peaceful walk while you admire the traditional Chinese buildings and lakes full of colourful carps. An enjoyable place all in all!
Lovely gardens in the middle of the city. What a great way to get away from the hustle and bustle of Sydney life. The gardens are truly amazing and we love to visit every time we visit Sydney

Peaceful.. Wondered here on a day out in the city, if you have a YHA members card you can get a discount too! The gardens are beautifully maintained and the settings doesn't feel like your in a busy city centre. They have a dress up tea garden in the first half of the garden, which is $10pp I decided to do this and had so much fun. I walked around he rest of the gardens dressed in traditional clothing which got a lot of attention with many selfies later returning to the tea garden there were people queuing up to also get dressed up after seeing me. Great fun and a place for all ages when the sun is shining. - photos are my own.

A Day out w my girl!. Both my daughter & I have been wanting to visit these walled gardens in the city for a long time.Entry fee very modest, was lovely to walk around. Was amazed to see how many people hired the authentic costumes to have their photo taken around the gardens in them-great idea.Felt the overall place needs a bit of a lift, was looking very tired, still enjoyed though.

Serene , peaceful gardens!. Visited the Chinese gardens of Friendship with friend because we reached Darling Harbour quite early and had to kill some time! No regrets! For a small area, it's developed beautifully with mall lakes, traditional structures (not sure what they are called!). Get creative and you can snap some cool pictures!

Beautiful gardens of peace and tranquillity. On visiting Sydney once again I revisited the beautiful Chinese Gardens of Friendship at Darling Harbour.These gardens are a short walk from Chinatown or you can get the people mover from Darling Harbour as far as it goes and then continue to walk which then isn't far.To enter the gardens is like entering another world of beauty, peace and tranquillity from the hustle and bustle of beautiful Darling Harbour. If you have the time take a slow walk around the gardens or just sit and take in the beauty.
Friendly service. A great place to visit $27 entry for two people with two pots of tea and four scones with jam and cream to share in the tea house

Perfect for kids.. An oasis in the heart of Sydney. My ten year old and I absolutely loved the gardens. They supplied us with a treasure map to find the 12 zodiac animals. Thoroughly enjoyable hour spent finding and learning about the zodiac animals in a beautiful setting. Finished off with tea and scones in the tea house. Delicious! Well worth it. Nearby is the Darling Harbour water park which keeps kids thoroughly entertained where mum and dad can sit and have a coffee. If you gave young children I highly recommend it

Really peaceful spot for a sunny afternoon. Such a beautiful and calm garden right off the hustle and bustle of Darling Harbour. Wonderfully laid out, lots of bird and animal life and really well done if you have kids - lots were dressed up in traditional costume and doing trails.

Peaceful and has a calming effect on you. Only minutes from Chinatown. A lovely walk.Quiet and calming.peaceful and quiet.take your camera with you.relax and then walk onto Darling harbour you will love it.

Contemplation and serenity. A wonderful surprise to find this oasis of calm in the heart of the city. A beautifully laid out traditional Chinese garden design with great explanations of the purpose and intent to the design. The kids (7&10) loved exploring and following the Chinese zodiac clues and there was plenty of wildlife (birds, turtles, lizards) to observe as well. Aim to be there around 11.30am to help feed the koi in the jade pavilion. One of the best things we have done in Sydney. Allow about a hour.

Peace and tranquility in the xity. The front of the gardens doesn't do the inside any justice! As we walked in we were blown away at the size of the gardens and the beauty of it all. This made for a lovely afternoon activity.

A spot of tranquility in the city. I'd highly recommend a visit to the Garden to anyone looking for something to do in the city. It was so incredibly refreshing, and the Garden, although relatively small, seemed enormous. There were twists and turns galore, and gorgeous scenery at all angles. The tea house was a lovely addition, and allowed for a half hour break to simply sit and gaze around the garden. Bring a camera to capture some of the beautiful greenery! Admission was under $10, and I felt it was such incredible value. Highly recommend!
Wow . Hard to believe this amazing place sits in the middle of Darling Harbour - a wonderfulOasis. Lovely gardens beautiful place to reflect and savour the moment
Unexpected. This garden is beautiful and right near Darling Harbour so it was very unexpected to find an accurate Chinese Garden so close to the centre of Sydeny
Hidden paradise . With all the busy buildings around darling harbour you would not expect this paradise. Walk inside the gates and the hustle and bustle disappears.

we sell the chinese our country properties and power stations and they give us this garden. well maybe not exactly like that , but they did build this after having a few beers with Neville Wran , It is a nice garden , but you are not allowed to catch and eat the fish swimming in the ponds they are part of the scenery
Great experiencd. Was a great time here, lovely sanctuary from the city. Lots to do and the cafe looked great. Very central and affordable

A welcome little oasis in the heart of Sydney. A great place to spend an hour or more wandering around the serene, peaceful grounds interacting with the local lizards, birds and fish. Enjoy a pot of Chinese tea in the cafe before you leave.
Beautiful Gardens. You have to pay to get in this Garden but it is well worth the 6.00 admission fee. Beautiful and peaceful. Enjoyed tea after our tour.

An absolute must do in the city. Loved the Chinese Garden of Friendship. It is absolutely breathtaking. I took so many beautiful pictures there. It felt like I had been taken to China. The tea room is also great. Walked around and around for an hour. The Ibis are beautiful. All the pagodas are breathtaking. So serene.

A nice quiet spot in middle of sydney. An hour or so is enough to appreciate the pleasant gardens and waterfalls. Turtles and bird life, well established gardens and pathways make for some nice photos.
Relaxing and fun. Unwind and relax, such a beautiful place to relax and have a little fun. Thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and will be going back. Highly recommend
Lovely spot. An oasis in the hustle and bustle. Beautifully maintained and manicure it really is a lovely spot to sit and contemplate, read or people watch.
Wonderful. It is wonderful place but it has little small area. Also you can rent chinesee dress and go on your trip.It is 10$ for adult, 5$ for child. I saw iguana in the water and touched it.

A true Yin Yang experience. If you are in Sydney and exhausted by all the construction work that is going on or tired of all the high rise or maybe the hustle and bustle escape to the Chinese garden located between Darling Harbour and China Town. In one of the pavilions you will find a Yin Yang symbol which is perfect to illustrate the opposing busy city with a tranquil garden. In fact when you are close to one of the many water features you are unable to hear the noise of the city which is literally just the other side of the wall. Whilst only a visitor to Sydney, if I lived there I would visit these gardens every week just to simply escape into a different world. This is one of my most favourite spots in Sydney.

Enjoyable side trip after going to the markets. An enjoyable side trip after going to the markets nearby. Always beautiful and never overcrowded. The gardens are well looked after and very serene. Our little girl loved the interactive search around the garden looking for the animals that represented the Chinese birth years. A magnificent location to take some stunning photographs of the reflections and beauty of the location. Beautiful water dragon lizards sunning themselves around the location. Small entrance fee but not ridiculously priced.
Beautiful. In the heart of sydney. Excellent trip thru the gardens. Lovely staff and awesome gardens. Very peaceful and relaxing.great value too only $6

Waste of money!!!!!!!!!!. We visited the Chinese garden of friendship. It was a total waste of money. There isn't much to see. Had it been free, then can't complain. There is a waterfall pond, a pagoda etc.. It was so noisy due to the construction going on outside surrounding the garden building new apartments. You're better off going to a nearby local park.
Lovely oasis in the city. a lovely time, beautiful gardens. I hadn't been for years but will be back. So peaceful even with all the work going on around
Chines Gardens,Tranquility. A must for any tourist to Sydney. The colour the beauty of the stonework and buildings. The Koi fish

Did not get there this year.. I travel to Sydney at least once a year and on most occasions I manage to visit these gardens. Tranquil and beautiful, a great place to spend a little time to relax and meditate on the beauties of life. Sadly this year I could not fit in a visit.
Tranquil. This is a garden well worth visiting. The grounds are just so peaceful and beautifully set out you will want to remain there forever! You can enjoy refreshments in the tea house too.

serenity in darling harbour. a small but beautiful garden. a showcase of traditional architecture and flora. a must visit for anyone visiting sydney. won't take much time and the time spent is worth it.

Great Tranquility. This is one of the nicest places in Sydney CBD. It is a genuine oasis of peace, tranquility and beauty. The other people at the garden seemed to be infused with the same feeling and we were impressed by the cordiality of the other Chinese Garden guests.

Chinese touch in Sydney. We will know from just the trees .... I think it's Willow trees ?What makes me remember this garden is near the entrance we can find a drinking water fountain, just as what we hope if you are walking from Paddy's to reach here.As if not enough, after drinking you can even sit and relax at the bench under the willows .... feel the wind breeze, imagine it !After then you continue the journey to Darling Harbor.
A slice of paradise. This garden delivered on expectations. It's like being transported to China! The setting is tranquil and a great place to escape the busy Darling Harbor area.
A tranquil place in the middle of towering buildings.. spend a good 2 hours exploring the garden and and drinking green tea here, its a great place to meet and talk with friends.

Lovely oasis but could do with a spruce up. I've visited the garden before and spent time wandering and sitting watching the world go by. Although its still nice to wander through, its starting to look a bit grotty. Lots of things covered in Ibis poo (I imagine this is a huge job, if there was an Olympics for poo, these birds would win every time) and the water had a layer of pollution on top which took away from the pleasure a little. Hopefully I went just before they started spring cleaning.
Peaceful. This is a nice escape from the city. The gardens are tranquil. A great place to just sit. It is also not very expensive. A nice break from the hustle and bustle of Darling Harbour.

A wonderful oasis in the middle of the city. I am ashamed to say that having lived in NSW for 40 years and passed by the Gardens many times on my way through Darling Harbour this was the first time I had gone inside. I was absolutely amazed by the beauty, the tranquility and the wildlife - it really is a different world and not one to be missed.

An oasis in the city. On my last full day in Sydney, I wanted to knock off a few more places off the list, so I walked over to the Chinese Garden of Friendship. What a great place. It completely takes you away from the hustle and bustle of the city.It's a relaxing place to visit. As beautiful as it is tranquil. Definitely worth a stop during a tour of the city.

A must. I love this garden, and have been visiting periodically since it opened in the late 1980s. There's just something about it that makes you feel so calm and at peace. Go on a rainy day, you will have the place to yourself. Lovely!

Tranquility in the City???. Interesting surprise in the middle of a construction zone. Lovely gardens but you need to watch out for birds nesting in the trees overhead and dropping their business from a great height. The pond water was rather dirty which made viewing the fish (koi I think) in the murky water a little difficult.

Hidden Gem in the city bustle. Was firstly impressed by the entrance cost - only $6 for adults - and we spent a long time in the gardens. Everything was well maintained and the staff were very knowledgeable. Had fun feeding the koi too!
A must see place. A great place to spend a couple of hours, not what you expect to find in the middle of Sydney, a really peaceful fascinating spot.

Something happened to this place.. We have visited the place before and was beautiful and very well kept, returned to a visit and the place is dirty, full of birds nesting and spreading dirt everywhere, with no maintenance the place become dirty and smelly. The water in the little lake and river that runs in the garden was very dirty as well.It makes me sad to see such a beautiful place in that condition. Hopefully the summer will bring the bright back.

Traditional Chinese Garden in the middle of Sydney. This is a beautiful little place that showcases all the elements of a traditional Chinese garden. The "borrowed scenery" concept of oriental gardening is a bit weird here as the garden is surrounded by tall buildings on three sides. You can take thirty minutes or three hours to visit it, depending on your mood. We took 45 minutes to explore it as we were in a bit of a rush. You can visit the tea house if you want to spend a bit of time contemplating life while sipping Chinese cha.

Serene Garden. My boyfriend & I vacationed, in Sydney, Australia, in May 2016. While there, we visited this serene garden which is conveniently located by Darling Harbour.. We enjoyed our stroll throughout there.

Exploring Darling Harbour. We enjoyed the Chinese Garden more than we thought we would. Following pathways around and through different areas that depicted a variety of places. I especially loved the black bamboo area and finding wildlife amongst the exhibits...on and the cobbled and arty pavements, pergolas, water features and information at each area. It looks like they also have feature days with extra activities for children. There were a few folk walking around in native dress, another service the gardens offer :) A lovely way to spend an hour in Darling Harbour.

Peaceful stroll, and meditation.. Lovely peaceful garden, a beautiful oasis in the middle of the busy city. Wonderful plantings, rocks and shrubs and wonderful pools and water falls. Great pagodas to sit in and contemplate. Fabulous koi carp pool too.

Beautiful Oasis in the middle of bustling Darling Harbour. We stumbled across the Chinese Garden of Friendship while exploring Darling Harbour on our very short visit to Sydney in June and it was one of the highlights of our stay. The serenity and peaceful water features along with the beautiful plants and chinese architecture was stunning. Loved the giant Koi fish also.
Must see Sydney Attraction. A gorgeous tranquil place to visit when in Sydney. Affordable and relaxing. We visit often. Great for Cosplay photoshoots too😄
Beautiful, tranquil space. Beautiful gardens which are very well designed. A very peaceful walk around the gardens which are also informative.

Peace. Wonderful, serene, peaceful is just a few words to describe this place. We had a lovely couple hours wondering around, there are lots of places to sit and take in the beauty of the gardens. We finished off having tea in the tea house, nice way to sit and reflect on life. Only thing would be to clean the bird poo off seats, paths each morning. Great place to visit.
Magic. Magic place to visit. China in Sydney, we spent a bit of time walkign around and we felt in Bejing. Great!
peace and harmony. Whenever we come to Sydney - we visit the chinese gardens. A little bit of peaceful paradise in this big, bustling city. We just love it.

Oasis in the heart of the city. The Chinese Gardens are beautiful. The scenery is really representative of the Classical Chinese gardens that can be found in China. There is a very serene atmosphere in the gardens and many shady cool places to sit. The cafe has a limited range of food and beverages on offer but provides a pleasant end to the visit.We have visited with family including an infant in a pram. It was a difficult to get around with the pram in some places. But the older children enjoyed walking around the lake and climbing to the pagoda.

OK on a hot day. We've walked past this place a thousand times but one hot J\anuary day decided to stop for a visit.We found it peaceful and tranquil, with some interesting walks despite it's small area. It's well-designed and offers plenty of cool and shade on a hot summer day. A little on the expensive side for what it is.

Being friendly with the Middle Kingdom. The Chinese Garden of Friendship was designed by Sydney's sister city in China, Guangzhou. Guanzhou, formerly known as Canton, sent many migrants to Sydney. The garden is quire delightful, it has a tea-house, statues, groves of bamboo, ornamental trees and a waterfall. The garden is adjacent to Sydney's Chinatown district.
Looking tired and in need up refurbishment.. Part of the Darling Harbour area, this garden is in need of brightening up - mostly cosmetic to entice visitors.

A place of peace in a busy city. Visited here with my grandson. Great cultural experience with added attraction of interesting tasks for the children. Absolutely beautiful surroundings and great photo ops. Lovely tea house on site.

Tranquil haven in the city. We enjoyed a lovely stroll around the pretty gardens. It felt peaceful and it had cute ducklings and nesting ibis in the trees. Our daughter felt like a princess wearing a red chinese outfit (only $5 for as long as we wanted ).
Yummy morning tea overlooking the ponds. The chai tea was wonderful.
A lovely peaceful morning.

cultural experience. Interesting site, very captivating, fantastic experience for our 8 year old up, has a lake & will need younger children watched near water, cafe was reasonably priced, would recommend
Hiiden gem in Sydney!. Beautiful garden where it is nice to have lunch. If you ignore the high rise on the outside you think you are in China

Gardens were nice to walk around but could do with an upgrade. Have been through the gardens say 15 years ago and this time, maybe because it was winter and rather cold, it seemed a bit tired? Not as spectacular as I remembered it? Thought it could do with a bit of a makeover or upgrade, but still a lovely calm place to visit.
Chinese Gardens. These gardens are wonderful but every thing is quite expensive in Sidney but still very worth a visit, very interesting

Teenagers loved it!!?!!. Took our 3 teens there. They loved it...which I was surprised about. They loved exploring. And loved dressing up in the traditional outfits. A tranquil space away from the cities hustle and bustle.
A must see if visiting the city!

Respite in the City. This place is just a short walk south of the Sydney Aquarium and the yacht harbor. If walking here, you should approach from the west side, which is where the entrance is, away from the busy Sydney downtown traffic.The Garden has an entrance charge. This is a good thing, because it’s probably the only thing keeping the garden from being overwhelmed by harried Sydney businessmen seeking a few minute’s peace. And this place has what every Oriental garden should have: a small café. The café specializes in Chinese hot teas in small pots, and has small snacks to accompany the tea.Surrounded by high-rise buildings, the garden has its own high walls, allowing a sense of isolation.

Afternoon Exploring. Had just stumbled across this amazing place so peaceful in such a busy city. Beautiful gardens and waterfall amazing pond at the bottom with Koi Fish swimming around. The kids threw in some money in the wishing well which they loved doing. Really nice place to visit has much to see.
Beautiful Garden in the city. Had a nice stroll in the garden and it was very interesting to see it all. Would suggest as a nice side track between Darling Harbor and Paddy's Market

Excellent quiet place in middle of crazy building frenzy which surrounds it.. We enjoyed this trip into the Chinese Garden. It is beautiful, peaceful, well appointed, and maintained. It's a nice stop if you visit Chinatown. Lots of ibises nesting. (Watch out above your head). Takes about an hour, but could sit and relax longer. There is also a tea garden, but we didn't have time to stay.

enchanting. My daughters loved it here so much, they decided when they grow up and are at uni, this is where they would like to work!
Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful
Very nice Stroll. It was a sudden when we arrived here. The garden reflects very well Chinese pavilion and landscaped gardens. Great place for family

Sanctuary in the CBD . I made my first visit to the gardens in many years when I had spare time on a sunny Friday. The afternoon tea / entry deal is great value. The gardens are bright & secluded from Darling Harbour. I enjoyed the many "rooms", the flora, Pagoda & waterfall. May be even nicer earlier in the day, outside of ibis nesting hours.
The best I have seen in Australia. A very well planned garden, the Chinese had a lot to do with its construction so it is very authentic. Definitely with the visit.

Pretty place. Very nicely laid out garden in Darling harbour. You might miss it if you are not looking for it. The gardens are beautiful with a nice mix of water, different eclectic plants and rocks along with some nice pavilions. Good experience
Oasis. Perfect getaway from the city. Serene from the word go. The multitude of pavilions are all so beautiful.

Ibis central. Great gardens, coulorful koi, great for the adults and kids. However, the ibis have taken over, the place stinks of these unwanted birds. They need to be moved on, spoilt our experience and many others there. I would not return until these 'protected birds' are gone.
Beautiful. Very beautiful gardens here. Its in Darling Harbour i think its $6 to look in the garden. They have a cafe too.
Hidden treasure. A lovely space in the midst of a major city. Very beautiful and tranquil a amazing place to just rest and relax

Peaceful. Stunning. Peaceful.
Hard to believe it is on the edge of a bustling city.
$6 entrance fee...worth it.
Just beautiful 😊

A tranquil setting to enjoy friendship, beauty and clear the mind. Spent half a day in the Chinese Garden of Friendship and loved it! We started by having a delicious afternoon tea at the cafe which was very reasonably priced and then gently and gradually wound our way through each section of the garden. Breathing in the beautiful atmosphere and enjoying the ambience was a calming and clarifying experience for the mind, body and spirit. Very healing! Would love to visit again.
A peaceful escape. Located in the middle to the city and this garden is great for the "escape". Beautiful, peaceful and tranquil garden. Great for photographs too.
WOrth the effort. awondrful place to relax away from the city and only a short walk away.Go at fish feeding time if possible.
Peace amid the hustle and bustle!. Worth every cent, a truly peaceful, relaxing place to take a break from Sydney. No effort to move around, beautiful gardens and well worth a think!

A little piece of Chinese beauty in the city. I absolutely loved the Chinese Garden. I spent a few hours here and wish I had more time to really explore it in it's beauty. The garden is inhabited by various birds which add to the beauty (watch out for droppings!).There is a small restaurant that sells tea and other goodies. We just opted for tea. The architecture here is truly gorgeous! I felt like I was transported to ancient China.Wish I could've been here when they fed the Koi Fish. Magnificent and must come back here for a visit on my next trip here.

A serene retreat from the city. If you've had a long and tiring day in the city and need a rest this is the perfect place to catch your breath. The gardens are absolutely gorgeous, particularly in spring when everything blooms. There are many ponds and lovely bridges and it's the perfect location for a romantic date or for families.

Lovely.. This was an amazing place to spend some time. We explored the whole property and it took probably 15 minutes. Tons of photo ops. Don't forget to finish off your experience with some dim sum. It's yummy!

A peaceful oasis of calm. This area of Sydney is so busy being right near Darling Harbour, but this place is a beautiful peaceful oasis of calm. Spent an hour or so here and saw some great wildlife as well as being relaxed !

A little haven of peace and tranquility. Or at least it would be and perhaps is on the weekend but for the huge amount of development still taking place in the area. nonetheless a nice place to visit and chill a while.
Lovely for a wedding. I went to a wedding ceremony here. It was lovely. Thoroughly recommend it as a wedding venue. It is a very nice spot and the Asian accessible

Great Location. The Chinese Gardens are an oasis in the middle of a concrete jungle. They give you a snapshot of Chinese culture, architecture and design that will open your eyes to another world. Spending an hour or two wandering through the gardens then sitting at the tea house drinking jasmine tea puts tranquility to a new dimension. With the sound of a waterfall in the background the Ibis calling out to each other and colourful Koi swimming in the lake it makes for a wonderful place to relax. If you feel strung out and in a spin or just want some where that is beautiful to spend some time, I recommend that you visit this brilliant oasis in the middle of Sydney.

Small Sydney oasis . Haven't been here for at least 20 years so went with friends today. We did the free 12 o'clock tour which gave us a great insight into the gardens and their history since opening in 1988If you have time go and visit in Darling Harbour and it's not expensive at all

Cultural Visit. The Chinese Gardens were easy to walk to & it's in a lovely setting but the local birds are making a mess & nesting in the trees, spoiling the nature of the gardens. Some of the stairs were steep & we were glad to use the hand rails.

How's the serenity?. This was a shock! The $15 family admission fee is quite possibly the best money we spent while in Sydney. Considering that this site was once old warehouses, the end result of this garden project are truly outstanding!I could have spent much longer here, but really enjoyed just walking around and relaxing in each section of the garden. There were not many people there when we went so the kids were almost on their own feeding the giant gold fish. Everything for this park was brought in, but you wouldn't know it. All of the landscaping seems natural with the buildings and pathways only adding to the overall appeal of the park. I would consider this a must see at Darling Harbour!
Tranquil yet fun in costume. The grounds are beautiful and tranquil. But the real value is spending an extra $10 to get into costume as you explore/parade around. Would definitely recommend!

An oasis of tranquillity. The Chinese friendship garden is well worth a visit. It is right in the centre of the business district and is an unexpected joy. It is beautifully designed with different levels. There is a pleasant cafe.
quiet in the city. Lovely to visit. Calm relaxing in the busy city. Lovely to take time out and just sit and breathe. Lovely plants and gardens

Quiet and Paeceful. I was skeptical about the Chinese Garden of Friendship, but I ended up staying for the entire afternoon. The garden is larger than expected and is divided up into many different areas. I spent time reading about specific features in the brochure and took lots of photos. As I walked further into the garden I was treated to a different perspective and view. There is a tea room with nice views of the water, if you're hungry during your visit. Great value for the $6 entry fee!

Peaceful & Calming. I recommend a visit thats for sure, it is easy to get to and it is in the middle of CBD.Once you step into Garden, you are in a peaceful and calming environment surrounded by beautiful views with the sounds of nature around you.You can sit down and enjoy a cup of tea while observing the Garden or you can walk around to take pictures, even do both :)It is a good way to spend the morning or afternoon for an hr or so while being in a busy city.

Visit to chinese gardens. Nice way to spend an hour or so. Quiet gardens in the middle of a bustling city. Entry fee only $6 per adult. Gardens also have a tea room where you can have some light refreshments at a reasonable price. Worth taking the time to sit and have some tea whilst taking in the tranquility of the gardens. Seating overlooks the little lake.

Beautiful Garden. The gardens are beautiful, we loved meandering around the different 'rooms' in the garden. The only negative- we went with a baby and pram, although there are flat parts, you need to climb quite steep and uneven steps to get the best views and full effect of the garden - very hard to do with a pram.

A place to relax and soak in the views. These gardens are an amazing place to just take a book and coffee and enjoy a calm afternoon there. It's also a very nice place to just enjoy a romantic stroll, or even a solo stroll by the ponds. If you need a break from the city, just go there for a good hour and it will do the job.For tourists, you can dress up in Chinese attire and take photos across the garden. I think the rental charges were 10$ for adults. You'll have to take your own photos but there is no time limit on how long you take the clothes.Dont forget to throw a coin in the pond before you leave!

Cheap entertainment for all the family. With a 6 yr old we visited the Chinese Garden of Friendship in Darling Harbour. For an adult to get into an attraction for under $10 is a great bargain nowadays. But to spend nearly 3 hours there is an absolute steal. They have a place you can hire traditional chinese costumes and get dressed up in, then take your own pictures or the attendant will take some for you if you ask nicely. Our 6 yr old granddaughter had an absolute ball walking around all dressed up. Even got a bit of special attention at the very nice cafe they have in the garden. Food was tasty and wasn't the usual over the top price at all. We visited on a Sunday and there was activities happening (free) including demonstrations. One such was 3 chinese girls playing traditional chinese instruments. Our 6 yr old (still in costume) asked if she could have a pic taken with the girls, they said yes. They then allowed her to have a go at playing the instruments. The garden itself is worth the look but with the cafe and other things, best entertainment money can buy in Darling Harbour I reckon.

Peace and solitude in the middle of the city. Love this place... Its not very big but extremely peaceful when you need to get away from all that city traffic and tourists hustle and bustle.Calming. Watch the Koi swimming around, take tea and enjoy the tranquillity..

Chinese gardens. It is very worth while visiting the Chinese Gardens. It is a good place to meditate or just relax and clear your head while sitting on a bench and reflecting. The gardens are well laid out and as you meander along the pathway a new vista opens up to around each corner. The water and water falls are soothing and calming.
Chinese Garden. Near Chinatown. Wonderful little garden. Told it would take about 45 minutes to see, I spent almost 2 hours looking around. Nice tea room.
Gem in the city. Worth a visit. Found this accidentally. Beautifully done with great plantings. The ibis have taken over - which adds to the charm- but could use a periodic cleaning of bird poop.
great place. Stubbled upon this stop during a day in darling harbour, neat to see such a pretty nature spot in the city

Well designed and constructed Classical Chinese Garden. It's bigger and less-refined than most of the classical gardens in China. Nevertheless the garden is impressive in its ability to stay true to its design heritage, to present new vistas as you walk around, and in its inherent tranquility. Our local Chinese community had some Chinese Opera and other performances scheduled on the Sunday we visited, so it would be worth checking timetables pre-visit. The young girls strolling the gardens in classical dress were enchanting.

A must see local cultural jewel. Located in the midst of high-rise buildings and next to a construction site, its somewhat unassuming outer walls are easy to miss, so make sure to enter the gates to see the magic within. I am attaching several select photos of the dozens I made in the garden to give you a flavor of the beauty within.Inside the garden, there is also a dressing room, which gives you an opportunity to try on the beautiful clothing of a Chinese Empirical official or nobility. An unforgettable experience!

A little piece of China in Aussie!. Built by the Chinese in Darling Harbour, the Chinese gardens are a stunning example of a Chinese scholars garden. Keep an eye out for the lizards that are around, they make for great photos, as do the many Ibis that hand around. The tea shop also does a great range of chinese teas. All told, it is a great respite from the hustle and bustle of the city

mixed review. The garden itself was nice and maintained and what I imagine an oriental garden to be (not having visited asia yet myself). The signs explaining the different features were nice and informative. The garden itself is small and full of people and you can hear the outside traffic and noises. It does not lend itself to being peaceful as you would expect (or maybe i am silly to expect?) and doesn't feel like somewhere you can stay and relax for a while. I wouldn't go again simply because you have to pay to enter and I didn't feel it was worth the money.

Stunningly beautiful for a smallish price. . After a restful lunch at Darling Harbour, the wife and I had renewed energy to continue walking around the area. We came across the Chinese Garden and we're happy to pay the $6 entry fee for a great walk. The gardens are stunning. Waterfalls, cascades, pavilions, rockeries, beautiful plantings everywhere, traditional Chinese architecture, a wonderful ornamental lake and lots of tranquil spots to sit and admire the views. A chance to dress up in traditional clothing for photo ops ( at a cost ) and other activities during the day are available and a tea house as well. Worth the cost.

Garden paradise . The best $6 I spent in Sydney! Its so tranquil and beautiful. I highly recommend going to visit. Its in between the Darling Harbour and Chinatown. They close at 5pm. You can dress up in traditional dress for $10.

Little but nice. Very beautiful gardens just south of Darling Harbour in Chinatown, to show the cooperation and friendship between China and Australia, namely Sydney’s sister city Guangzhou. It is a peaceful garden in the busy city centre which is great, we had a picnic here one day and spent a few hours on a couple of days reading and relaxing while the city buzzed around us. Best part is if you get hungry, there are many great asian restaurants nearby!
A good place to relax. Not very big park, a gift from China. Excellent rest spot, located in Darling Harbour. The place is very peaceful and interesting.

So peaceful. Such a beautiful & serene environment right in the heart of Sydney. With a nominal entry fee this is a lovely place to unwind for a few hours, rest and relax with beautiful scenery.A must do if visiting Sydney.

Peace in the middle of a city. We went here with our granddaughter and she thought it was wonderful. She was able to get dressed as a Chinese child and wander though the beautiful gardens. You could imagine that you were in China. It is well worth a visit.

A slice of tranquility. Within the hustle and bustle of downtown Sydney is a slice of tranquility called the Chinese Garden of Friendship. It is modeled after the private gardens of the Ming Dynasty and offers an insight into Chinese heritage and culture. The walled Chinese Garden recreates the philosophy and harmony of a traditional Chinese garden with waterfalls, lakes, exotic plants, pavilions and hidden pathways. If you want an hour or two of solitude, the Garden allows for an ideal escape from the concrete surrounds and construction activities of Darling Harbour. It also provides beautiful photographic opportunities. Definitely worth a visit.
oasis in the city. if Sydney gets too much go there it is so peaceful and relaxing and a very easy walk from town hall and close to china town
Lovely gardens and nice to chill with a cup of tea. The staff where helpful and walking around was easy. Lovely views and at times you forgot you where in a city.

Beautiful . We decided to visit the gardens as we were at a loss for what to do with our morning. I'm glad we made the effort!It's a $6.00 entry fee to get in but you are able to visit as many times as you like on the day of purchase. The gardens are extremely beautiful and well kept. Just a peaceful place to sit and relax. You can't hear the buzz of the sydney cbd within the walls of the garden, its quite lovely to take a break here.The only thing that turned me off was that the ponds were quite green and in deffinate need of a clean.

Little piece of China in downtown Sydney. OK so not as authentic as the real thing, but behind these walls you could be a world away from Sydney and forget your woes. So peaceful and amazing to just stroll around. The day I was there, people were dressing in traditional costume and make sure you take your camera. Definitely worth seeing. Chinatown is just a few mins walk away so lunch or dinner after your visit to the gardens is not far.

Tranquility like no other . This is my Shangri-La, the very epiphany of tranquility & beautiful all rolled into one! I spent an hour in complete harmony admiring the garden design & beautiful plants which make the place so unique!

Beautiful Gardens. A peaceful and relaxing place to visit right in the middle of the city. Places to sit, waterfalls, gardens, statues and plants - lovely and serene, I recommend a visit to everyone who visits Sydney

Very peaceful walk in the midest of the harbour. I loved exploring the gardens with my partner. It was beautiful and provided a nice quiet break. Very photogenic place with beautiful gardens and ponds. Worth paying to see.

More fun than I expected!. It's a beautiful garden and what made it fun for our kids was a little game where they give you a paper with animals photos and you have to find hidden statues of those animals across the whole garden. It kept the kids interested and enthusiastic which is a very commendable achievement - all credit to the folks running the garden! They also rent out traditional Chinese costumes that you could wear as you walk the garden - we didn't try it but saw some who did and they looked really nice.

Another gem in the city. I first went there when it was first built, where it was virtually a lot of rock & frameworks, but now, it has become so tranquil & lots of little sit down areas to take in a different aspect of the garden. Worth the visit.

Relaxing. The garden has a small fee but the environment is very peaceful and relaxed. There are several water features and buildings. It started raining halfway through our visit but three is a good amount of coverage if necessary and it was still nice.

A peace of Paradise!!. ok this is an amazing place!
i think we paid 6 dollars per person, not expensive! And it worth all the cents!
It's literally a peace of paradise in the middle of Sydney!!
Don't miss it!!

Peaceful, beautiful gardens. Just off Darling Harbour you will find the Chineese Garden. There is a small admission charge. Today when we visited they had just finished a wedding ceremony and the bride and groom were still having their pictures taken. The gardens are very scenic, only spoilt by the high rise buildings around.

Surprisingly pretty good!. Doesn't look big on the map, but head inside and be amazed at how much there is to explore inside the walls. Everything is beautiful and well maintained, plus it is amazingly quite and peaceful inside considering you are in the centre of the city and right next to a freeway.
Garden have pay tickets to enter. I think I look like botanic gardens but not. You have to pay tickets to enter. Nothing special inside

Peace in the midst of busy city. The title says it all. After spending your day in the busy Sydney, it feels nice to spend some time in quietness here. The fish pond is my favourite. My encounter with wild birds is something priceless.

Peaceful oasis in middle of the city. Beautifully landscaped, explore at your own pace. Plenty of plaques to describe what you're seeing. You can dress in the original Chinese Costumes & have enough for ALL sizes!
Feel peace & beauty. It's a very nice, calm and green garden, very cosy and sweet. Take English tea for 5 o'clock and enjoy this place.

An ideal spot to relax. This garden offers a great place to relax in a green surrounding with the sounds of birds and waterfall in the background. It was properly arranged to promote Chinese feng shui. It has a teahouse serving light meals and various types of Chinese tea.

Peace and tranquillity, and tea. We intended to visit for an hour, three hours later we left, refreshed and at peace with the world. The garden is splendid, trees, shrubs, plants, water and rocks together with buildings and pathways make this place a supprise and delight at every turn. Then there was dressing up as a Chinese emperor and having your photo taken not something I would normally do, but the girls made it fun and enjoyable. And then there was tea, many choices served with the lightest scones I have ever had. When we left it felt that time had stood still, and we just drifted for the rest of the afternoon.

Relaxing oasis in the heart of the city. It's always a pleasure to visit the Chinese Garden of Friendship in the Sydney CBD. It's relaxing, visually appealing and allows you to escape the hustle and bustle of the city for a little while.

Such beauty in such a small area. We stopped off here from the hop on-off bus and were so surprised at the beauty in this small awesome Chinese garden. We ambled along the walkway past the lake, sculptured rocks, mosaics, pagodas, statues, waterfall, flowers, and trees. We had a map, but everything is also labeled. Definitely worth the visit.

Amazing day out!!. This place is beautiful and also so much fun.
We went as 2 couples & dressed up in the traditional chinese dress which made the experiance even better.
Got some awesome photos and really enjoyed our time there.
Whether you want a peaceful walk or a good laugh in stunning surroundings this is the place to go!!
Go there to relax.. Just nearby our hostel at darling harbor was nice lakes and pagodas and a peaceful retreat.Then there are lots of cafes and shops in the area nearby.

Serenity in the city. For a nice break from the noise and activity of the surrounding city, the gardens offer serenity and visual delight. Whether sitting on a bench and watching the koi or admiring the seasonal plants, bonsai and architectural elements, the traveler seeking a different experience will be pleased. This is not an attraction for everyone as it is quiet and low key.

A wonderful contrast to the inner city. A good place to clear your head and recharge your energy levels.. I have been visiting this beautiful garden for over 12 years so I really pushed my family to visit with me this trip. They loved it so we spent more time here than we expected. The teenagers took lots of photos and even sat quietly to take in the views.

How's the serenity!. Wow, what a magical place. We spent 2.5hours just walking around and enjoying the gardens. Came away with some amazing photos. Wished I took my blanket and a book. I could've stayed all day. And for $6 it was well worth it. Plenty of fish and turtles in the ponds, lovely waterfalls and magnificent gardens. Take your time going through it so you can appreciate the atmosphere.

Our favourite place in Sydney. A glorious oasis in the bustle of Darling Harbour. It is not large but it is perfectly formed with many places to sit and reflect. A highlight is sitting in the tea house sipping tea watching the koi swim just below you. There are facilities to hire traditional dress if you wish and there is a Chinese horoscope trail for kids to follow. Always on our must visit list.

SO CHEAP and so beautiful. I took my parter here and was blown away at the value for money $6 for an all day pass, includes a map of the garden which makes a great momento. My parter was so captivated by the garden. we didn't but you can rent authentic costumes and have your makeup done for photos, Great place to take a walk with a loved one

A quiet, beautiful placeto escape the city. We very much enjoyed our trip to the gardens, even though it's very central to Sydney, it's very peacful. We bouth the traquil teatime ticets which included the entry, a pot of tea each and dim sim. This was an excellent deal, they have a wide selection of teas and their cafe is situated with a beautiful view of the gardens. Highly reccommended for a chill out day in the city.

Now is not the time.... The garden is very zen: a small, tranquil space. But not at the moment.Presently the gardens are surrounded by out of control, unchecked property development, with the construction of the huge new convention centre across the way. Dusty, loud, corrupt and laboured. Find the zen in this.When the construction is completed, I recommend looking at the Garden's website to see the time of the daily tour/info session. Until then, if you find yourself in the neighbourhood I would suggest table tennis outside the CBA building in Tumbalong Park (3 minutes walk away).Adult: $6; Child: $3 (under 12 years)

Nothing special but a peaceful place of chinese culture. The park is now surrounded by a busy highway, overshadowed by many buildings and hotels, and rather touristy inside. Not worth the fee to go in, oriental as it may be, but plenty other natural spots just outside, and along Darling Harbour.
Beautiful. I have walked past these gardens for years and never went in.....silly me! Such a lovely place to visit in the city.

An Oasis in the city. This was our second visit here and although there is a great deal building work going on it is still a tranquil place for a few hours. It is still a little oasis and has quiet nooks and crannies to explore. It's a great place to relax and be calm in the hustle and bustle of the city.

Loved it. Although we went on a rainy day, the majority of this beautiful place is under covered walkways. So peaceful in the middle of the hustle of Darling Harbour. We also had something to eat and drink, all very serene and peaceful. Once the sun had come back, walking around was very relaxing.

Beautiful. Don't miss this - it's a beautiful way to spend an hour or two. It's extensive and you feel like you can pick your own path through it, so it never feels crowded. To say it's RIGHT in the CBD, it is sooo serene and peaceful.
Lots of places to sit and take pics, etc. Great for kids.
Amazing.
Beautiful tiny spot. Very nice walk around. Got discount for being HI member. Took great pictures of nature and pagodas. Worth the visit.
a quite peaceful place. the moment you enter this amazing Garden the hustle and bustle of the city is lost behind its walls the wandering and seeing the different rooms was amazing

A beautiful oasis in a great City. If you are tired of walking and shopping and on your way back to the City from Darling Harbour or just wanting somewhere beautiful to 'chill out' then head for these beautiful gardens - you will not be disappointed.

Peaceful beautiful garden in the city. We loved this Place! As close to the busy streets it is, it is so peaceful and beautiful Place. Walking there you get the feeling you are somewhere else. Excellent desing of the garden!

Garden Tranquility - a must see landscaped paradise. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is a must see feature at Darling Harbour. This landscaped garden has meandering footpaths, lakes and waterfalls. The site is a beautiful mixture of featured limestone boulders and lush bushes, lilies, bamboo and flowers. We enjoyed a relaxing lunch at the Chinese Teahouse, while overlooking the spectacular main lake. The reasonable entry charge is well worth the quality venue. Enjoy.

Peaceful beauty.. I was very impressed with this garden. They have done a really good job of creating it. Beautiful is one word I can use to describe it. Peaceful is another . To look down on it all from the highest spot and to look across the pond at all is very calming. How could one ever not feel happy and at peace while in here......but we did come on a brilliant sunny day. Would it be any different on a rainy day? Except wet. The cost to get in is worth it, there is a tearoom should you wish to have some refreshment, and once you have paid the entry you could exit and enter as much as you wish throughout the day. And it's just a stones throw from Chinatown if you feel like some nosh once you finished relaxing in here. Well worth taking the time out to visit.

A lovely morning visit. We came here for a morning visit on our way to darling harbour. We had our 3.5 yr old and we all had a lovely time walking the garden, seeing water dragons, and finding the Chinese zodiac shapes. The garden was tranquil and a lovely place to visit Ina busy city.

Peace in a busy city. Step into another world of waterfalls, lakes and stone pathways. It was easy to feel at peace here away from the busy city.Tranquil and relaxing.The Tea Room Restaurant served excellent snacks and the visiting lizards around the tables were a wonderful addition. Loved it.

Beautiful Gardens and activities for the kids. Great for a family group or couple to go for a nice walk. Entrance fee is worth the views and the kids get an activity to complete inside which is alot of fun.

From Shetland to Australia. This is such a beautiful place. You would never know looking from the outside just how amazing it is inside.For 10 dollars you can get dressed in traditional costume( over your own clothes) no need to undress, then you can get photos taken. What a novel idea.
Beautiful Scenery. The Chinese garden of friendship was a surprisingly good time. I really didnt know what to expect when we entered but was blown away by the gardens.

Charming and tranquil. The garden was recommended to us by friends. The gardens are beautifully set out and well kept. Even though it was raining during our visit it didn't spoil the experience. A beautiful tranquil setting in a busy city.. The staff are friendly and welcoming. The cafe served a range of teas and tasty snacks.
Peaceful. A nice peaceful garden tucked away in the busy city. $3 entry for students which includes a detailed map. Really enjoyed the bamboo Forrest and the centre lake

Beautiful Oasis in a big City. Well worth taking a look. This has been extended from the original Chinese Garden, spectactacular waterways wonder through a magnificent Chinese Garden. Don't miss the tea house.

Such serentiy. The Chinese Garden is in the middle of the city and massive construction going on. You need to go in there and enjoy the beauty and try to tune out the construction noise. Great pix, gorgeous waterfalls and the bldgs are exquisite. Great value and your pix will be gorgeous that you take there.

Very peaceful afternoon. We took a "train "ride around Darling Harbour just for a bit of fun and saw the Chinese Garden of Friendship from the outside and we were curious what was behind the walls.We decieded to take a look after a very busy few days in Darling Harbour.In the middle of the city is the most peaceful area we have ever been to. The many walkways took us around lovely landscaped gardens where beautiful waterfalls dropped into tranquil lakes. Golden carp swam amoungst the lillies and "Lizzards" roamed around the gardens or sat lazilly in the sun. There were a large number of native birds free to come and go as they pleased. We originally thought that we would be in the Gardens for an hour or so, but we stayed for several hours just walking around and unwinding. We ended our day sitting by the edge of a lake with a cup of hot chocolate and a scone from the Cafe, while watching the Golden Carp and a "Lizzard" that wandered around our feet waiting for nibbles "accidently" dropped by my wife.

Peace in a building site. Close to a number or busy roads and on the edge of the reconstruction of this area of Darling Harbour, this is not currently a great attraction for the tourist. Nice gardens, not a lot in the way of flowers in bloom and water features. Quite a lot of Black Ibis and Koi Card but thats about it.Disappointingly the Senior Citizen Discount on the entry fee only applies to Australian Citizens. Perhaps in the UK and Europe we should withdraw this facility for all Australian Senior Citizens!

Oasis of Tranquility in Sydney. This place is fantastic. Not sure how much it usually costs to enter but we were lucky as they were having a 'gold coin' donation entry day so got in for a couple of dollars. What a great place. It's just like being in China. There is a pathway that you can follow all the way around so that you don't miss anything. There are lots of places to stop and take in the views and just relax. While you are there you can de-stress. When we were there, there was a zodiac hunt for the kids to keep an eye out for models of the animals. We also saw some sort of Ghecko (a real live one) that lived there. They also have clean modern toilets. There are ponds, waterfalls, buildings, pagoda's etc and at the end a small tea shop / café. This is a must see while in Sydney. Look up and you can see the Skyscrapers, look down and you could be in China!

An Oasis in the heart of Darling Harbour. What a wonderful place this is. Quite breathtaking in fact. The feeding of the fish at 11 am is a great experience. The Koi are enormous. The grounds are very well laid out with so many interesting features. There is a tea room which looked good although we did not participate.

A little disappointing. Whilst this is a tranquil area in the middle of busy Darling Harbour/Sudney, I was a little disappointed with the content. lots of rock, and water, and greenery, but little in the way of much else. You can pay extra to dress up in Chinese dress if that's your thing, and it's fine for a quick visit, but the entrance fee made me want a little more.
A gift to the Aus from China. Typical Chinese garden full of rocks and water . A chance to try on the Chinese robes and headwear for a fun photo oportunity
If you dont have extra time dont visit. Sydney is full of treasures and this shouldnt be on yout top 10 to do in Sydney, yes it is beautiful but dont spend the time you dont have here
a green spot in the city. the chinese gardens are so lovely, and its in the middle of the city! you can stay there as much as you want and just enjoy the beautiful silence.

Amazing and Peaceful. Walled Chinese garden in the middle of the city featuring pavilions, exotic plants, ponds & waterfalls, including a teahouse. A peaceful place to get away it is like a secrete garden. We have been letting all our family and friends know about this gem and no one has been dissapointed. Also you can get dress up in there amazing costumes for a little extra.

Calm sport in a crazy city. Beutiful gardens to visit I did think the price was a bit steep for what is was so we made sure to take advantge and do the tour too, we even did the childrens game to find all the zodiac animals hidden amonst the garden. The tour was very intresting so try and catch it if you can , we spent a few lovley hours in the garden and was lovely to find somthing so natural in the big city and made a intresting contrast with the skyscrappers in the back around . God plce to visit with kids as long as you are carefull around the water areas .

Small peaceful garden. Really lovely way to spend an hour easy to walk around and very pleasant. We went on a sunny day so we really enjoyed it. You can dress up in traditional costumes, there is a cost for this, but its great fun for children.

Blissful!. What an amazing place to get away from the rat race and just wander around and enjoy the awesome surroundings. Definitely worth a visit whether you are alone or with family. You can pay $10 to dress up in costume and walk around the gardens. Brilliant!!!!

A serene spot in the hustle bustle of Sydney. A lovely place, worth a visit. A highlight tour gives you an insight into the Chinese philosophy on life. Only wish it could be made soundproof to cut out the traffic noise around the garden. It's so annoying. Overall a must visit place.

Special Garden. Easy to find in Darling Harbour. Established plants and garden with large ponds and water feature. Huge carp. Well thought out. Follow the paths or stop and relax. Very peaceful. Lovely tea house. Take a book sit, rest be mindful, read and drink tea.

Chinese Garden of Friendship. We are in Sydney for just two days before boarding the Explorer of the Seas for a repositioning cruise back to Seattle. We had taken a six hour tour of Sydney and the surrounding areas so yesterday we decided to walk around. My wife saw the gardens listed on a map so we decided to visit it. Much construction surrounding the gardens but upon entering ($6 p/p) we found ourselves emersed in the beauty and tranquility of a true Chinese garden. We spent about an hour here watching and listening to the nesting cranes and other birds, observing the beautiful Koi, and just relaxing. This was truly a wonderful experience and I highly recommend it if you have just a few hours to spend in Sydney.

Stunning. My friend and i stumbled across this stunning place as we were on our way to darling harbour. For a small fee, we found inside the most beautiful views. It was so quiet, peaceful and just absolutely wonderful. We spent a few hours here just sitting in the sunshine and taking in all the beautiful views it had to offer. if you like the quiet or are looking for something relaxing to do then you should definately come here!

A tranquil place to reflect in the heart of the City. This is a must to visit, so beautifully laid out and tranquil, right in the heart of Sydney close to Darling Harbour. Wonderful plants and even wildlife, I saw a small lizard and some dragonflies. My photos were fantastic, with waterfalls, a lake, pagodas and a shaded walk through bamboo canes. Absolutely breathtaking.
relaxing place in the middle of the city. a beautiful place in the middle of the city. the asiatic style changes from the buildings around (very modern)a very quiet place in the middle of sydney
Outstanding place. A nice cosy japanese garden in downtown Sydney. A nice place for afternoon tea ceremony. Enjoy the waterlily, and the waters cascades.

Oasis of tranquility. I last visited approximately 15 years ago and it's still wonderfully relaxing. More noise from outside but this is quickly forgotten after a few minutes. Try having a Chinese tea in the cafe. Also try and spot the hidden animal signs around the garden. Good activity for children. Most enjoyable.

Quiet place to relax. Although this garden is hard to find due to the extensive renovations/construction that are being done in the Darling Harbour area, it is worth the visit. Although there is an entry fee, it is moderately priced and you can spend a few hours just sitting around the various parts of the garden while reading, talking with friends, or enjoying the peacefulness. It reminds one of such gardens found in several cities in China although it certainly is not as extensive or ornate.

Worth a visit. A tranquil oasis in the heart of the city. Parts of the garden look a little neglected but overall it's a beautiful place to visit with it's waterfall, ponds, pagoda and Tea House (which we didn't avail ourselves of). A nice place to spend some time in and lose yourself.
Peace & Quiet. A lovely garden and an oasis of calm in the middle of Sydney. Water features, bridges and pagodas make up a well set out garden, loved it.

Worth the admission fee. The gardens are quite vast for the footprint they occupy. They offer afternoon tea but unfortunately we were too full to try it. You can rent period costumes to take pictures but this was kind of overpriced ($15 per costume, I think).
very tranquil and peaceful. It is a nice place to visit in the heart of the city. Wouldn't go again unless it was free though. Nice little cafe inside

Lovely little oasis. In the built up area of darling harbour this is a great little bit of peace and calm. It is all well cared for and the staff were really helpful, not just with the garden but the area in general.

Excellent way to spend a couple of hours . Came here today with my husband & bother in law on his suggestion. Wow, what a beautiful place, stunning, quiet and peaceful. Very pretty and so much to see, I would highly recommend this to anyone.

So little space, So much to deliver. This garden is tucked away at the end of darling harbour and blocked by construction and highways so it is not very easy to find. Although it is appropriately placed being a stepping stone to china town which was a 1 minute walk away. Once entering the garden you are greeted with a wishing well. Seeing as Luck is a popular trend in Asian culture this was a good idea! The entrance fee was A lot cheaper than i expected considering that i paid with some space change i had in my pocket, it is great place to spend your lunch break and relax for a while. The garden shows off traditional Chinese landscaping, architecture, culture, flora and fauna. Being such a small space, there isn't much to do but take pictures, drink tea, and maybe even try some meditation beside the waterfall to kill some time.

Very peaceful and beautiful. We arrived about 45 minutes before closing thinking that would be plenty of time, but once we entered we wished we'd saved more time! It is amazingly peaceful and beautiful throughout the garden. I enjoyed the information on the symbolism and decisions about what to place in the garden. Beautiful location for photos and great place to just sit and enjoy the scenery.

Serene enviroment. The Chinese Gardens are in a busy area of Sydney, but once you walk through the entrance everything seems to calm down and there a really quite and peaceful quality about the place. The trees and water falls give a relaxed feel to the gardens and at the end of the walk there is an open air coffee shop which offers a sampling of Chinese cakes with a choice of coffee or several varieties of Chinese teas. Also serves the usual Western fare like scones and cream. Well worth a visit.

Peaceful even in the middle of the city. We visited right around the Chinese New Year, it's a lovely experience, so tranquil, well looked after gardens, loved the ponds, waterfalls and the koi were great, could just watch them all day. Loved it.

A true gem!. If you love gardens, if you love art, if you seek peace and a place to withdraw, this is it! The $6 entrance fee belies the value of this gem. Winding paths around lakes, streams and waterfalls, through glades and hills affords a mountain top experience. This is a genuine Chinese Garden experience, a true peaceful haven in the bustle of the city.

A place to relax and unwind. This garden is a real surprise in the middle of busy Sydney (Darling Harbour). Beautifully designed with plenty of spots to sit down and relax.Loved the tranquility, the Pagoda's and the fish in the ponds. People watching (i.e. people being photographed in traditional Chinese outfits) was good too.I have been back a couple of times since..

What a beautiful hidden gem!. What a beautiful hidden gem! I had walked past the Chinese Garden of Friendship many times but did not expect it to be so peaceful! A lovely way to escape the noise and hustle and bustle of Sydney.

Tranquility in the midst of all other things. If you get a chance do NOT miss the opportunity to visit these lovely gardens.A sea of tranquility it is amazing to think of all the construction works & the busy harbour that surrounds the lovely gardens. For a small fee you can be dressed as a Chinese emperor for the purpose of a little fun & some photos. well worth the effort to visit. Highly recomended.

A true haven of peace and pagodas!. For those wishing to escape the noise and bustle of Sydney's CBD, this exquisitely planned Chinese garden is located on the edge of Darling Harbour. Lush flora and so atmospheric. Golden carp dreaming, winding paths of mystery and dynastic architectural wonders await. Truly beautiful and lovingly maintained!

Don't miss out on these Gardens. Been to Sydney many times and always visit the Chinese Garden. It always seems quiet and never excessively busy. If you just want some peace and quiet, even for just an hour, then this is the place to go. Good value also with such a low entrance fee. Nice place to visit for a stroll after lunch in Darling Harbour!
a peaceful place amid running Sydney. Experience peace and calmness here. Sit down for a while. I found this place all of a sudden while going to Power House Museum from Darling Harbor.

Lovely tranquil spot amongst the madness....
