With all of the construction noise, and masses of people about- our trip to the gardens was just what we needed to refresh ourselves after epic shopping ;)It would be good if there were a few grassy spots you could sit and read or reflect, but a jasmine tea in the teahouse, and the waterfall were a beautiful reprieve from the business outside the wall, and had a soothing, calming effect on us.

Lovely Garden. This garden is a nice walk and enjoyable experience. They have a game your kids can play where they search out animals using clues. My daughter loved it and made us go through the Gardens 3 times to find all the animals over and over again. Highly Recommend.

very relaxing way to spend an hour. beautiful gardens, lots of water, ornamental lakes, bonzai trees, water lilys, wonderful pavilions, tea room, plenty of places to sit and relax. it is situated at the end of Darling Harbour, just beyond an incredible water park for children. I will upload pictures when I've managed to get them from my camera!
This is the start of 'Chinatown'

Chinese Gardens are are nice relaxing stop. We happened to stop here and were so glad that we did! A beautiful and scenic escape from the bustle of rushed crowds around Darling Harbour. We spent about 2 hours walking the paths and enjoying the perfect landscape and water. Definitely worth the $6 admission and the time to sit and relax and enjoy such a well cared for and manicured garden. Simply stunning in all respects.

A tranquil paradise in the centre of Sydney. The Chinese Gardens of Friendship is the most beautiful Chines garden I have visited in the world. The landscaping is superb, it is well maintained and a wonderful escape from the busy-ness of Sydney right next door. Absolutley worth a visit and taking time to relax and enjoy

A haven of real peace in a busy city - great to recharge. We stayed in Darling Harbour and had spent a full on month in Australia and wanted something a little quieter on the last morning of the trip. I found this amazing place. Really easy to get to. Cheap to get in. A truly beautiful garden, well worth an hour or so. I did not rate the tea shop at all - a bit of a let down

oasis in the city. You must take an hour to visit this gem. So relaxing and calming. The gardens and waterfall are beautiful. There is a huge pond full of koi fish. Lovely walkways and rockerys add to the charm of the gardens.

A beautiful and calm oasis in the city. This is one of my favourite places to visit in Sydney. We were in Sydney over Easter and we were sure to visit here. It's a beautiful and calm place to relax after a busy day sightseeing in Sydney. The staff are friendly and helpful here too. Definitely park your pram in the front as some parts are not pram accessible. It is well worth the visit, you will feel calm and relaxed.
Nice garden but dirty around. I really like the place, the falls, lakes, fish, water dragons but in the surrounding was very dirty of the tourists due to the lack of rubbish bins in the garden.

Wonderfully relaxing. Staying nearby in Darling Harbour my husband and I decided to walk down to see what we had heard so much about. It gives one a sense of serenity and peace and was an excellent way to conclude our sightseeing in Sydney.
" In the Heart of Town". This little beauty in the middle of a large city, SydneyIts so Beautiful to see a Chinese Garden in the City....This is a must to see (-:
Beautiful!. Perfect if you want a peaceful morning or afternoon. The garden is stunning and it is great for pictures

Quietitude and Serenity in the heart of busy Sydney. I love going here and bringing friends here. It is such a serene escape from the busyness of Sydney. The cost is cheap and the tours are no extra cost. It is worth having a tour as it helps to understand more about the intricacies of the designs and the plants. Cafe available inside, toilets also. Accessible from Darling Harbour.

Hidden garden gem. Really enjoyed our time here! The gardens are beautiful and very well maintained. The guide your given is nice so that you can easily follow along. There are views of trees, water, flowers and structures at every turn and it really is tranquil. You can get a cup of tea at the end of the tour and relax for a bit and at 10am they feed the koi fish.

Beautiful serene garden. If you like Chinese-style gardens, visit this one, too. It's a nice walk with different paths and routes to take, and plenty of beautiful scenery. A cute small waterfall, a bigger one, a nice lake, a small "mountain" path, plenty of small or bigger pavilions where you can sit and take in the scenery. Every part has a small sign that well explains the design of the construction and the meaning of it. They feed the fish around 11:30 with is fun for the kids to watch (the fish rush to get the food!) and they can help feed them, too. They have a cafe near the end of the route where you can sit down and have some food or a drink.
So peaceful. What a lovely place to visit. In among all thenoise of the city is this gem. A lovely couple of hours walking around here. Nice tea ROM also.

Tranquility amidst a metropole. This is my second visit to the garden of friendship. This symbolically displays the link between the Chinese and Australians. It is a wonderful microcosm of the peace, care and attention to detail that is paid by so many people around the world. Spending time in this garden reminds us of the beauty that surrounds us in nature. The water features are alive with life with fish in abundance, the bush & trees around provide refuge to many bird species. The tea garden is a tranquil place to put your feet up and stop and enjoy the peace.
Beautiful. Lovely relaxing place to visit in the middle of the city. Worth the walk about to enjoy the calm atmosphere.

A quiet oasis. A hidden gem. well worth the small admission charge for a little peace and quiet away from the hustle and bustle of the city. A lovely tea room and home made cakes finish off the tour of the gardens nicely. Spent a lovely hour walking around.
Tranqil oasis in city. Worth the entrance fee, lovely gardens, nice snack in restaurant; well kept and imaginative use of plants and rocks and water

From Canton with love. The Chinese Garden of Friendship was presented to the people of Sydney by the city of Guangzhou in 1988, Australia's bicentennial year., Guangzhou is better known by its Anglicised name of Canton. Chinese gardens on the whole do not have a lot of flowers, instead they have water and bamboo features.which are intended to calm the viewer. The day I visited the Gardens were very busy, it is a bit of a tourist trap. Try to visit early in rhe morning when you can appreciate the serenity the Gardens are intends to induce...

Hidden Gem. Caught train to Town Hall and then walked down Liverpool Street, walked over a small pedestrian bridge and you were at the side of the gardens, followed the signs to the entrance. Adults $6 - bargain. Arrived at 11.30am just in time for the carp feeding from a pavilion. Then spent a pleasant hour wandering around the gardens. Such tranquil gardens in the middle of a busy city. Finished up by having lunch in the onsite cafe. Salmon roll and pot of tea was $12.00. Very pleasant and plenty of tables in several pavilions where you can sit and eat. Watched a small wedding ceremony taking. Very pleasant visit. Would recommend.

Awesome in spite of the Construction. Almost completely surrounded by the construction of the ICC, this garden is a sharp contrast to the chaos that lies outside it's gate. This is a must visit, for a nominal fee it can bee seen in approximately a half hour. My six year old enjoyed looking for the Chinese Zodiac animals and my wife and I enjoyed the fact it is impossible to take a bad picture here. This is a great option for an attraction that can be enjoyed before leaving for the airport.
Tranquil. Really enjoyed our visit to the Chinese Garden of Friendship. It is an oasis of peace in the centre of Sydney. Be sure to see the carp being fed

Stunning Gardens. If yoiu love oriwental garden design you must see this garden in the centre of the Sydney CBD near china town. Great vistis and authentic plantings of established traditioinal oriental should I say chinese plants and fixtures. Waterfalls lakes bamboo rocks and forests all there. Come and have a look its worthwhile.

Tranquil . Having traveled around Japan I've seen some impressive gardens but I'm confident in saying that this garden is comparable to some of the best I have been to. There is a $6 entry fee but don't let that put you off. Once you walk around to the main area with the big lake the wow-factor will hit you. It took us about an hour to explore the gardens but even if you don't have much time it is worth it for a quick stroll. You'll certainly feel more relaxed when you leave. I should point out that there was some construction happening outside the gardens. The noise did detract from the experience, particularly around the edges of the garden. I would imagine this would be quite the tranquil place once the construction is finished.
Chinese garden. What a beautiful place a real Jem ,it is hard to believe it the place is enchanting ,the plants the animals and the people great place
A little oasis near the bustle of Darling Harbour. This is a peaceful and well thought out Chinese garden, and very cheap. Definitely worth a visit. Some wildlife to be seen.

So Peaceful in the centre of a City. Well kept and certainly worth a visit. We strolled round these beautiful gardens and loved every minute of it. We also had a light lunch here which was very reasonably priced.
Peaceful haven.. A truly lovely garden. It is so calming and full of interest. Could have stayed for hours just sitting.

Surprisingly beautiful . We have now been living in Sydney for almost four years and always gave the Chinese Garden a miss. Until today. We have heard of a "zodiac treasure hunt" where kids have to find the 12 Chinese zodiacs. It's 6 AUD entrance for an adult. I have to say, it's a nice little oasis in the middle of town. Yes, it's not big and some may call it boring but we actually enjoyed the short walk. Only problem: whilst they say that 70% is accessible with a stroller, it's probably less and some path are rather bumpy. But if you are on foot, go for it!

Tranquil and a great place to reflect. Tearooms are available. I was surprised when I stubbed upon this place when walking from darling harbour to central station. The gardens are just gorgeous. I great place to take time out and reflect. There is a Chinese tearoom in behind the walls. The children will enjoy this place too. It's not the place to run around though so a pram is best with small kids Opening hoursShare the secret of the Chinese Garden every day of the year, except Good Friday and Christmas Day.9.30am – 5pm (April – September)9.30am - 5.30pm (October – March)AdmissionAdult: $6Child: $3 (under 12 years)Family: $15 (two adults and two children)Concession: $3(Australian pensioners and students only) Senior: $4.50 (Australian seniors only)Tours are also available

Peace and quiet in the middle of Sydney . Not massive but still an authentic experience away from the busy hub of Sydney. A lovely place to contemplate and unwind, especially by the lovely waterfall area!
terrible. Hard to get to, no bus no train no light rail, bloody expensive ticket to get in, and the place smell...

The free tour is a must-do if visiting. Located right in Darling Harbour, it is a little hard to find because of the construction, but well worth it! 6$ for admission. There are free guided tours at 10:30am and 2:30pm everyday and a plant-specific tour around noon. We took the 10:30am tour. I would highly recommend the tour. It is a beautiful place on its own, but taking the tour lets you know about the history of the place. For example there is a dragon piece near the beginning... wonderful to look at, but we learned from the tour guide that the blue dragon represents Sydney in NSW and the brown dragon represents the Guangdong region of China and the ball they are both reaching for in the center represents their friendship. We wouldn't have known that without the tour! There was lots of other interesting information provided. The tour ran about 30 minutes, I think it was actually a little short, I would have liked a longer tour so we could have covered more of the gardens. But overall, would recommend to do and would go again if visiting Sydney in the future!

One of Largest Chinese Gardens outside China. Was there during Ne Year's celebration so extra activities going on. As all Chinese Gardens, this is beautifully executed with stone and water features. Abundant ibis and koi. Nice tea house. Darling Harbour area.

Chinese Garden. A must visit for anyone who appreciates loveliness. An island of calm in a busy city. The gardens are not big enough to make your feet ache but just the right size to help you relax and take the strain out of a busy day in the city. Lovely

Very basic chinese garden. The garden was not really well decorated despite it's the lunar new year period when we visited. They could have at least lit with the Chinese lanterns along or around it but supposed for a western country standard, not many would have known the difference. Not exactly a place that we would visit again.
right in Darling Harbour. a good place to visit and right in China town.....you weill be amazed that this is right in the center of the city well worth a visit

A nice way to spend an afternoon. Highly recommend. Its only $6 for admission... not too bad for tranquility in the middle of the city. I wander amongst the gardens and then sat down to enjoy the pond. Just a lovely quiet time out from the crazy city.

A place of solitude. In the bustling city of Sydney it was so nice to find a spot where you could relax and enjoy the peace and quiet of this garden. Reasonably priced my family thoroughly enjoyed a quiet walk through the many mock temples and facades. Very nicely landscaped with the lakes and rockeries.The children would enjoy the feeding time of the many koi carp or goldfish.

Quiet in the middle of a city. A beautiful quiet area to visit in the Darling Harbour area. They are building around it at the moment so it is noisy but amazingly enough that disappears once you relax into the garden.

Serenity abounds. This was the most beautiful of places to visit & filled me with serenity & calmness that I could have stayed all day!It was only $6 to enter & has the most Beautifully Stunning gardens, pools & waterfalls that you can lose all your trouble as you just sit, watch & listen. I recommend for all ages & take your time & enjoy.

Chinese Garden unexpected delight. Walking back to out hotel from a stroll around the city and the loveliest surprise that is the Chinese Garden. As we entered out mood lightened and our feet softened. As we strolled around it was impossible to feel anything. It really is a sight to see. And how what you see effects how you feel. Relaxing was all we could do. A great way to end a busy day walking the city sights.

Wonderful Example of Garden Harmony. In honour of the Chinese New Year, suggested admission was a low cost donation. I would have paid more to see the excellent example of what a garden area can be. Remarkable that this oriental oasis is surrounded by civic property. You'd hardly know it once you're inside. The paths are not too strenuous; much of it is on fairly level ground. There are some natural stone steps if you navigate the whole route, but they should not present a problem for most people.

Wonderful,enchanting garden in the heart of the city. What a great peaceful and tranquil area in the heart of Sydney center ,you wouldn't expect such a place amidst the skyscrapers,its a must visit just for being in such a wonderful and relaxing place ,giant carp ,waterfalls,and chinese sculpture ,you can get some really memorable photos around here do not pass by the chance to visit here if you are in Sydney

Gorgeous Spot in the Middle of Construction. We didn't go in, but walked around the outside and looked in. It was gorgeous and would have liked to see more of it, but at then end of the trip our funds were low so just enjoyed the parts we could see from the outside edges. I would go in next time.

Chinese Garden, Darling Harbour- so tranquil.. We visited on a perfect summers day, and whilst it was hot, the temperature was very comfortable and the atmosphere so tranquil. One can learn so much from a visit and there is the opportunity to dress in traditional Chinese clothing and be photographed. The water falls and lake add a certain serenity to the atmosphere as do the Coy Carp swimming within it.A lovely place to call in and catch your breath at any time.

Very Tranquil. A very peaceful and tranquil setting,the gardens are just gorgeous and you can get some lovely photos here with the waterfalls and ponds,quite fascinating to see lizards wandering around everywhere especially one in particular in the outdoor dining area,very friendly wee guy though.This wee bit of paradise is a must see!

Great but spoilt by the noise of building work outside. A lovely place to visit if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of city life. When I visited it was towards the end of Chinese New Year and instead of the usual $11 entrance fee you could gain admission by making a small donation ($1 upwards) which was a very pleasant surprise as we were visiting with some relatives and children. Usually a very calming place but unfortunately there is extensive building work going on outside which spoilt the normally calm and tranquil atmosphere. Still worth a visit though and one of our party who is Chinese felt is was a realistic representation of a garden back home in CVhina.
lovelu quiet garden. tranquil garden but completely overlooked by sky scrapers, which spoil the back drop. Lovely place to visit if in Darling Harbour

Beautiful setting... I would say this is a must do! The gardens are very well kept and offer plenty of photo opportunities. It is easy to relax and have an easy stroll round or have a nice tea in the cafe. You can also dress up in Chinese costumes and get great fun photos!

Good fun awesome value. We spent more than one hour here and at free entry for kids and only $6 for adults $3 for concession it's a beautiful good value attraction. The kids had fun seeing the koi fish and the fish feeding at 11:30 is nice to watch. The waterfalls and beautiful scenery means endless photo opportunities are available. You can also dress in traditional clothing and take photos. It's a nice chilled place to just walk and enjoy nature it's like a piece of paradise between the hustle around it

Tranquil garden hidden in CBD Sydney. this amazing garden surrounded by high rise buildings is an oasis of calm in the city centre. Beautifly laid out gardens with many unexpected featurees combined to produce an opportunity to switch off and enjoy a visual delight. Plenty of places to sit and peacefully enjoy the views. Great cafe/tea room incuding outside seating. Spent a whole afternoon here and thoroughly recommend.

So serene!. I visited the Chinese Garden of Friendship in Darling Harbour when I was in Sydney recently. It is a beautiful, peaceful and serene place in the heart of one of the busiest cities in the world. Perfect for a walk or even just to sit and meditate.

Beautiful green spot in the middle of the city. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is a beautiful spot to spend an hour or two. I enjoyed it's beauty and my six year old enjoyed the fun hunt for animals representing the Chinese zodiac. Certainly worth the price of entry.Water falls, very big ponds with very big carp too. I would suggest you visit on a weekday if possible. We were there on Sunday and the noise from a concert at Darling Harbour did change the experience I think. That said it was not hard to imagine how peaceful restful this place could be at the right time of day. We will definitely visit again.

Serene gem oasis in heart of city. The chinese garden is serene oasis in heart of city ,tip go early and hire a costume and took photos around the garden, no one would guess you in Sydney ,gardens are beautifully maintained ,its not a too large place too

City sanctuary. This is a great place to experience authentic Chinese gardens in a fairly surreal setting. There was so much to see and lots of separate gardens to both loom at and enjoy. There is the invitation to bring your own food and drink also which can make for a really great afternoon. The large Carp fish were also fascinating to watch. Great attraction.

Something to do if you must. We went just for something to do, got some photos but nothing stands out. I expected it to be nicer but it is located right in the business area of town and every photo has the buildings in the back drop so kinda takes away from it.

Peacefull. This place is in the middle of the city and you would think you are in the country. We enjoyed our day there walking around the grounds and taking in the wonderful gardens, We ended the day with Devonshire Tea YUM.

Beautiful oasis in heart of city. So peaceful, beautiful oasis on heart of city. Fish (koi) pond is full of fish. Go during feeding time. Lots of greenery & lovely bamboo throughout the garden. The only downside is high rise buildings are popping up nearby and they seem to be building too near the lovely garden. As a result, photo backdrop will show modern high rise buildings. Price of development.

Serene and tranquil place. This garden was built to mark the bicentennial celebration of Australia in 1988. This was built to promote the frienship between the twin cities of Guangzho in Guangdou province in China and Sydney in New Southwales in Australia.The garden is very near the Darling harbour and opposite the Convention center being constructed now. The garden is constructed within a wall and is based on the architectural principle of Tao's ying-yang and the five elements.The garden has beautiful lakes, greenery, exotic plants , lovely waterfalls and pavilion. It also has a nice Teahouse where one can have green tea and Dim sum. Very beautifully designed and it provides for nice cool and shade inside.The wheelchair access is only for the lower level. Toilets are neat and clean. The garden is open daily from 9.30am to 5pm and entrance charge is AUD 6 for Adults and AUD 3 for children below 12 years.

An oasis. Well worth a visit...beautiful gardens in the middle of a city! You can sit in several places and look at the wonderful gardens, have a drink in the cafe at the side of the lake and watch the fish, lizards and birds.
Surprisingly nice, amazingly designed. very historic and well labeled. We ended up spending a couple hours touring the gardens and it was very peaceful!

Peaceful Break from City Life. The Garden of Friendship is a beautiful spot of green in the middle of the city. Worth going to visit during the week when you'll have time to wander and relax. When we were there, we stumbled upon a wedding. Very lovely.

The land of the temporary fencing. Have visited these gardens many times, a bit of calm in a madhouse. When we were there the serenity was challenged by all the building/digging up work that is going on around Cockle Bay. Get in touch with your inner Yen or Yan and enjoy this beautiful area.
Stop if you have time. As we had a whole day, we stopped here to check it out. Kids were fascinated by the resident ducks and ducklings.

Serenity among the jackhammers. This beautiful garden between Sydney CBD and Darling Harbour where workmen are noisily reshaping the environment provides an oasis of tranquillity and peace. The waterfalls, pools stocked with enormous goldfish and abundant and varied plants, juxtaposed between rocks, beautifully set off the Chinese-style pavilions and provide a delightful setting for a quiet stroll, even though the work is proceeding outside. Well worth an hour of your time if you like gardens, water and serenity.

Reminds of old HK. . The Year of the Monkey was still in its infancy, and we arrived on what was called a promotional gold coin day. Admission charges were waived and you only needed to voluntarily deposit a 'gold' coin (1 or2$) in a box at the door. Plenty of activity, and typical Chinese garden of rocks, hills and lakes with artfully arranged trees plants and waterfalls. Reminded me of old Hong Kong gardens and we spent a pleasant couple of hours there taking tea and watching the birds.

Excellent and peaceful gardens near Chinatown and darling harbour. Excellent and peaceful gardens near Chinatown and Darling harbour, take a couple of hours to stroll around and have a cup of chinese tea at the end. Lovely setting and so peaceful.

Tranquil and elegant. This garden is fabulous - I was so surprised by how much content was packed in to what is a relatively small site. Having expected to pop in for half an hour I found myself completely enthralled and left three hours later. There are numerous paths and structures to discover and masses of wildlife - I saw numerous water dragons, two turtles, dragon flies, cormorants and koi carp.The free 30 minute tour is very informative and delivered by enthusiastic and knowledgeable guides - it's a great introduction to the garden and a good way to begin your visit.My only disappointment was that the cafe closes earlier than the gardens. Having enjoyed the gardens I wanted to complete the experience with some Chinese tea and a snack overlooking the gardens, but was told that only ready prepared and canned drinks were available as everything else was closed. But it's a small moan, after what was, on the whole, a great visit.

Beautiful & Worth It!. Sydney is a big city but this attraction is a breath of fresh - or zen - air. It's beautiful, stunning and worth taking time to visit. It will not take you more than an hour to get through it and take photos so be sure to fit it in your day.
Fab!!. You would never think you were in the middle of Sydney, what a beautiful place very peaceful and the wee walk round was just so beautiful, well worth the visit just lovely! Loads to see.

not to be missed; a delightful surprise. These gardens are constantly being added to and they are magnificent for the fauna, flora, and architecture. One of the highlights of Sydney, clearly not know by the tourists.

Tai Chi at the Chinese Garden of Friendship. I have been meaning to go to the Chinese Garden of Friendship and finally managed to go yesterday. As it was part of the Chinese New Year celebrations, entry was by gold coin donation and there was a wealth of activities to try out.I ended up doing the free Tai Chi class which was set in a room opposite the lake and was a beautiful setting to try Tai Chi. There were about 16 of us, and our teacher Fiona was a brilliant teacher.It lasted for one hour and I felt very relaxed afterwards and now eager to try this again. It would be lovely if this could occur every week and charge a small fee as I would love to come back and do it again.Before Tai Chi I had time to wander around the gardens. There was building work going on which meant it wasn't as peaceful as it could have been, but there are spots you can escape to where it is more quiet. It wasn't too busy whilst we were here and there are plenty of spots to sit down and forget about everything.The lake is also home to many Koi fish which were large in size and colourful to watch. There are bonsai trees and plenty of signs to read to gain a better understanding. You can also do a guided tour if you prefer which runs every day.Overall, a lovely hour or so enjoying the Chinese Garden of Friendship and a wonderful Tai Chi class.

Nice relaxing place in the middle of the city. During the Chinese New Year time, they don't even charge (just gold coin donation). It's a well-maintained garden park just in the heart of Sydney. I've been here many times just to relax, sometimes to take scenic photos. This is really a photogenic place, too.

Tranquility in the middle of the CBD. Really good value for money, enjoyed just wandering around and learning about the Chinese culture. Definitely somewhere you could escape to and just enjoy the sound of the trickling water.

Such a relaxing and serene place in the middle of the big city. Highlight of Sydney's wonderful Chinatown. The gardens and waterfalls are fabulous and you can even dress up in traditional Chinese clothing.
lovely place to escape the noise of the city. This is a wonderful place to escape the noise of the city! We were exploring the city and stumbled upon this place and we enjoyed ourselves here!

Tranquil and lovely. These gardens are beautifully maintained and remain a gift to Sydney. They are very tranquil and really pretty. Hard to believe when you're inside that outside the doors is Darling Harbour and bustling city. Worth doing.
Tranquil. Lovely stroll around gardens amazing to find this in the middle of a busy city so much to see and learn well wort it

Hidden beauty. I have walked past the Chinese Gardens a number of times and decided to take my fiance there for a small picnic. It didn't disappoint! Whilst we were there we were allowed to feed the hundreds of Koi fish and birds in the gardens. There was also the option of a guided tour and a costume shop to dress in kimonos.
So tranquil!. If you are looking for peace and tranquility visit the Chinese Gardens. Perfect place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city for a little while.

Calm at the eye of the storm. The Chinese Gardens provide a welcome escape from the CBD on the one side and the mammoth building projects on the other. Classic Chinese garden layout with ponds, bridges, pavillions and rock features. Also has a small cafe.

Urban oasis . What a beautiful and tranquil place.
Interesting views and walkways, something different to see around every corner.
Would love to return and just sit, meditate, reflect .... peace

Tranquility in a busy city.. Overwhelming noise of traffic and building renovations, clanks, bangs and sirens completely forgotten in this haven of peace and tranquillity. A most beautiful garden reminding us of our visit to China years ago. It has everything
chinese gardens. being interested in horticulture this was good, just a pity that they are taking some of the area away and making it a bit difficult to get to

Very tranquil. We spent a couple of hours here last week at the end of the holiday to Sydney & we're so impressed by how beautiful the gardens are.
We were right by the fish feeding station at feeding time, great to watch the beautiful koi carp being fed.
Thorough tranquil place in the heart of the city, loved it.
nice small compact. well done garden located in darling harbor area, nice details, steps, pagodas, waterfalls and ponds, nice bonsai also, very doable in 30 minutes
Accidentally stumbled upon this park. Accidentally stumbled upon this park and I am so glad I did! It is so so beautiful and such a relaxing place.

I walked through here today and it was brilliant!. Because it is the Chinese New Year of the monkey, this place was rocking today. There were stalls set up, people playing traditional Chinese instruments and although it was hot and humid, there were many peaceful and relaxing places here to rest and to contemplate. I loved it and highly recommend a visit to it during a time of Chinese celebration.

Beautiful and tranquil garden in the middle of a cement jungle.. A very tranquil place amidst the chaos of a giant city especially during the busy period of Chinese New Year. We're entering the year of the monkey which is my animal on the Chinese calendar. There is a lot to see here and I say no rush because it's hot outside and in here cool and calm. Make sure you check that you're still breathing. Enjoy!

Beautiful and relaxing. It's not an exceptional garden of its type, but that doesn't mean it's not still a calming respite from the noise and crush of the city. Some niceties include being able to rent some costumery on site for pictures and a charming and quiet tea house with beverages, pastries and bon mi.

Lovely little unexpected delight. A peaceful spot set back from Darling Harbour in the park area. Though having said peaceful right now they seem to be rebuilding Sydney around it. But that doesn't actually matter as once inside life slows down; there is the calm of water, the stillness of birds, glimmer of fish, the shades of greens and the many differing sizes and shapes of foliage. You can, should you wish, dress up in rather grand bright Chinese garb and take photos. Doesn't cost much and probably very good for your state of mind.
Just Amazing!. In the middle of a huge city, this is a beautiful sanctuary. Very well laid out, easy to walk around and the scenery and plants and buildings are beautiful.

Charming. The Chinese Garden is situated within walking distance from Darling Harbour. With a small amount of entrance fee, you can enjoy many types of plants, trees, fish, and waterfall. Don't miss the Koi fish feeding time every 11:30 AM. The garden is very peaceful and relaxing. There are many construction going on around the area, but it is still worth a visit!

A visual delight !. I absolutely loved the Chinese Garden Of Friendship. It only cost $6 to enter and was well worth it. We had a lovely lunch here, also.The gardens are superbly maintained and are an absolute must see and a visual delight. I was very impressed.

Tranquil. I love visiting the gardens there's just something about it that puts me at peace and feel relaxed whether taking a relaxing stroll with my hubby or a excited walk with the kids while they enjoy looking for lizards, turtles, coi and bugs.. They too enjoy the gardens taking it all in. Find a nice place to sit and enjoy take it all in and reflect x

It not going to be relaxing for a few months. There's a lot of construction going on in Darling Harbor so it's not going to be very relaxing for a few months or so. The garden is okay though, not as well kept as I might wished, some trash laying around and whatnot.
A lovely place. Such a beautiful place to see. Unfortunately not as serene as we expected due to building demolition taking place nearby. But well worth another visit though in the future.

Beautiful oasis in the city. Beautiful oasis in the city. Very pretty and relaxing. The Chinese Gardens have developed beautifully over the past decades and are worth a visit. You could visit here before or after a visit to Darling Harbour.
Relax . Beautiful garden secret in the city cafe was nice had selection of Chinese food would recommend if in Sydney this is a must see allow 2 hours with lunch

Unbelievable in the middle of the town. It's like an oasis, a beautiful garden in the concrete jungle. I could spend all day there. It has a big water fall, ponds with fish,plants and trees from China, beautiful small buildings Chinese style,a winding pathway around the garden. Beautiful.

So Relaxing. Visited this wonderful garden and could not believe this beautiful oasis in the city of Sydney. The staff were extremely helpful especially as I had a group of elderly people with me who had some mobility issues. The gardens were very well kept and the tea house was a treasure. Wished I had known about the section where you pay extra and they dress you in Chinese garments so that you have the wonderful backdrop of the gardens. Will definitely like to do this again when the cherry blossoms are in full bloom.

Visit to Chinese Gardens. The Chinese Gardens was such a peaceful place to be considering it was Australia Day. The gardens were well laid out and there was some lovely spots to sit and reflect on life. There was plenty of shady spots along the way. The penultimate was having some lunch at the cafe located within the gardens.

Celebrating Chinese New Year with toddlers. 12 toddlers in tow a visit to this kid friendly spot was lots of fun for everyone. Spying the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac hidden around the garden was the second best thing after the feeding frenzy of the GIANT carp.
BEAUTIFUL. A gorgeous sanctuary in the middle of the city. Could spend the whole day here just wandering around the gardens. Great place for photographs and relaxing

For 6,00 Australian dollars, Yes. It's a very small garden, you can easily see everything, not rush through in 30/45 minutes, well manicured as a Chinese gardens should be, nice pond thought the entire gardens, Bonsais distributed in many corners. We were pleased

Lunar new year at the gardens. Beautiful experience, such a lovely garden, it was busier than usual because of the timing, but still peaceful and unique to the centre of a Capitol city. It really is a must visit and entry is a gold coin donation.

Decent for a first time visitor to a Chinese garden. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is located in Chinatown near Darling Harbour in the heart of Sydney. The garden is beautifully landscaped with features such as pagodas, water streams, and rocks. However, the garden is rather small as compared to similar gardens located elsewhere. Also, its entrance charge of AUD 6 is a bit on the higher side. If you have already been to a Chinese garden elsewhere, you can give this place a miss.

Beautiful Gardens. The Chinese gardens were an absolutely beautiful way to spend an hour or two in Sydney and it is in a very convenient spot in Sydney's Darling Harbor. There was even a cute little spot were you could get dressed up in traditional clothing and take pictures throughout the gardens, the kids were so cute all dressed up and loving it!

unexpected paradise in middle of Sydney CBD. what a beautiful surprise this was. We wandered around admiring the beautifully manicured garden and ponds, admiring the gorgeous flowers and themed gardens, relaxing more and more as we roamed. We saw children dressed in period costumes (extra charge) and wished we had more time to linger. Will be revisiting and taking the guided tour next time to learn more of the history behind the garden.

Pretty. Visited the garden in July school holidays last year. The gardens are quite pretty and it would be quite peaceful except for the construction works going on around Darling Harbour. The noise was deafening at the time we visited and the traffic noise is quite loud as well. It's a bit of a pity it is surrounded by city in a way.
Amazing!!!. Its an amazing oasis in the middle of the city. The gardens are beautifully manicured. It is so peaceful. Awesome for pictures as well!!!

Do not miss this.. If you go to Sydney or more particularly Darling harbour you must to these gardens. Situated a short walk back from the harbour.It is a beautifully laid out garden in the Chinese style. Lots of pools with carp in them, little streams, rills and waterfalls. The paths meander in-between them and everywhere there are beautiful trees and shrubs with rocks and stones dotted around, there are places to sit. Despited being in the city it is a very quiet place to go and very relaxing.There is a cafe where you can get things to eat or simply have a cup of tea.If I was a Sydneysider it is a place I would go every day if I could.As I said, do not miss it.
Chinese garden. Don't get me wrong it is a very nice garden but way to expensive. you can get dressed up into traditional Chinese clothes but have to pay extra. Extra cost.

Escape to a Chinese Garden in downtown Sydney. What a delightful spot for a leisurely wander. Located on the western side of the city, near the bustle but isolated from the noise. Beautifully landscaped grounds, plants from tall bamboo and Black Pines to tiny flowers, good self-guided tour complemented with small plaques throughout the garden to describe a particular location or planting. Well-fed koi in the Lake of Brightness, some shy tortoise and wonderful Water Dragons that position themselves on rocks just waiting to have their pictures taken. Stop for a coffee or lunch in the Teahouse overlooking the Lotus Pond and Dragon Wall. Designed and built by Chinese landscape architects reflecting co-operation between sister cities Sydney and Guangzhou in Guangdong Province, China.
Must visit gem. Lovely oasis of tranquility in busy harbour area, albeit lot of construction work going on round about.

Beautiful experience. This is a great activity and so cheap $6 for adults!You can spend as much or as little as you like here, we had a free guided tour which went for about 30 minutes, and we stayed for some extra time. I would recommend a guided tour as everything in the garden has a meaning, so you won't know what you're looking at if you do it alone. You can also enjoy tea and light meals in the tea room.Thank you to our guide Sue who was fantastic; knowledgeable and so friendly!

A Bit of Asia. This is one of the stops on the Hop on Hop OFF bus that you can get at Circular Quay or Darling Harbor.It is a beautiful Chinese Garden that serves tea.Not a place I would go to unless you are spending several days in Sydney and have seen all the other more important things.

Beautiful. This garden really is a hidden gem is the middle of the city. When i went there was building works going on outside so it was harder to find the entrance.Cost 6 dollars to get it but really worth it. Follow the path round beautiful Chinese themes gardens. Such a peaceful place, beautiful surroundings and calm zen.I sat for a while by the main pond but there is a cafe to sit and chill in too.Make sure you explore it all and take your camera for some beautiful shots.Possibly my favourite place i Sydney

Nice. We happened to be in Sydney during Chinese New Year, so we thought this would be great to see as the timing was perfect. It was nice to see the different pieces and small artwork that brought history.The garden was peaceful and relaxing to walk through. There is a small waterfall that was cute for pictures for just to sit by and enjoy the sounds.

Restful Haven in Sydney. This Garden was a peaceful respite after strolling around busy Sydney on Australia Day. The layout encourages leisurely exploration and contemplation with beautiful trees, shrubs, flowers, pagodas and a waterfall. Even saw some almost tame Australian Ibis, which are perhaps a nuisance in the grand scheme of things, but add to the enjoyment. There are few better ways to spend a couple of pleasant hours.

Very tranquil . If you're looking for tranquility in crazy Sydney city look no further. Based on Chinese theme these gardens are amazingly peaceful beautiful and is great for families and groups of friends too. They also have tea rooms which are great to soak in the surroundings.

Peaceful part of town. A very beautiful, relaxing place. We were in Darling Harbour and were walking around when we decided to take a break in the gardens. There is an $8 entry fee which is a small amount to pay for the tranquility in the middle of the city.The gardens are well maintained, the lake is lovely - it really is worth a visit.

An oasis amid the city skyscrapers. Well worth a visit. Entry cost us just $8 each and there was plenty to see with koi in the lake and some wonderful planting. There's also a very good tea room offering a wide choice of teas.

Calm in a hectic town. These gardens are between Chinatown and Darling Harbour. It has a small entry fee but it allows you to return any time during the day. It is a calm garden with carp, birds, waterfalls and statues right in the centre of Sydney. It adds a nice dimension to a vibrant, hectic city. Recommended.

Tranquility. A tranquil gem in the heart of a bustling City. Worth spending an hour in these beautiful gardens. Lovely red pergolas and ponds filled with Koi. An array of bird life as well. I packed some sandwiches and spent some time sitting quietly taking in the beauty around me. Within walking distance of most hotels.

A tranquil oasis in a busy city.. A lovely peaceful setting, fabulous vistas, lovely plants, places to sit and relax, birds, lizards, fish all waiting to be discovered. Lots of things for children to find so all in all a lovely family attraction.
Beautiful. This is the perfect peaceful place to find a little relaxation from the city after a days sightseeing.
Hidden Gem. Peaceful and calming afternoon walking though the garden right on the edge of the bustling Darling Harbour precinct is this gem.
So Peaceful. It was extraordinary having this garden in the middle of Sydney. Very serene, well kept and interesting to boot. Definitely a place to go when visiting the city.

Great little gardens. Right near darling harbour and China town is this lovely little piece of paradise. Quite and relaxing. Great place to wind down. Well maintained gardens. Great ponds with huge fish. Wildlife all around. Little tea house has great food.

A hidden jewel - make sure you visit. This was one of our Sydney highlights and we almost didn't visit. It really is worth taking a few hours to spend time in the Chinese Gardens, even better make sure you are there for one of the walks guided by the Garden staff. The staff really bring the garden to life and highlight things that you would otherwise miss. Such a tranquil and beautiful location, don't miss it. The only slight downside is that some of the views are now slightly marred by all of the construction currently taking place in the area outside the garden but it doesn't distract from the beauty of the Gardens overall.

Lovely Garden. Stroll through Chinese Garden of Friendship in Darling Harbour and discover the hidden plants and pond that lie within. This place have been used for the movie The Wolverine. Many beautiful spots you can use as a background of your photos and your memory.

Lovely surroundings . Such a lovely and peaceful place in the middle of the city. Was so nice to walk around the gardens with little paths everywhere. Lots of Chinese style architecture and koi carp too! Some days there may be activities going on too! Makes a nice change to take a break from the city bustle

Hidden paradise . Definitely a hidden paradise and well worth taking the time to visit this place. Entry is very cheap and worth every cent...i could have stayed here all day i will be back on my next visit.
Something you wouldn't expect in the heart of the city. This is a place we were quite surprised to discover in the centre of the city. A very tranquil and relaxing place to get away from it all.

Chinese garden in the middle of the city. We spent a nice hour in the garden, I liked the lakes, the waterfall and the architecture. We also had an encounter with a giant lizard. We came in late and the tea room was already closed. We saw a couple of people trying on popular chinese clothes, which you can do at an extra price.

Beautiful gardens - even has fun activity to keep younger ones interested. The garden is an easy stroll from the water at Darling Harbour, along a lovely part with green spaces, playgrounds for kids and great outdoor cafes. The garden is lush with lots of interesting features and easy to absorb information. Hidden throughout the garden are figures from the chinese zodiac to discover - a lovely way to spend an hour or so.

Lovely garden. We spent a lovely morning here the setting was lovely lots to see loads of fish in the water nice waterfalls and ponds the Chinese buildings and paintings were good and the cafe served lovely teas and food which were very reasonably priced

A Tranquil Retreat in a busy city. We really enjoyed our walk around this lovely garden. If you have time to sit and rest I am sure you will find this visit well worthwhile. It is a beautiful and tranquil place in the midst of a very busy city. We also enjoyed a cup of tea in the tea house which finished the visit perfectly.

Nature at it's best, escape the city. I love this place, the best place to escape the city, it is nature at it's best.
There is a cost but it isn't that much.
Dress up as a Emporia or Queen, and take your own photo's in the garden.

Amazing Tranquility in the city. We loved, loved, loved the Chinese Garden of Friendship. The price is reasonable for such a relaxing and beautiful oasis. They have various walking tours so plan ahead. I think ours was at 10:30 am and our guide, David, was excellent. You can easily cover the grounds in about a half hour or you can stay longer and listen to the sounds of birds and the waterfall. We spent a month in China and did not encounter many gardens this beautiful/unique.

Escape the hustle and bustle of the city!. A peaceful spot in a busy city, enjoy a walk around the beautiful gardens. There are plenty of informative plaques, a Chinese zodiac trail, children's dress up area and koi fish feeding shows sure to keep you busy! You can also enjoy a nice pot of tea in the cafe area.

A must-see in Sydney. This was one of the highlights of my first trip to Sydney.A magical place filled with beautiful scenes - kids will love spotting water dragons and koi. Lots of open water spaces with no fences though so keep an eye on kids.$6 entry was a good price for an adult - we spent a good couple of hours in the gardens.NOTE: I recommend not eating at the café. We ordered scones and were severely disappointed with the microwaved, totally not-fresh lumps we received. Jam was jelly, impossible to spread and the cream not pleasant.

A Magical Place. An oasis in a region of the City undergoing major construction work made it, for us anyway, even more impressive.The noises of the city seemed to fade almost as soon as we walked through the gates. The gardens themselves, although not huge, were easily large enough to get lost in your thoughts. Go early enough in the day and you can find a spot to meditate with a cup of green tea cooling by your side.We had some beautiful sunny, and very hot, days whilst we were visiting the city and there are also generous number of spots to sit in the shade.Purely and simply, a magical place.

Big garden with lots to view. Big garden with lots of Chinese 'star sign' to look at. Great pamphlet for kids to keep them interested. There's also a costume for hire facility where you could hire and wear the costume while exploring the garden. We didn't do that as weather was just too hot. But I agree that it's a great idea!

Beautiful place and very relaxing. Just came upon this place by accident.. I t was a very warm day and this was a delightful little place to stop and have a drink and a look around the tranquil gardens.

Simply stunning!. These gardens are stunning and a must see whilst at the harbour!Entry is very inexpensive & there is so much to see. The paths are easily negotiated by all abilities & you can take short or longer treks. We stopped in for tea & Chinese pastries, which were delicious!We will be back!

Chinese Gardens Sydney.. Enjoyed our first morning in Sydney, visiting this very tranquil place. Designed in China to celebrate the Australian Bicentenary, the gardens at Darling Harbour is a place of peace and tranquility in the heart of Sydney. Winding pathways, waterfalls, lakes and pavilions. A traditional Teahouse overlooks the water.

Chinese Garden of Frienship disappointing. Garden was hard to find due to poor signage and construction near it blocking some of the access. It is fairly small but nicely done. Not as elaborate as other Chinese gardens seen in China itself (likely due to small size). One thing that was interesting is that they rent out Chinese traditional costumes and let visitors wander the garden taking their own photo's while dressed up as a very reasonable charge. Did not do this but saw many people that did.

Surprising!. I loved the tranquility here. An oasis of calm in the middle of Darling Harbour and Sydney city. Once you are inside, you really forget where you are. The garden is well set out and easy to walk around although some spots were a little slippy because of the recent rain. There is a small charge to go in but I thought that the visit was worth the cost.

Ming Dynasty Garden in Sydney. Sydney's Chinese Garden of Friendship is next to Sydney's Darling Harbour. It was designed by Sydney's sister city, Guangzhou, and opened in 1988 as a bond of friendship between the two cities.Since then the gardens have grown and matured. It is full of bamboo groves, bonsai, and many water features. You cannot see the whole garden from any vantage point, which means that features of it leap upon you as you walk around and explore, adding surprise to surprise.The Tea House in the gardens offers traditional Chinese tea and refreshments where you can relax and enjoy the gardens around you.
Peaceful and beautiful. Definitely worth a visit! It's a big and peaceful Chinese garden in the middle of the city. Felt incredibly relaxed sitting there just soaking in the atmosphere.

Beautiful place among rush city. We had small difficulty to find the entrance because there are civil works around the garden. In the garden itself there is peace and calm atmosphere like and you can just sit and relax. Really beautiful.

Amazing. From the minute you walk into the place you are met by stunning landscaped views of the Koi Carp and lily pad pond, a quaint little care area and dozens of photograph opportunities from the fish to the ibis , the ducks to the spiders in their webs around the pond and the dozens of small to medium sized lizards running around, a soothing a calming ambience and a prize for any kids completing the easy quiz as you walk around the gardens and waterfalls
Amazing . Amazing. From the second you walk up to the doors everything is stunning. Lots of little pathways to explore and lots of photo opportunities

Oh the serenity. Such a wonderful place to get lost and forget about whats happening on the other side of the wall. From sitting by a waterfall, to wandering through a bamboo forest, to just enjoying the peace of these beautiful gardens.
Sad, lacking lustre. Once an attraction of Darling Harbour, it is now a quiet, sad looking venue. Needs to be spruced up, more life.

Tranquility in the Ciy. What an amazingly beautiful place. We spent several hours in complete peace wandering through these magnificent gardens. Then topped it off with a lovely afternoon tea in the tea gardens.

Time Out. When having a hectic time with battling car parking and miles of walking, take a moment to visit these wonderful restful gardens in the heart of Sydney. The peacefulness restores your mind and body and helps get you going again. Birds plants flowing water and a tea shop. What more could you want. Such a surprise find at the centre of this busy city. We loved it, and the kids did too, so has to be a plus.
Quiet haven. What a surprise - just a few steps from the bustling and hectic Darling Harbour, an oasis of calm. Beautifully designed and maintained.

Memorable experience. Our visit to the Chinese Garden of Friendship was one of the most memorable during our time in Sydney. It was such a surprise to find this peaceful haven in buzzing Sydney - instantly relaxing. By clever landscaping so much has been packed into a relatively small space - including a pagoda on a hill and a waterfall. Highly recommended when you feel like getting away from it all in the city.
December drizzle no problem. Romantic place to stroll and be taken to another world. Fantastic. Great photos! nice refreshing cider and beer topped off a beautiful afternoon.

Peace Amongst the Hustle and Bustle. This garden is absolutely beautiful. Literally a hidden gem as it is tucked away near Darling Harbour with freeways surrounding it and yet you step into another world when you enter this peaceful oasis away from the busyness of the city. The work that has gone into this garden is amazing. The construction alone would have been amazing. After 30 or so years it is now well established and absolutely stunning. A must see when visiting Sydney. The greenery and the water features have attracted many water fowl as well. Just beautiful.
Peaceful. was surprised you had to pay but it is pleasant and peaceful. Not many people visited it while we were in the area taking photos.
Quiet relaxing garden in the busy harbour area.. Beautiful, quiet, relaxing garden, with pagodas, waterfall, carp in ponds. Bondsai tree courtyard. Excellent tea room.

My Favorite Place In Sydney. Anybody who asks me what they should do while in Sydney i always tell them to visit here. It doesn't cost much to visit & its so peaceful & quiet. Its like it is a world of its own.Visually stunning & its hard not to take a million photos.Every time i go to Sydney i make sure i stop by.
Beautiful. I loved it. So beautiful and tematic. Coast around $6 and you can rent a costume to take pics or just sit and relax

Better than the Bridge & Opera House. When visiting Sydney the one place you must visit is The Chinese Gardens in Darling Harbour. I wont go into any great detail as it will take away some of the pleasant surprise that you will experience. It is a little bit of peaceful joy in a very busy city. Its great!!!!!

Enjoyable.. Supposed to be a place of calm & tranquility unfortunately during the height of the summer holidays it is far from it! We did however enjoy it & there is a pavilion in the grounds where you can hire Chinese costume, which adds to the ambiance of the Garden. The biggest shame is that when you look up the whole garden is surrounded by towering buildings.
Peaceful. This is an oasis in a very busy part of Sydney. You walk into the Chinese Gardens, and you walk away from the cares of the world. There is arguably no better place in Sydney to meditate.
a nice surprise in Sydney. We hadnt planned for this but we discovered it from our hotel room window. Its a small beautiful garden, worth a visit if you love to be in the midst of nature.

It's nice but could be better. The attraction is nice, amazing rocks and beautiful landscape. You have to walk like 10-15min but one time you are in, it's small. People can walk it in 20minutes or less. There is a entry fee of 6aud which I think it's too much for it. If yo are not fan of garden I suggest jump it, otherwise it's nice.

A welcome surprise. While walking around in the Sydney rain, one November afternoon, I stumbled across the Garden - it was a very welcome respite from the weather and the terrible morning I had just had. The gardens were serene and well maintained, the staff were exceptional!

Lovely memories. Amazing peaceful Oasis in a big city. We went in November and discovered children could go in free for this month only. We walked around and discovered that there was a kiosk where you could change into Chinese emperors clothes for a fee. This added to the fun as fully dressed we were able to walk around and view the garden from a different perspective. The wild life within the garden also added to the tranquility. One of the must do activities when visiting Sydney.

Stunning and well worth the time!. We took part is a free tour given by a garden volunteer, Sue. She was SO knowledgeable and fun to be with. We learned WAY more about the garden, the traditions reflected in the displays, and the history than we could EVER have understood just walking around on our own. It was truly one of my favorite things we did, but I'm nuts about flowers and gardens. I highly recommend!
Great garden. Easy to find, this beautiful chinese garden is like a little oasis of peace and silence in this huge, crowded city.
Tranquil space. Lovely tranquil space hidden in the bustling darling harbour district. Beautiful gardens with many hidden corners and wandering paths.
Small but nice. If you never been to China you can give this a go, to have a roughly idea what traditional Chinese garden looks like
Beautiful and peaceful. Lovely place to visit. Very peaceful to just have a wander, sit and read a book or just relax and chat. Very beautiful as well! Worth a visit :)
Fabulous Gardens. What a find. Fabulous gardens, waterfalls, ponds, wildlife, lovely place to sit and relax, take photos. Well worth visiting if you around Darling Harbour.

Very peaceful, well maintained garden. A lot of places to sit down & rest the feet in this garden, which was just what we needed after walking so far on a very hot day. Didn't cost much to get in but it was just the 2 of us, A lot of Chinese structures which makes it a lovely garden to see.

Gorgeous. Master Four was a little bored but Miss Eight loved the children's map.
A beautiful place in the middle of the city.
The chaps at the front counter were great too.

A peaceful place. We went on this boat trip to Darling harbour in Sydney and walked along board walk when we came to this Chinese garden. It was so peaceful the gardens were very well laid out and water fall and ponds with Koi carp were excellent we could not believe it was so peaceful and tranquil in the middle of a built up city, well worth a visit. Red

Peace & Quiet in the midst of Hustle & Bustle.. Have visited many times since it opened - it used to be free, but well worth the small cost. Every visit provides a new experience as the place develops. Relaxation comes automatically, it's that type of place. If you feel it's time to escape the frantic pace of Darling Harbour, take time out and visit the gardens. We prefer the week days, less people.

Absolute peace and beauty amongst the city. I loved the Chinese Garden of Friendship. You can dress in traditional costume and walk through the grounds or have a peaceful tea and dim sum at the little restaurant/cafe. It had beautiful trees and plants as well as lovely birds and bearded dragons! I reccomend this as a lovely thing to do if you like gardens or simply want a nice spot to enjoy a peacful afternoon tea. It is beautiful and I can't wait to visit it again.

A Gorgeous Place of Serenity. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is very calming and a refreshing place to be for not only the locals but also for the travellers. The fact that the city is right next to it is quite amazing since there is such a change in scenery. Although you have to pay to enter, you can't really experience this scenery elsewhere in Sydney so in my opinion I think that it was worth it!

Relaxing afternoon in the gardens. A living picture of mountains, streams, valleys and lakes. Beautifully constructed with ample place to take advantage of the pleasant breeze filtering through the trees. Hard to believe that one is virtually in the middle of one of the busiest cities in the world. A wonderful opportunity to take advantage of the costumes for hire and to make some lasting memories with a difference.
Brief walk. Walked half the garden. Quite pretty plants and birds. Different fr the usual native Aussie plants. Worth a visit if u are in Chinatown.

Peace and tranquility. What a beautiful haven of peace and serenity in the middle of a busy area Only a few dollars to enter and no time limit on how long you can stay but it is absolutely amazing how well it is laid out

Well Conceived Layout, but not well-maintained. I enjoyed visiting this garden with my husband, and appreciated the thoughtful design. We found the garden to be undergoing seasonal clean-up, though, so not all paths were clear. We were also disappointed by the amount of trash around the grounds, despite a hefty entrance fee.

Asian place of peace. Very calm and soothing place amidst skyscrapers and cheerful vibrancy of Sydney. One must seat here for a while and observe trees, people ans swimming fishes. Looks like a piece of spiritual China is being cut from there and planted here.

Lovely retreat in a bustling city. The chinese gardens are on the edge of chinatown, & surrounded by several high rise buildings under construction. Once inside the gardens are idylic peaceful & the perfect place to allow for some contemplation, in the middle of the bustling city. I really hope they manage to keep the gardens going with the modernisation that surrounds them.It is a must visit place, simply beautiful.
A Hidden Gem. This is a hidden Gem right on the heart of The Sydney Darling harbor. This is a place where you step in time with a beautiful Chinese garden.

Past its prime. The Chinese Gardens are not what they used to be. I first visited in 2005 and the gardens felt like a blissful haven from bustling inner Sydney. We've made several return visits over the years and this year stopped en route to the Powerhouse Museum. The entry price of $15 fora family of four is great value. Inside the gardens are still tranquil and pretty and the "scavenger hunt" project for kids is a great idea. Unfortunately the water seemed very green and murky and the giant carp barely visible in many parts of the park. The cascading waterfall down one side seemed to have gone - lack of water perhaps? And the opportunity to dress up in traditional kimono seems to have disappeared too. The little cafe still exists but was empty on this particular day. It was a bit sad to see such a nostalgic favourite neglected.
Great place visited a number of years ago!. Close to China Town,Darling Harbour and Paddys Markets if you are in the CBD district and want an escape from the city!

So lovely we got married there. The beautiful Chinese Gardens are an oasis within the CBD, to wander through, allow sometime for contemplation or share your vows of eternal love (well get married anyway).
Lovely getaway from city bustle. Just gorgeous with lots of photo opportunities and a really nice place to escape the busy city, a must visit.

Well maintain garden with some very serene settings.. Great Chinese garden right next to Darling Harbour, reasonable entry fee. Can come and go for the day with your one entry fee. Nice place to relax after a nice meal in China town.

Very attractive little oasis. They are quite small but pack a lot of beauty into the space that they take up on the Cockle Bay side of the Darling Harbour area. I got here by walking up along past the restaurants of Cockle Bay (don't go over the Pyrmont Bridge if you are coming from the CBD - the gardens are on the Cockle Bay Wharf Side), heading up toward China Town and Paddy's Markets. The gardens are just before the Pier Street exit out of the Darling Harbour area. Beautifully ornate, they are an oasis amongst the construction being carried out in Darling Harbour at the moment. Entry fee is $6 and in January they have school holiday activities for kids. This is one of the nicest things to see in the Darling Harbour area.

Unexpected highlight. When planning a month long trip down under this place had not even featured on the radar. In fact we stumbled upon it by accident whilst working our way to Darling Harbour. But what a lucky find. For entrance of only $6 you are met with a little treasure of a garden that is as fascinating for its reptiles and fish as it is for its plants and ornate buildings. We took advantage of following the lovely guide Hayley around the garden who told us so much about its history and how traditionally the Chinese found such peace and tranquillity through many of the types of plants and exhibits found in the gardens. This place could easily be overwhelmed by the developments taking place all around it but it is worth taking a step away from the hustle and bustle of Darling Harbour to enjoy the peace of these gardens and of course take a glass of beer from the gardens cafe whilst admiring the Koi and wild birds that keep an interested eye upon them!

Amazing. GO GO GO. This place is priceless. i have been here so many times. but might go during summer. it's like being in another world. it's priceless. castlereagh st is the high end. like prada.. but it doesn't even hold a candle compared to these gardens. here me when i say this. (bodyguard) love farmer0

Relaxing place. You could spend many hours hereto just walk around and relax at many different spots.Be sure to take your camera!.Many areas to view.You can also dress up in authentic costumes for a small fee.Finish of with eats and drink at there cafe.

A refuge from the rushing crowds. This is a perfectly tranquil refuge from the crowds that plague the city streets. If I had some more time I'd probably have packed a sandwich and some tea to enjoy somewhere (if that's allowed?). A very beautiful garden, however, and absolutely a must for anyone who likes Asian gardens, bonsai, etc. Only $3 for concession entry, too.

Restful and peaceful. Have never been to these gardens, found them amazing especially something like this in the middle of Sydney.The garden and features are so photographic for all to see.The Koi fish in the pond are so amazing and Hugh in size.It's a lonely leisure walk through the garden and worth doing it if your in town.

New buildings are getting closet to this peaceful haven.. This was or third visit in 5 years to this wonderful city centre attraction. It is still an attractive place, well laid out in such a small area but the new buildings close to the entrance have spoiled the view in that direction.
Great spot to relax. Nice park in the middle of the district. Be sure to go during the season when flowers bloom as more spectacular at that time

Peaceful. A very beautiful , peaceful garden in the middle of a bustling precinct. Very much worth a visit.has beautiful Chinese buildings and some lovely wooden carvings in one rotunda. You can dress up and have your photo taken in traditional Chinese dress.
Beautiful!. One of the highlights of my trip. The gardens were gorgeous, the tour guide friendly, and the food lovely. Only with it wasn't stuck in a city!
Quiet and beautiful. Two of visited the gardens for 2.5 hours after walking from another local attraction. Giant koi in the water features add a nice touch to the walkways and viewing locations.
Fantastic place for a walk. We loved this place! Walked here from Darling Harbor on our last day in Sydney. Great way to spend an afternoon!

Boring and a rip off. This attraction costs $6 for adults and $3 for concession tickets. This is for what is basically a 10 minute walk around a fake and mainly concrete replica of a Chinese garden. Don't go if you have mobility problems or a stroller - the paths are mainly uneven stone and there a quite a few precipitous stairs with no handrails. You cannot find a spot to sit down and contemplate the quite pretty views, because the multitude of ibis have fouled all the benches and no one has hosed them down. The ponds are dirty and full of leaves. The whole place feels neglected and that may be partly a result of the Darling Harbour redevelopment, but being one of the few attractions that is open, you'd think the management would make an effort. The cafe was mediocre - we felt we were interrupting the staff's down time. The whole place needs an upgrade.
Fantastic garden in the middle of the city!. What a lovely peaceful place to have a wander and relax at the coffee shop. The garden is much bigger than expected and very well set out.

Tranquility in the heart of CBD of Sydney. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is a hidden gem of Sydney. Amongst all the tourist attractions, here is 2.5 acres in the Darling Harbor area where you can walk, sit, and have a refreshment and enjoy the tranquility and beauty of this Chinese Garden which divided up by a water fall, lake, and pond.Highly recommend you take the free guided tours at noon or 2pm which will provide the history and basic elements of the Chinese Garden.This a must see attraction if your're going to visit Sydney

A peaceful haven in a busy city. You can hardly believe that you can sit and take tea in a beautiful setting in the middle of the city. If you have children they can dress in traditional costume . There is also the opportunity to spot wildlife . Despite the adjacent building works you can still enjoy this peaceful oasis.

Wonderful Chinese Garden to relax and walk. The perfect site to finish a long travel!. Chinese Garden of Friendship is a garden given by the Chinese Authorities to the city of Sydney as proof of friendship between the two countries. It is a typical Chinese Garden, where you can relax a lot (hearing the water and the birds, walking around the Garden, seeing the waterfalls, rivers and lakes) and drink or eat several typical chinese gardens. I recommend you taste tees.It was our last visit in Australia (after 1 month travel in the country) and it was relaxed, quite and beautiful. It is an excellent place to begin to prepare the next travel... ;-)(thank you dad for this gift)

Beautiful afternoon tea in the middle of the city. These gardens were a great surprise tucked into the heart of Sydney. For a round $12.00 each we toured the beautiful gardens and had afternoon tea with scones jam and cream. The gardens are stunning with lots to walk around. The city seems to disappear from view.

a little bit of heaven in central Sydney. what a wonderful garden in the centre of Sydney. Yes you have to pay to get in but it is well worth it. Lovely plants, birds and fish. Take a couple hours out to see this - a must.

Wonderful. This was by far one of my favourite places we visited. Once you step inside the gardens you are transported to a place of beauty and tranquility. It was so easy to forget that you were surrounded by a busy city.

Excellent, and beautiful restful place.. As i entered this place , with anticipation, i was greeted by the sounds of birds, a waterfall, also other people who were visiting this place.., For me it was magical, the sounds surrounding me, walking along i noticed the 'Koi carp'. It happened that it was their feeding time and as i observed them coming to the surface, i observed also an 'eel'. I spent a fair time just listening, wandering and really enjoying myself; i then stopped for something to eat in the cafe' area. For me it fulfilled my stay in Sydney as i was travelling home later that day.

Well worth a visit. Visited Tuesday Morning and managed to join a guided tour with Hayley. Excellent guide informative and looked like she loved her job. Gardens are lovely and a nice break from the city.

Return visit. We visited the Chinese Gardens about 3 years ago and really enjoyed the experience, so we were keen to find out if the Darling Harbour development in progress at the moment, had had a detrimental effect on the gardens. On arriving we were pleased to see the gardens open for business as usual, even with the chaos surrounding them. On entering the garden of friendship it was just as we remembered, a beautiful tranquil spot in the middle of a major city, it is not easy to resist gazing at the skyline outside,but is still a wonderful place to relax for an hour or so and soak up the atmosphere of a true Chinese Garden.

Get your Zen on. The garden is an oasis among the madness that is Sydney...a perfect place to chill after a hectic day..you can enjoy some tea at the teahouse or hire traditional Chinese costumes to be photographed in

Authentic Chinese garden experience.. It is a lovely garden to walk through, not quiet because of the background noise of the city, but that in no way takes away from how authentic it feels. I live in China and have visited many Chinese gardens, so I was interested to see how authentic this one is. It did not disappoint.However the tour guide is not Chinese and although she knew a lot about the garden and Chinese culture that relates to it, she could not answer questions that a Chinese person would just know because they grow up in the culture.This seemed to me to be a obvious oversight.

Chinese Garden of Friendship in Sydney, NSW. This is one of the places we liked the most in Sydney, A relaxing walk through this garden that has a pond with big fishes, a tea restaurant, a traditional Chinese building on top of a small hill, bonsai trees, and more. The complete walk will take you around 20 minutes unless you decide to order something at the tea bar. Many Asian visitors seemed to enjoy it a lot. There are many spots where you can take beautiful photographs. Small entrance fee.
Close to Darling harbour. Difficult to find the entrance because of the major work going on in the vicinity.I was disappointed by these small gardens.
A touch of Asia. After the buzz of Darling Harbour, it is nice to walk around the quiter Chinese Gardens, and then on to China Town for dim sum.

Ah so, peace in a hectic city.. We visited on a day that had the sun beating down and gave us 34 degrees. The gardens have a wonderful mix of shade and open walkways.. Plenty of informative signage and a lovely tea room. Will always go back any time we're in Sydney.

An amazing place to visit. These gardens are a gem , if you are visiting Darling Harbour stroll down to the gardens an have a walk around. These gardens are not LARGE but are very interesting with the wildlife , ponds, and beautiful gardens. Not wheelchair or pram friendly as there are steps to walk up to reach the top of the gardens.

A tranquil place amongst all the hustle and bustle. This is the second time I have visited these gardens, and this time was even better than the last. I don't know how it can be so peaceful right in between the buzz of Darling Harbour and massive construction works being carried out. It must be the Yin-yang thing! The restaurant provides a welcome, relaxing finish to the visit. Would visit again if in Sydney.

wonderful garden to explore in Darling Harbour. what a gem, oasis in Darling Harbour. Only spent a short time here but it was just so relaxing and beautiful to explore. Will def come again, maybe for afternoon tea next time as it looked so good.

A JEWEL AMONGST THE GIANT Buildings of Sydney's Darling Harbor!. We enjoyed a change of plans today in Sydney, OZ.We were searching for a didgerydo concert when we stumbled upon the Chinese Garden of Friendship in Sydney. What luck! This garrden is fantastic with it's beautiful trees and blossoms and it's pagodas. The large holders are more like members of the community and the ponds with their koi residents just add to the mystery.This garden is surrounded by high condo neighbors, streets, and cats but the garden is still an oasis of calm!The waterfalls just ignore the man-made buildings and the roosting birdds do the same.Visit this lovely place and you will love it!

A place of peace and quiet in the hustle and bustle of the city. It's $6 to get in for adults but well worth that small price of admission. You feel as if you're in another time and place away from the hustle & bustle of Darling Harbour on the outside. Beautiful, quiet, peaceful, and relaxing
A haven of tranquillity. The garden is a small area of tranquility in the midst of a massive area of redevelopment associated with Darling Harbour. Well worth a visit

Beautiful place to visit and well designed. Spent almost an hour here yesterday and found it a peaceful place to relax in. I was listening to jazz music while walking around which I think helped eliminate the sound of the city and made me feel relaxed. I loved walking along the various pathways and being surprised by the garden landscape and features, especially the water features and buildings. If your in a rush to see the Sydney sites I might say give it a miss mainly because it's Chinese, not Australian origin but if your walking from Darling Harbour to China town it may improve your opinion of china town and if you do have the time to see the Garden I'm sure you will be very impressed and will enjoy it!
Beautiful and quiet. Best place to enjoy the quiet beauty. ..loved it...you can even dress yourself in Chinese traditional costumes

My favourite place on the planet. I adore this garden and have visited it many times over the years but each time find something new or different.
