A special well laid out garden. During a recent 5 day stay in Sydney our family enjoyed an hour wondering through these well planned gardens. As part of our visit we were able to dress up in traditional Ming Dynasty costumes and have photos taken, using our own camera, at $30 we thought it was good value. Our teenage daughters enjoyed finding animal figures dispersed through out the gardens via clue map given to us at the entrance. The entrance fee of $15 for our family was good value. We traveled to the gardens from The Rocks area via the free bus 555 up George street. It was a short walk from the George st bus stop to the Chinese garden of Friendship .There is a cafe on site which we didn't use. Plenty of clean toilets available.

Serenity in the midst of bustling Sydney. The staff are very helpful and friendly and the place is quite interesting, for a moment you forget you are in Sydney. Whilst it was enjoyable it was not very exciting however I am sure kids may find hunting the animals game quite enjoyable. It is scenic with some information and the rock forest was interesting. Given the low entrance fee it is probably worth a visit once but certainly not somewhere I consider going back unless you have kids.

Entrance fee for a garden?. The garden looked good from the outside but we decided not to go in because I found the entrance fee to enter a garden just absurd. If it was a voluntary donation, I wouldn't have minded.

Tranquillity plus. I'm so glad that I squeezed a visit to these gardens in on my recent weekend in Sydney. These gardens have a very soothing effect on you amongst the hustle and bustle of the city, the only regret is that I did not have more time throughly enjoy the experience.

guided tour despite the rain. We went to the garden on a cloudy morning and learned that there was an 11:00 tour. We were the only people for the tour, as it sprinkled, but the guide took us through the garden and explained some of the history behind various plants, rocks, and design features, as well as why the garden was donated to the people of Sydney. While we had rain jackets, he did the tour in just his shirt but was not willing to skip parts of the garden to move in side even when the rain got heavier - a clear demonstration of the spirit of friendship that inspired the garden in the first place. A great morning activity.

Romantic, green, beautiful oasis. One rainy early morning, in our last day in Sydney, we headed to visit the Chinese Gardens, as our last chance to do it, despite the not so pleasant weather. Arriving at the entrance, the ladies giving us the tickets told us about the unique opportunity we were having - the gardens all to ourselves, given the bad weather :) We began to stroll among the pavilions and the beautiful, magical landscape developed inside, feeling the mystical charm and the enriching silence. Discover this garden at your own pace, take your time (about 2 hours) to fully take advantage to all corners and vantage points. It is an unexpected calm spot in the vibrant and lively Sydney. We remained mesmerized by the beauty of the gardens, highly romantic and peaceful. We were told they inspire couples to arrange marriages here. In my heart, I hope they will be able to keep this place safe from the heap of tourists and from becoming a commercial spot; it would alter its soul.

A beautiful garden in the middle of a busy city. When we were tired of all the glitz and glitter for the day, we just had a 5 minute walk from our Meriton City LIfe hotel. And we were amply rewarded. Easy walk through, not expensive, and you just had to sit down and enjoy the beauty. A large pool, a waterfall; the kind of relaxing place you want at the end of the day.
Peace in the Middle of the City. These gardens are a little oasis in the hustle of Sydney. they are peaceful and calm with fish and ducks if you have children with you.

peace in the middle of Sydney. This is a beautiful spot to relax and escape the noise and bustle of Sydney. i was amazed by the beautiful water features and the covered pathways truly took me back to parks in Beijing

Tranquility Plus. I just love this place, and as far as I am concerned, no visit to Sydney is complete without a visit to this Garden. Although small, the peace and tranquillity of this place will surprise you. Sit down and close your eyes ... it won't take long for you to become really relaxed.Before you leave, enjoy a cup of Chinese tea in the tea room - there's a great variety of teas to choose from ... and the service is terrific.

Serenity in the middle if the city. After waiting for my friend to come back from a sailing trip at Darling Harbour, we started walking to Chinatown and discovered this beautiful garden. It reminded me of the gardens I visited in Soochow, China. The bonsai display near the entrance was beautiful, the landscaping, the pond, the Chinese structures are all so picturesque! I would recommend anyone visiting Sydney to spend some time at this place, it is truly a nice change from the crowds and noises from the big city!
Not very friendly if its not free.... Yeah, it looked nice from the outside, but it's about $11 AUS to walk through. Friendship should be free, frankly. Go visit the Botanic Gardens... for free.

Surprisingly great. Despite living close to sydney for my 38 years and remembering when darling harbour and these gardens where built, I had never visited them. Today that changed when I took a 15 and 11 year old to lunch at darling harbour. I didn't expect much and was thoroughly shocked to have an amazing time I can't believe this amazing garden exists in the city. The employees were helpful and had my kids engaged from the beginning we looked for all the zodiac signs hidden around the gardens seen turtles, lizards, fish and ducks.Next time I'm going to take a picnic.
Chinese friendship garden. What a great peaceful place in the middle of a busy city. Unfortunately not very handicap assessable. Beautiful place to relax.
THIRD VISIT. Every time I visit Sydney I alway come here. To me it is always a place to rest and unwind from the hussel & bussel of the city.

Calm and Beauty in the heart of chaos. These magnificent gardens were a gift to Australia during from the Chinese government and are a truly peaceful and calming place amid the chaos of the city. Located at the Chinatown end of Darling Harbour, they provide a place to stroll, rest and refuel.The gardens are designed to be viewed from many different vantage spots and offer a changing range of vistas throughout the seasons. There is a cover charge but it is worth it. The garden is well laid out with access for disabled but the access is not across the whole garden.Having taken children there they love it so many places to explore. Just make sure you word them up about not being too rowdy. There are clean restrooms and a tea house. Make sure you wear sensible foot wear as there are uneven surfaces. Bring a camera and have fun taking shots through the window and arbors that dot the garden.

A Tranquil Oasis in the heart of the city. Had a lovely time at the Chinese Garden of Friendship.This was on the list of things to see on a recent five night stay in Sydney.Located at the end of Darling Harbour, due to building around it I had to negotiate a scenic route to find it. Would have been easier coming in from the Harbour end than the Chinatown end.The Gardens are very pretty and as I was with friends who wanted the guided tour I also took the tour which was included in the $6.00 entry fee and was very informative delivered by a friendly young man.There is a cafe located in the gardens that did lovely scones jam and cream and coffee, amongst the other items on the menu. Was lovely sitting in the outdoor area even though we had quite a heavy shower of rain.Would go back to the gardens to experience the peace and enjoy the buildings, fish and water features

Peaceful space. Quiet well laid out garden in the midst of a busy thoroughfare. Worth a visit for a half hours rest. Interesting garden features and lay out. Quite different from Western gardens. Recommended for everyone.

Tranquil. On our second day we walked around the Darling Harbour area and then paid the small entrance fee and spent a great hour or so at this garden. Lots of water, koi fish, a turtle and the sound of chirping birds. A lot is packed into the relatively small area,

Beautiful gardens and fun for kids as well. Average-sized attraction. Good for kids too with school holiday activities and fish feeding. The Chinese costume hire was reasonably priced and good fun for kids. Great photo opportunities.
A Must See!. We loved the Friendship Garden. Stunning flowers, trees, fish, rocks, statues and pagodas. A great picture opportunity! A very peaceful place in a busy city.

Totally worth the entry fee. It was a total surprise to find these beautiful gardens amidst the city landscape. Even with the noise of the convention centre build very close by it was peaceful and fun. There are ways to spend MORE money once you enter (try on period costumes for pictures or tea ceremony) but don't feel compelled. Well worth it even without these extras.
Peace. Been there, done it and it was truly worth it ! Ended a lovely visit in the tranquil tea house, a little haven

Chinese garden of Friendship. What a gem of a place! My friend and I spent the first 2 hours just taking photos of this stunning garden. A credit to its landscapers, such a shame that it will soon have a back drop of multi-storey buildings from just about every angle. The cafe could improve the cakes and food provided but this wasn't enough to spoil our visit, and would definitely recommend the Chinese Garden of Friendship.

Peaceful time out. It is a wonderful, restful place to visit to just slow down from the fast paced area that is Sydney. I paid the entrance fee and included the tea and scones option (yum), which was very reasonable. The gardens are a delight - you can wonder around at your own pace, and there is a photo opportunity at every turn. The waterfall, lotus pond, chinese inspired pagodas and different plants are all beautifully presented and maintained. The only negative was the number of unruly children (who were dressed in hired costumes) running around unsupervised, and making unnecessary noise...it spoilt the ambience just a little.

Beautiful gardens. This is a must to visit if you are in Sydney. Down near Darling Harbour these gardens are magnificent. So lovely to walk through and see the stunning garden displays! The bonsai are amazing! Lots of beautiful water features, You could spend a few hours here. It is very relaxing and peaceful. There is a tea room their and lots of shady spots to sit on a hot day. A short walk from the centre of Sydney really worth a visit!

a quiet and peaceful corner in a busy city. it is a nice and relaxing place to check out if you are near darling harbour area, something different to see for a reasonable price + to take some nice pictures with a waterfall and Chinese style garden, I advise to make this sight part of your darling harbour experience, it's not worth going to Chinese f=gardens on purpose

it was nicely decorated but be careful!. Ok pros first:it was nicely situated in the heart of Sydney's darling harbor.It is fabulously decorated inside and gives you the feel like you are in the country and not in the middle of such a built up city.Very calming and peaceful atmosphere.Cons:Very expensive for what it has.Much smaller than i expected.BE CAREFUL: They have a facility where you can put on traditional Japanese clothes. There is a sign outside which says something like "dress up inside" or something like that. So we decided to do this and believe me, it made for amazing and funny pictures which I will have with me forever. It made the experience way more enjoyable walking around in these clothes. However, when we went back to hand back the clothes and collect our bags, we were surprised to hear that we had to pay in order to put on those clothes. Not once did they mention prices or were prices seen on the sign. If i remember properly it was 10 dollars each just to wear those clothes. If those clothes were included in the admission price I would have recommended everyone go just for the amazing pictures we got alone but overall it ended up being a very expensive trip and you wouldn't spend long there, max 1 hour. We left the garden feeling that it was extremely overpriced.

Better than you'd expect!! Stunning garden in the middle of Sydney!. I was just taking a walk with a friend around the area and we just came across this garden so decided to go in. What a beautiful garden! They have tea ceremony (additional fee applies) with a little dessert but we missed it by a hair. It is pretty big and it took us about 1 hour-90 minutes. They have a game for children where they have to find animal figures scattered around the garden so family with kids can go without anyone getting bored :)

Tranquility in the city. I love this garden and try and visit it whenever I'm in Sydney. A very tranquil and peaceful garden, although I did notice this time that given all the building happening in Darling Harbour, that it wasn't quite a peaceful in the past. Definitely worth a visit and at only $6 entry fee, doesn't break the budget.

transported out of Sydney Harbor. Even with Darlington Harbor all around and multi story high rises in sight, the garden is an oasis of calm. Listen to the birds, watch the dragons, and enjoy the many views of the garden. While you are walking around, you forget you are in very busy harbor with shops and loads of people.We took the 30 minute guided tour to learn a bit more about the design elements, and background into the garden. The guide was very knowledgeable, energetic, and answered everyone's questions.

Amazing. We have travelled all over China and found these gardens to be exactly what we would find gardens in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Beijing. Really friendly staff, and inexpensive to enter. Loved it, job well done to those who've created it and who run it.

Spend the money and enjoy yourself!. It cost us $6 each to enjoy this masterpiece of Chinese gardening. It is money well spent. You need to see it for yourself as words and pictures cannot do it justice.

A haven of tranquility in a very busy city!. This is a little treasure tucked away on the edge of Darling Harbour, close to Tumbalong Park and Chinatown. It’s a walled haven of peace amidst the bustle of the city, a traditional Chinese garden filled with waterfalls, exotic plants, a lake and pavilions. It’s good value too, at $6 for entry.
Nice. This is a nice little garden close to Darling Harbour. It is there so you need to see it. I feel it needs a little more loving and care as you might walk by it without noticing.
Little piece of China. A tranquil garden in the centre of Sydney. So many photo opportunities. Not expensive a really worth a visit.

A haven. Who would have thought that there would be this haven of tranquility just a stone throw away from the hubbub of the Darling Harbour area.The gardens are beautifully landscaped and maintained. It fits perfectly into the general idea of what a Chinese garden should look like. Very serene,romantic and peaceful.
Chinese garden darling harbour. what a relaxing spot, just amble over to it from the Oaks Goldsborough through the Darling Harbour shopping/food precinct

A haven of tranquility.. I think everyone who has visited here, gets the same feeling of relaxation and tranquillity away from the hustle and bustle of city life. A chance to reflect, ponder life, and enjoy these beautiful gardens. Well worth a visit or two.

Beautiful and Serene. Allow two hours and just enjoy this oasis of calm in the middle of all the scrapers and building work.
Also try the Chinese Dim Sum and the teas in the (small) restaurant. Very nice and very good value.

tranquil setting in busy CBD. this garden is so beautiful full of lovely flowers and trees with traditional chinese architecture. its an oasis amongst a busy cosmopolitan city. it has all the classic chinese garden design features. the teahouse is particulary nice enjoy steam dumplings or coffee with wonderful views.

Beautiful Oasis in Sydney. I'd heard of this place but was not expecting such care and detail here. The garden is quite large and surrounded by the city and tall buildings. Even so, they do a good job of taking you away to a dream landscape. The central pond is awesome. There are trails that climb around hills and trees. There are many places just to sit and enjoy the views. there is also a small café that serves tea, of course. Nice place to spend a few hours.

Tranquility. If you need a peaceful spot in the middle of the city this could be the place. It is so serene in there, that you can almost forget you are in the city and there are hundreds of cars out side.

Chinese Cultural Garden. It is a superb garden located in Darling Harbor near to China Town. The garden reflects the Ming Dynasty. The enclosed garden has waterfalls, exotic plants and hidden pathways and a Tea house serving Chinese tea. If you go to Darling Harbor, you must visit this garden which is much more than a garden.

a beautiful garden in a beautiful city. well darling harbour is a sensational place to visit in Sydney many great restaurants there, however visit the Chinese gardens and be over whelmed by the beauty of it. I have passed it so many times on the flyover and it always amazes me

Beautiful. Right in the heart of the city this is a beautiful place to visit and very tranquil. It is a must for anyone staying that area of Sydney. Very friendly staff and the bonus for us was, it was Seniors Week and we didn't have to pay but that would not have stopped us paying a visit.

best day in sydney. beautiful gardens to wander round and relax , lots of quite spots to sit and watch the fish or birds and also their is an opportunity to dress up as and emperor/empress for an extra 10asd well worth the experience but my girlfriend said i cant upload the photographs

A Pearl in an ocean of Concrete. This peaceful garden is simply beautiful wherever you look. So much concentrated in such a such a relatiively small area. Albeit by right, we benefited from the Australian Seniors rate but it's worth the full entry fee by any measure. Plenty of places to sit and admire the views (and take copious photos). A temple, a waterfall, lots of interesting rocks and beautiful trees. We went on a Sunday morning. So did a group including Chinese children in traditional custom. They were clearly in their element and enjoying every minute. There's a nice cafe where you can sit looking over the pond and enjoy a glass of wine. Don't miss it!

You must to visit the beautiful garden. A beautiful and tranquil little garden is located in the heart of this City: Darling Harbour. When you go inside this garden, you feel like you are in China, everywhere is so amazing, the maintained is so good, you can find some frogs, lizards, birds & fish etc...The kits will love that.Different flowers open in four seasons, the lotus pond and the willow make the garden so charming. The teahouse is the perfect spot to enjoy an authentic range of Chinese tea, dumplings, pastries and steamed buns. That's so many things to see in the garden, you can spend the whole morning inside this beautiful garden, Everywhere in the garden is a good spot to take the photos.
Lovely place for a visit. Such a lovely place and so reasonably priced. Really enjoyed revisiting here after 20 years. Very well maintained and the front desk staff were very helpful.

Great gateway from the city. It felt relaxing to be able to walk away from the busy and noisy streets and submerge into peace and beauty. Kids loved it too, so much to look at, every corner had an amazing sight and something to get excited about.
Wonderful place to visit. This was our 2nd visit and thoroughly enjoyed it. We have travelled to china and seen the gardens there, but the Sydney version is just as magnificent. Well worth the visit.

fabulous ..do visit.. A most beautiful garden in an amazing space, peaceful, inspirational and a delight for all the senses. Set in amost the high rise bussle and chaos of Sydney CBD it is truely refreshing. The tea house is a great stop to admire the carp and birdlife. Hiring costumes looked great fun. Allow yourself more time than you might expect and relax.

Must do.. This garden is an amazing place, my only regret is that I would not be there to see the change of seasons. Amazing peaceful place in the middle of a busy city. I wandered around this beaufiful garden for a couple of hours and could of stayed longer,

A great way to show UK visitors another side of Sydney. Brilliant. On a warm Sydney January day we took 4 visitors from UK to this lovely little green escape in the middle of our huge, bustling city. Once inside the walls it is hard to imagine the concrete and traffic outside. The gardens have been beautifully nurtured over the past 20 something years and every corner is another delightful vista. It's easy to see why a number of couples choose this inner-city spot to hold their weddings.We also came across the costume hire venue in the gardens which was an amazing way to entertain ourselves (being aged between 45 and 71). For a small hire of $10 per adult we were dressed like Chinese Royalty (complete with ice packs under the costumes to keep us cool on a 30degree day). We took some beautiful photos out in the gardens and our visitors went home having had a great adventure, many laughs and taken some glorious photos.

lots of fun. Lovely garden you would not think you were in the middle of a city. Loved hiring Chinese costumes which you then walk round the gardens in taking your own photos wherever you want.It was a great laugh.

Oasis in an urban jungle. Like WOW! surrounded by skyscrapers this garden is just so peaceful and is wonderful place to sojourn from the daily stresses of city life. It is really well laid out and maintained and is a peaceful place to get away and reflect. Beautiful

An unimagined surprise!. What a lovely surprise this tranquil little garden is--right in the heart of the city! When we first entered, we had no idea we could spend over an hour exploring the intricate paths and photographing the gorgeous landscape. Though relatively small (perhaps a couple acres or so), the Chinese Garden of Friendship is incredibly varied and interesting, with winding paths that lead past beautifully manicured gardens and trees as well as koi ponds alive with not only fish but turtles and birds of all kinds. We encountered several tame lizards as well! Flowers were blooming though it was February when we visited, and they added to the beauty. The garden sits right in the heart of the city, just off Darling Harbor, so it's possible to see the skyscrapers over the tops of the trees--but the garden is so beguiling and soothing that the city sights almost seem like an illusion. It was hot the day we visited, and strolling along the shady paths of the garden provided a restful break from the heat and noise outside. This truly is a sanctuary. Don't pass this one by--in just an hour or so, you can take it all in, and you'll emerge refreshed.

Beautiful oasis. It was a pleasure walking around the Chinese gardens. A little oasis in the middle of the city. Take the time to stroll and sit - maybe have a cup of tea. Entrance fee is only $6. well worth it.
An oasis of calm. I first went to this garden when it opened many years ago. It has matured into a beautiful place in the heart of Sydney, well worth the $6 entry fee.
CHINESE FRIENDSHIP GARDEN. A piece of tranquillity in a busy city! Went there during Chinese New Year and it was just so peaceful and lovely.
peaceful and beautiful. a wonderful place to chill out , flower displays in abundance. the Chinese café is also a good place to relax and have a cup of tea. c

Beautiful Chinese Gardens.. A lovely Place to go to Meditate or just get out of the Rat race. A little piece of heaven in the middle of a busy city. Well worth seeing. There is also a pretty coffee shop to sit in to enjoy the garden on your own or with friends.

A haven in the city. What an unexpected delight to walk up from Darling Harbour to find a perfect Chinese garden, spacious and tranquil amid the bustle of the city. Entry was by small fee and we entered next to the exquisite bonsai display then mounted the path through a circular gateway to a chain of ponds with landscaped hills and small delicate temple-like shelters. A short walk up beside the waterfall and around descending through the rocks and on to the tea room which serves refreshing scones, cakes and pastries and tea or coffee all reasonably priced. This place is truly a tranquil haven.

2 1/2 hours of pure joy ---photo opportunity with every step. I had the great pleasure of walking around this garden with my daughter who also loves gardens and taking photos.water flowed around the garden in a perfectly placed rock lined stream-- one great waterfall and many small falls dotted around .a grotto where the tea rooms are sited was a joy to sit beside--- happily we were able to watch the giant Koi being fed the oldest was about 45 years old--- this garden was manicured in a way that complimented the design--- there were steps some were natural( uneven) so care must be taken if reduced sight or difficulty in walking(I managed with a walking stick quite well)--$6 entry I got in free it was pensioner week-- well worth it --- coffee was great lunch type food quite reasonable and tasty-- you could hire robes to get in character$100 adult$5children

Beautiful. Really worth the trip. Seems ridiculous that in the concrete jungle of the city is this beautiful garden. Can spend hours here. Also a nice restaurant where you can rest your feet before venturing back out into the city.

Chinese Garden Of Freindship Sydney. The Chinese Garden Of friendship is the one of the most beautiful gardens that I have seen very peaceful and tranquil some idiot complained on trip advisor of the uneven ground well it is a gravel ground garden and all gravel gardens have uneven ground do your selves a favour when you in Sydney this is a must see.

Waiting for the plane. What a garden, so close to the city it is unbelevabley prety. We had checked out of the hotel and were killing time before the trip to the airport, when we stumbled accross this atraction, I would urge everyone not to miss it

Tranquillity. This is a wonderful place beside the busy Darling Harbour. Once you go through the doors, all the noise and bustle fades away and you are in a colourful, fragrant and very peaceful place. There is so much to see but no urgency - it's for gentle strolling. There is a lovely tearoom to top up your energy. Highly recommended.

Don't miss this.. So beautiful, my wife and I spent a couple of hours wandering and stopping at various points just enjoying the peaceful feeling and enjoying the views from different angles, my wife was very keen to see this and I was a little reluctant....I am glad we went.
Very Relaxing. Very relaxed wander around, quite surreal a haven like this in the middle of the hustle and bustle. Would definitely recommend a visit!

Peace in the hustle & bustle of Sydney. Peaceful and beautifully laid out. This was my favourite place that we visited on our short stop in Sydney. I could have spent a whole day just taking in all the different views, but unfortunately didn't have enough time to do so. We also took the opportunity to dress up in traditional Chinese costume from the Ming dynasty. The staff who helped us were amazing and their attention to detail was excellent. They also spent time taking photos of us at different spots around the gardens, and made the experience fun for us all. We had a delicious light lunch in the cafe afterwards. it was worth every cent of the small entry fee we paid, and I look forward to visiting again next time I'm in Sydney.

Great place to visit in SYD centre. It is with great location and fantastic Chinese atmosphere.The garden is designed greatly and staff who explains at the information site helps a lot while walking around. strongly recommend to go if you have time
Peace and Tranquility. This is an excellent spot for a little peace, tranquility and quiet reflection in the middle of a vibrant city.

Peaceful retreat from City Crowds Hustle and Bustle. the best anti stress therapy I could imagine. we found these gardens years ago, when walking to Darling Harbour. A strange feeling of being cocooned from the constant noise of the city. Even though it was a weekend it still retained the calming tranquility of a genuine Chinese garden. My favourite were the water features and small streams. Surprisingly there were no screaming out of control children running about. They had obviously succumbed to the calming influence there or someone had attempted to teach them to swim with the Koi.
relaxing. we had a lot of fun finding the dragons, and the maps helped with the zodiac challenge . Everyone was so nice

Beautiful & Peaceful. I loved it in here, I went on a warm day and wanted to get out of the sun. The gardens are so well done and there were stories and activities going on as it was Chinese new year. The gardens are green and have plenty of water features, so tranquil, I found it a really peaceful and recharging experience

Beautiful gardens. These tranquil gardens are a perfect escape from the busy Sydney city. My boyfriend and I decided to buy the lunch ticket which got us either a tea and scones or a dim sum and a jasmine tea each, which to me was a bargain at $11 each. The gardens were gorgeous and there were loads of big lizards chilling on rocks which was awesome for us to see as we are from the UK and we see none over there! At the end of our walk we then had our lunches which was delicious and definitely worth the money. A must see visit if you are visiting Sydney!

Visit when building work opposite is complete. This should be a nice peaceful area but due to the building of the new conference centre it is not. I would not recommend coming here until 2016 when the building work should have ended

Compact. We visited the Chinese gardens when it was throwing it down with rain so we probably didn't see it in all its glory. It's in the middle of the city in walking distance from a darling a Harbour. It is set out as a traditional Chinese garden with waterfalls , pagodas etc and there is a cafe in the middle. It is quite small and after half an hour we had seen it all so I thought it was a bit expensive for the amount of time you spent there.

Tranquil and beautiful. We spent a few hours here, the gardens are so beautiful and you get a genuine sense of wellbeing while you are there. The tea house is wonderful for morning tea and scones. The map is really easy to follow and you can find lots of secluded places to sit and chat. Whenever we are in Sydney we always plan a visit to the Chinese Garden as it is outstanding.

Beautiful. A really pretty attraction worthy of a visit. An oasis of calm in the busy area, the juxtaposition of the beautiful gardens and the skyscrapers is remarkable. They even had a little treasure hunt for kids. Highly recommended and just $6 for adults.

Great place for a day trip. The scenery is truly amazing and hard to believe that this garden is in the CBD amongst all the buildings. Once you get in you can spend the whole day inside the gardens and looking around at your own pace. Don't forget your camera.!!
Peaceful Gardens. I have been several times to the Gardens. It is such a peaceful and pretty garden to explore and to have morning tea.

Outstanding!. We spent an hour or so in the garden -- it was interesting and peaceful. We had originally gone by on a Sunday, when admission was free\, however for the $6 admission charge we returned the next day and avoided noise and crowds. The signage at the garden is excelle nt and there is very good interpretation provided.
Stunning. A beautiful and tranquil garden in the middle of the city. This is an authentic Chinese Garden with Koi ponds, little bridges and pergolas scattered around the walk.

Tranquil.. This is a lovely, peaceful, garden to walk around. You just get lost in the calm quiet and it doesn't feel like you are in a large city. We did the afternoon tea and entry ticket which was well worth it.

Chinese Gardens. Well worth a visit, entrance fee payable. Unfortunately we had to hurry our walk around the gardens as closing time was only half an hour away. There are some lovely tranquil spots where one could sit and meditate. We plan to visit again.

Excellent!. Was a worthwhile stop while at Darling Harbour. Possibly a bit under-rated. I am not really a gardens person but stopped in on recommendations. Thought the $6 entry was very reasonable. Gardens are wonderful and exceeded my expectations.

Zen spot in the middle of the city. I love this place. I visit every time I go to Sydney. I always lose a few hours here, just taking it all in. So tranquil and peaceful. Nice to get away from the busy feel of the city for an afternoon.

Calming. I was in the city early for a business meeting. Feeling particularity frazzled after hellish city rail train trip down from the Central Coast. I went into the gardens when they opened at 9.30 as needed to relax before my meeting. I chose the perfect time to go in. Away from the hoards who would descend later in the day. There was hardly anyone in there apart from me - it was almost eerily creepy. But it was also extremely relaxing. You can hardly believe you are in the middle of a busy city. Highly recommended to spend an hour.

Gorgeous Chinese gardens. Absolutely stunning! This is a tranquil little garden in the centre of the hustling bustling city that is Sydney. Recommended for older individuals as children can take from the tranquility of the atmosphere represented. There is a little cafe serving a variety if nibbles and drinks. It's a lovely place to sit and read, take a stroll, meditate and just relax overall.When I went there was also a wedding underway.

A peaceful escape. We had often walked by the gates of this garden and had always meant to go in. I have been to some marvellous Chinese gardens in Shanghai and didn't expect these to compare particularly well but I was surprised at how such a compact space could be so calm and evocative of the Chinese spirit with some lovely spaces ... and even a few live dragons ...
calm in a busy city.. We thought this garden was beautiful. So well designed and such a stunning sight that you couldn't help be stunned as you walked in. Lovely planting!

So peaceful. This walled garden was conceived and constructed in the 1980's and gifted to Sydney by the city of Guangzhou in southern China. Though it is right down town at Darling Harbour the minutes you walk through the gate you forget about the hustle and bustle of the outside. Though the garden is not large (1 hectare) it has lots of paths that twist and turn around the water features, rocks and small buildings. This is a photographers dream and well worth a visit.

Take the kids for fun Chinese dress-ups and photos. I have been to this location on many occasions for many reasons, shooting TV segments, fun outings for the family and just for something to do on a quiet Sunday. There's a shop there where the kids can get dressed up in colourful traditional Chinese clothing. If you have little girls this is a must. Mine love it. You can get dressed up too if you like, and I've seen plenty of adults getting into it! Each time the ladies who run the dress-up store have been friendly and kind, fussing over the kids and even doing their hair. I've gotten some great photos of them dressed up over the years. If you're looking for something fun on a weekend, give it a go. It's also quiet surreal being in the garden next to the city buildings.

Nice little garden but in pokey place of Sydney.. I happened to come across this place by accident on my walk back from Darling Harbour and the darling harbour concrete jungle. It's a pleasant enough little garden, and I had a bit of wander through it. But I wouldn't go out of my way to go to it again.
A lovely oasis. This is a sanctuary from the rest of Darling Harbour. There is a map to take you around, lots of photo opportunities.

Pleasant. Very pleasant when I was there as it was the Chinese New Year Celebrations. Lots going on. Also Valentine's Day Celebration in Darling Harbour which was a bonus and both events were complimentary to each other.

Tranquility. Next to Darling Harbour the Chinese Gardens are a very good place to spend an hour or two. There is a resturant that serves lunches and teas.
The only negative thing is they only give reduce entrance to Australian pensioners.

Just superb. To see this awesome Chinese Garden in the heart of Sydney is so mesmerising.
Really well laid out and as good as anything I have I have seen in China. So many spots to sit and look back over the gardens etc. an enjoyable day. I suggest to anyone to visit here it's a good day.

Family Visit. We love the Chinese Gardens and the tranquility of the grounds.. the nature based 'architecture', the water features and peaceful design / layout made the time there very special. Took a photo in the same spot as we did on our honeymoon 23 years ago! Having a cuppa and food is an option we took and a water dragon 'joined' us as we ate.. the feeding of the Koi was amazing.. The bonsai were breath taking! Such a wonderful experience and less than $10 each! An absolute must see!

Beautiful. Love this place. August probably isn't the best time to go, the plants and trees aren't in bloom. But we went in September a few years previous and it was absolutely amazing. Great little teahouse there also.

A little piece of heaven in a concrete jungle. Had a great time enjoying the Chinese New Year celebrations in and around the garden. They have a Penjing Competition on there at the moment too. Well worth a visit.

Amazing Place. Absolutely brilliant space. There was so much to see and it was laid out so that you could see everything without missing anything. It was a wonderful, peaceful place right next to Darling Harbour and had an amazing amount of plants and trees and the water features were lovely.

Peace and Tranquility. I'm sure that if this place was easier to get to it would be overrun with visitors. However, I was pleased that it wasn't. A lovely guide walked us around some of the garden and then we spent time looking at what interested us. It is really beautiful - a lovely lake in the centre and the Bonsai garden is amazing. Good tea shop too!

Not to be missed. This would be one of the best attractions around Darling Harbour. The layout and tranquillity of the place is fantastic. You can walk through displays of lakes, ponds & waterfalls filled with many Koi & Turtles that you would believe you were in China not in the Middle of Sydney. Take time to stroll around and enjoy.Snacks & drinks are available on site.The $6.00 entry is worth every cent.

Another Oasis in a busy City. The Gardens are exquisite and bring a sense of peace and beauty to a busy City. We spent time walking around and enjoying the various little aspects and corners of the garden. The plants and blossoms are beautiful and the ducks and fish are an added delight. The cafe was good but a bit limited for a Celiac like myself but it is worth having a coffee just to sit for half an hour and enjoy the atmosphere.
Relaxation. Enjoyed the setting in the garden and atmosphere. It really stands out in the middle of CBD.I just wish the garden would be bigger.

A Complete Oasis. A very nice place to be at if you want to relax with a big pond in the middle mini waterfalls ducks frogs fish around you ... If alone take a book or close your eyes and relax .. Otherwise great fun for families and kids too ... Cafe doesn't offer much options though so pack your lunch and drinks ... Otherwise great fun and not expensive at all ... Ideally you could spend three to four hrs in here but if you just want to have a look, you could be out in an hour

I come back every year. The Chinese garden of friendship is possibly my favourite place in Australia. I make the trip to Sydney atleast once a year purely to spend a whole day reading,studying and listening to music in the beautiful and relaxing surroundings. It's a must see while in Sydney, and it's my personal escape from life when it gets too much.

An oasis of peace.... I had an easy 30 min walk from my hotel in the Rocks area. Way cool to find this gem in the city. Larger than it looks from the outside. Pay your money cause it's worth the $6. Just wander around this secret spot in the city. City sounds disappear. Stress disappears. Wonder and awe appears at the beauty. Similar yet so different from the Roy. bot. Gardens. An oasis in the city. Definitely worth a visit.

Tranquil beauty. We visited this garden on a hot sunny afternoon. It was a beautiful and peaceful place.$6 entry fee.Paradise in the middle of the Sydney. Waterfalls, lakes, huge trees.... There are traditional chinese costumes available for hire and take photos of it which was great fun.And the small Tea room, sells good food and tea/coffee at very reasonable prices

Changed my life. After an epic journey to see my beloved son who lives in Sydney, he brought me here, I didn't know what to expect and I was transformed by the experience. It's worth taking time to just be at one with yourself in this garden. The majestic city towers as a backdrop but in the garden there is only tranquil beauty. Slow down, stroll, don't rush through, notice the undulating stone, the lattice work where you are hidden from view, wait for the lizards to pop up and the turtles to cast a lazy eye on you.You cannot see the whole of the garden from any one place, such is the quality of it's design. We walked my son and I, Jasmine drifting on the breeze and the hint of another culture strong in our minds. At the end of the walk I was calm, serene and happy and also truly grateful for the opportunity to be there. We ended our walk in the Pagoda overlooking the pool and time stood still for me as I looked at my first born and knew I would remember this moment forever.

Beautiful garden. We visited this garden to while away a couple of hours on a hot sunny afternoon. It is a beautiful and peaceful place to be. The design allows you to enjoy the different aspects of the garden from many different angles. The flowing water and cascades are very soothing. We enjoyed a cup of tea whilst watching the Koi. The garden is not large but if you enjoy gardens then the $6 is a very cheap price to pay. Well worth the money.
Relax here.. When you go to Darling harbour and want some peace wander in to these gardens. The water features are most relaxing to listen to.

Garden of peace. I was amazed to find that I could totally block the sound of a very busy city while in the gardens. Every turn bought a new visits. Sitting watching the huge carp swim languidly by was amazing. I'm Blown away by the place. Facilities for buggies and wheelchairs. Simple food is available?If you're a weary tourist..
Chinese Gardens secret. Looks small from the outside, huge and beautiful on the inside. Very serene. Go in for a quiet picnic lunch or a short stroll to get your zen going.
A Place of Solitude Within the craziness of the area. Visited here first in 2013 and came back to revisit it again. Sorry to see that the jade carriage is gone.

Lovely way to spend an afternoon. After travelling Asia and visiting temple gardens there I was surprised to find I really felt like I was back there! Complete contrast to the hustle and bustle of city life. Defiantly reccomend going to the area where you can get dressed up in traditional clothing and have your photos taken, it was really fun!

Highly recommended. Nice place to be with the nature, didn't expect it to be so beautiful and hats off to the pristine and beautiful architecture in the middle of business city. Catch a cup of green tea and Chinese buns they were tasty. You can also wear Chinese attire for some dollars and see the fish the whole day. Had an awesome experience.
You have to go there. This I recommend highly. It's a beautiful garden and so tranquil. I got so inspired walking there and the staff was very helpful.
Give it a miss. A pretty poor circular pathway with little quality. Walk was done in 15 minutes, not worth the entry fee.

Lovely Oasis in Darling Harbour Sydney. I visited The Chinese Garden of Friendship before meeting friends for lunch in Darling Harbour. It is such a little Oasis of tranquillity and beauty right in the middle of a bustling and busy city. The entry fee is $6 adult and $3 child (under 12)The gardens are not huge, so easy to walk around (although wheelchair access only being good in the lower regions and not into the steeper sections) The various vantage points across the ponds and lake are beautiful. It really is a feast for the eyes. The Lotus flowers were imposing and the many dragonflies delightful. The water dragons were also a great sight sitting on the rocks. Even a baby duckling wandered bravely around. There is a sense of calm and serenity throughout the gardens and multiple seating areas to sit and relax a while.My visit was early in the morning, so people traffic was at a minimum which I would recommend to get the real sense of beauty and peace. If you are looking for a bit of fun, you can dress up in traditional costume and have your photo taken and if you are on the peckish side, there is a well priced Teahouse where you can sit and view large koi and turtles in the surrounding waters. A bit of heaven for a nature photographer.I would recommend it for all ages.
Romantic. Thought we had travelled back to china. brought back so many memories. the gardens are very quite mid week.

A bit twee but still good fun for the kidlets. By the time your children are over 10 they will wonder why you brought them here. It's a token gesture, kindly bestowed on Sydney by the chinese government in the Bicentennial year, and well maintained in the 20-odd years since. It is, however, more of a pocket park than a garden and will really appeal to a) garden buffs and b) families with smaller children.There are other, larger asian styled gardens in Australia, but my feeling is that if you are here from overseas with limited time you should spend your garden viewing time in the beautiful Royal Botanic Gardens rather than here.Sydney visitors should go at least once, especially while your family is young. Then give it a big tick and move on :-)

Lovely gardens. A beautiful garden in the midst of the hustle and bustle of the city. It is very peaceful for some time out away from it all. The gardens themselves are lovely and they also have some interesting historical elements. There are traditional costumes available for hire and there is also a tea house. $6 entry fee.
Beautiful and serene. Nice retreat from the hustle bustle of downtown Sydney... Lush Asian inspired gardens. Try to make it in time for the Teahouse (we got there too late and it had closed).

Feel like a traditional Chinese. Although not a big fan of visiting other cultures in a different nation, I entered this attraction twice. The first one just to have a look at the elements it offers inside; bonsai trees, sculptures, a pond. And the second one to dress in traditional Chinese clothes. They provide you with extra equipment if you want such as swords.
Zen in the city.. A quiet & peaceful garden in the middle of the city. Quite small but beautiful. Lots of plants, ponds with koi fish, pagoda with benches where you can sit & relax.

A slice of lovely Suzhou in sydney!. An excellet and beautiful traditional style chinese garden in the middle of sydney, what more could you ask for?the entry fees have gone up a bit over the years, but I would say that the prices are worth it, expecially if you are a student and bring your concession cards. It is a great place for a date, in fact we saw many couples there, taking pictures and doing romantic things together.You can also hire a traditional costume inside the garden which we did and take photos of it which was fun. An excellent place to spend a peaceful afternoon!

Tranquility in the CBD!. We visited The Chinese Garden of Friendship on a sunny Thursday in January. The cost was $6 and was well worth the visit. This is an amazingly peaceful and beautiful place right in the heart of Sydney. There is plenty of wildlife, we saw a range of birds, fish, lizards and turtles. The grounds are superbly taken care of and I would definitely go back. Everything has meaning, and it's a fantastic place to relax and leave your troubles behind.We took a highlights tour which meets at certain times throughout the day in the reception area. Our guide, Sue, was extremely friendly and knew so much about the garden. It was so interesting and her enthusiasm was contagious. Thank you Sue.I would recommend this place to anyone, check it out! Fantastic experience for a hour or two :)
Beautiful. What a beautiful escape right in the heart if Sydney! Wonderful lush gardens. Fabulous to wander around in.

Relaxing. Do not come here in the morning. We did and found ourselves drinking tea and feeling so relaxed. It is so beautiful and the fish are fun to watch. It is not expensive. We paid $6 per person. Very clean and very friendly
weekend escape. Set on a small piece of land and gain a lot of tranquillity is amazing even while it is was raining we wanted to stay

Always a beautiful place to visit. Peaceful and serene right in the heart of Sydney these gardens are visited by hundreds of people daily. I visit there every time I'm in Sydney and just sit and relax for a while, it's a great way to shake off the stress of the day. Beautifully maintained and you may even see a lizard or two.
The Chinese garden is in darling harbour. Situated in darling harbour which is another amazing place in Sydney loved having a wander around and the fish in pond round about the gardens .

Peace. Peace and quiet in the centre of Sydney. The tour explains the ethos of the gardens and lake.
Try to go when it is not to warm you will miss the mossies.

A peaceful retreat. Despite being in the middle of the city, the Chinese gardens offer a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle. We had a lovely visit, took about 100 photos! Such a beautiful place to visit.
Great food and service. Well presented and the staff just friendly.The food was cooked to satisfy the best tastes.Clean . Atmosphere a little down trending but still appealing
Very nice. Nice and tranquil with plenty of bridges,trees plants and a few species of birds,a waterfall and small stream.
Beautiful. Although I went alone I really enjoyed walking around the gardens. Everything was nice and green & kept in great condition.

A peaceful oasis. The Chinese Gardens are a quiet oasis in Darling Harbour. Met up with friends for a look around the Gardens and a bite to eat. It is reasonably priced and has enough shade and cool breezes to help counter a hot Sydney morning. A vey pleasant way to spend an hour or two, with a treasure hunt to keep the kids interested and occupied.

Exotic.....!!!. When we took the hop on hop off this was one of the attraction on the map. It did fancy much for us to make a visit. From outside also it doesn’t appeal. And being on the busy street it could attract us. But somehow we made our mind to visit and I’m glad we did!!!Entrance fee is $6 per adult and the park is only open until 5 in the evening.Inside it was all together a different world and it changed our imagination we had about it. A lovely place to escape in the middle of the city which has waterfalls, lakes, huge trees. You also have an opportunity to rent Chinese traditional dress and photograph (of course at additional charge) It’s a different feel altogether when you are here. Must visit.
the gardens are beautiful. the gardens are beautifuland well worth a visitjust to get out the hustle and bustle of the cityit is a paradise in the middle of the cityquiet

Quite a surprise.. Not sure why but I had avoided this place for years, or perhaps rather than avoid, just not bothered with it. But what a lovely oasis in the middle of all the Darling Harbour bustle. Worth a visit.

wonderful. Lovely little garden, very cheap to get in and just beautiful. Very impressive coy carp in the ponds too. Also be sure to visit the costume hut and try out the traditional Chinese dress for some fun photos
Nice. This is such a tranquil place to wander around. Beautiful surroundings, nice little pool full of ducks in the middle

So serene. We visited these gardens on a trip to Sydney in November whilst exploring Darling Harbour. They were just beautiful and very calming on a very warm and busy day. It was wonderful to just sit amongst the plants and soak in the atmosphere.

Just wonderful. Just walking past the gardens we popped in on a whim, and so very happy we did, what a wonderful oasis in the middle of a very busy area in Sydney harbour. It's situated in darling harbour right at the waters side.The cost was 6 $ each and well worth every penny. You can take a guided tour but we just wandered about under our own steam, the layout of the garden gives a feeling of a much larger area, there is beautiful trees and flowers, with water running all the way through and huge fish swimming about. You can even hire traditional Chinese costumes to give you the feeling of really being part of the garden, I can't say enough about this attraction it's just wonderful.

Celestial!. This darden was situated immediately next to our hotel. You can't see much of it from the outside but it looked enticing, though it seemed closed much of the time.When we did get in we were not disappointed. This is a beautiful romantic oasis of a place and larger than expected. The purpose and ideas behind the garden are well explained and it has a huge aura. There is much to see, feel, photograph and enjoy.There are Chinese Imperial costumes you can hire and wear in the garden if you wish and these were popular with children. You can akso take tea and dim sum in the garden. It is reasonably priced given the quality of the experience.

Beautiful, tranquil. When I first arrived I was surprised I had to pay as I had been on the internet before leaving the UK and asked was it free -'YES', but its not.The layout was good and easy to follow round, missing nothing, places to sit and contemplate, soaking up the atmosphere.You could even dress up in native Chinese costume for a photo shoot.Its amazing that its in the centre of things you wold never know.

Beautiful contrast to the city. A beautiful and serene location in the middle of Sydney, it really takes you out of the crowded and frantic nature of the city, allowing you to relax and enjoy. The gardens are beautiful, well maintained, and not crowded. it is actually surprisingly big once you get inside, and can easily lose time walking around. Lots of photo opportunities, including some interesting ones with the city looming in the background.

Good escape. The Chinese Garden of Friendship was a peaceful break from the city. It's very nicely landscaped with ponds, rocks, and waterfalls. It's a good chill spot to relax if you need a break from walking around the city. I think there was a $6 fee to get in.

A tad ordinary. As far as Chinatowns go, Sydney's is average at best. The Garden of Friendship is OK but not really worth a special trip. Better to spend time in the Botanical Gardens and Sydney harbour foreshore.

Chinese Garden of Friendship Darling Harbour. Be aware. The entrance is NOT on the street suggested on maps and suggested by NSW Transport's Trip Planner. We walked several hundred metres unnecessarily on a hot afternoon going from the Light Rail Station at Paddy's Market to a wedding. We were looking for signs but did not see any. This does not matter if walking is not a problem for you but for two people in their 80s it was significant.

Beautiful Oasis in the city. If you want to take a little time out from the hustle and bustle of the city this is the place to go. It really is very beautiful and there is quite a lot of wildlife in there as well. It has been beautifully designed and is well maintained. There is a café inside as well. It was school holidays when we went and there were special activities organised for kids. Would definitely go again.

Darling Harbour oasis.. On a hot day this is wonderful oasis in the heart of Darling Harbour. The gardens are beautiful and very tranquil. Lovely surprises and wonderful photo opportunities. Walking distance from the city. Suitable for adults and children.

Tranquility. What a wonderful tranquil place to visit, whilst the rest of the world rushes about its business. A positive sea of tranquillity in the middle of an extremely busy area. The gardens are just wonderful, and the water features make you forget the outside world. A place to visit many, many times

Pease & Quiet. In the heart of the Central Business District of Sydney this tranquil little oasis is sublime. For a fee of just AU$6 (£3.30) you can enjoy this beautifully laid out Chinese garden. With its Pagodas, Lake and water movement; it's tranquillity is unique and in contrast to the bustling city outside.The only drawback is the climb to the highest point which is in the main rocky and uneven and not disabled friendly, although there are other areas where those of less mobility can sit and meditate.There are tea rooms for refreshment and you can linger for as long as the mood takes you. Do not miss a visit to this wonderful oasis.

An oasis in the midst of the building. Chinese Garden of Friendship is an oasis of nature in the midst of concrete buildings. The garden was designed and constructed beautifully by the chinese. There are many different zones that you pass through. You get a sense of being in nature even though you are smack in the middle of the city. And the small cafe there sells good food and tea/coffee at very reasonable prices.

Lovely place to visit. A wonderful change from the fast pace of city life!The gardens are just stunning! So peaceful.A big contrast to the city just outside the garden walls! There are lots of little seating areas around the garden so you can sit back & take it all in! There is a small fee upon entry ($6 per adult) but its worth it! Great for all ages!

Tranquility in the City. Peace and tranquility in the heart of Sydney. Lots of water and concept landscaping. Spent some time wandering around watching wildlife. Guided tours available. Very pleasant place to whittle away an hour or so.

Lovely to visit. The first time we went to Sydney we walked back through these gardens and it was a lovely quiet, relaxing experience. This time it was peak holiday season and full of family and kids all having a great time - so this is a place for everyone depending on what time of day it is and what time of year it is.

Serene. Brilliant place. This place is worth every penny of the small entry fee they collect.( 6dollars for an adult). It's open till 5.30pm and has a beautiful calm and peaceful setting inside in the heart of the bustling city. The stark contrast can be seen by the towering buildings being constructed outside. As soon as you come in you can feel the cool air under the canopy setup throughout the garden. They have a water stream encircling the whole garden and different lakes,ponds and a small waterfall spread around with the different beautiful and quiet settings where you can rest peacefully or spend time with people. There are different birds and fishes inside and different plants as well. They have interesting stuff to read along the way as well. You can rent some Chinese clothing inside if you are more involved. It's not your typical 'garden' so don't expect different exotic varieties of flora on display in order. It's a nice quaint ecosystem where you can relax and let your mind ease. It's definitely a place worth spending time at to take refuge from the scorching summer heat.
Peacefull and enjoyable. For once a nice place that was so busy when I went with friends visiting from the states. Nothing to complain about here.
Delight in Gardens. While staying with an Aunt we visited the Chinese Gardens many years ago and was delighted with the tranquil setting and atmosphere .
Tranquility in the City !. Not very large but beautifully laid out. You feel out of the rat race for a short while ! the girls in traditional costume really add to the atmosphere

Magical little oasis!. Beautiful tranquil gardens, Take the combined ticket and sit beside the water watching the giant gold fish while eating dim sum and Jasmine tea - so relaxing and peaceful escape from hectic life outside!
Enchanting. This is so beautiful to wander around, and there are so many different ways to view it. The food in the cafe is great too! :-)

A new year in Sydney. An excellent site. Very well kept and peaceful. The staff is very helpful. Try the costume shop where you can dress up in traditional costumes. You can do your own photos, or if you would like, they can do it for you. Check out the massive Koi fish.

Very special. The entry fee is negligible compared to what's on offer. This special place is unique and having been to Hong Kong, it was easy to imagine that I was there. There is a welcoming tea room with great scones etc and toilets on site. If you are feeling adventurous head to the costume hire and dress like an Emperor or his wife and walk amongst the gardens. The costs is $10 for adults and $5 for children. There are photo opportunities around every corner. There are regular guided tours by friendly English speaking guides. I hope that Sydney will support this location way into the future. It was a great escape from the hustle and bustle and definitely a place of friendship.

Chinese Garden of Friendship. Very pretty, calm space right in the heart of Sydney (next to Darling harbour). You can buy a ticket and then go in and out all day so you can time it to visit when they feed the fish.

Cute but has a few and hours of operation. We assumed this was an open park but the garden has gates, an entrance fee and unlisted hours of operation. First time we came was a fiasco- locked doors with no signage of any kind. We would not have gone back specifically but happened to be nearby again. It was cute but there are better things to do in Sydney.

Beautiful and interesting Chinese garden. This is a wonderful gem of a garden in the Darling Harbour district of Sydney and very close to the Chinatown. The entrance fee is very reasonable and you can spend as long as you like strolling the garden.The gardens are beautifully done in the Chinese style and they are many winding pathways and hidden features to see amidst the plants and trees set around a central lake.There is even a little tea/coffee ship where you can have a snack.The ambience here is very restful and it is a most pleasant way to while away a couple of hours if you want to escape the hustle and bustle of the city.
Serene heaven in packed Darling Harbour. Quiet , green and lush and so beautifully designed.Allowed us to relax in crowded area of Sydney Loved it!

Surprise. I am quite surprise there is this kind of garden in Sydney itself. I would say plants inside is take care off, but the buildings are not the best you can find. For foreigner who doesn't really know china and Chinese culture well, it will e fine and worthy to go. But you have been to china and then you might find the garden is a bit rough... But well, it you have plenty of time and have nothing to do, it still worth to visit.

Beautiful landscape . The garden's landscape is soo beautiful with cascades, waterfalls, koi fishpond, and nice steps with tracks. It's so peaceful you won't notice that you are in the middle of Sydney CBD.
Tip: Entrance for adults is only $6. They have tea or lunch packages.
Serene. Stumbled upon this little piece of paradise whilst visiting circular quay,absolutely beautiful and Definately worth a visit
Serene. A lovely oasis in the middle of Sydney. Beautiful landscaping and a true sense of calm. The carp in front of the entrance are amazing, huge and so colourful.

Oasis of calm in Sydney . This is the first Chinese Garden we have visited and it was a nice way to spent about an hour and a half. Lots of little paths with symbolic meaning and nice landscaping. For kids, finding all the sculptures that represent the Chinese Zodiac can be a bit of fun.

Your in the city but feel like your in another world. The work that is put into this place is amazing. As soon as you enter you forget that your in the city. You will be captured by everything around you. Make sure you keep your eyes peeled as you may see a few turtles, fish and lizards roaming the grounds
Just a short escape. When ever your in the city and you just want to gather yourself for just a little while , this is the place to go
Beautifully landscaped. This place though not so big was like a paradise. The plants and the flowers were so lovely and there's a big pond which complements everything in the garden.
Lovely. Great garden! A lovley place to spend time, both for the kids and the parents. Rented chinese costumes for the kids, and had a really good time.

Peace in the middle of Sydney. If you're visiting Sydney and you're a bit sick of the noise of the crowds this is the place to go. So peaceful with beautiful plants, waterfalls and lakes, and some quirky little coloured animal statutes if you look hard. So nice to stroll around and enjoy the peace which has been created by the Chinese.

Little well maintened garden. Near the Sidney's Chinatown and Darling recreational park, it´s a pretty nice small garden, fee $6, with a lot of different plants e small artificial lakes and cascades, with ducks, ibis and birds without been afraid of the humans visitors...

I'm giving it a five because my wife loved it. I was going to read the paper outside while my gardener wife toured the Chinese garden. She dragged me in, and it was a real island of serenity in the middle of the city, with construction cranes for the new convention center in the background on one side, and high rise buildings on the other. Just go there. It only costs $6 and you'll have awesome photo opps with the waterfalls, pagodas, ponds and rock structures.
Not bad. Worth a visit to kill a bit of time but only really worthwhile if you are an enthusiast. There are plenty of surrounding areas more suited to relaxing on a patch of grass

Take a peaceful Break from busy Sydney. If you're feeling kinda beat by rushing around everywhere to see what Sydney has to offer. have a think about stopping at the Chinese Garden of Friendship in the Darling Harbour quarter. This was a great couple of hours to just chill out, get a cuppa and re-charge ready for more sight-seeing. It is sublimely landscaped and in case your children get board there are costumes they can go and try on to act our their favourite parts from Crouching Tiger.

Transported to a different time and place... This garden is right next to the Tumbalong park and completely takes you to a different time and space. The way various plants and other objects have been set up in this garden are so quite unlike one sees anywhere outside makes this a fascinating place. Quite a lovely gift from the Chinese to Sydney.

Nice, clean and so calm. Nice big Chinese garden near the harbour. Your entry ticket is valid throughout the day (6 dollars only). Well organised, calm, tours possible too. Really a nice place to visit!
Lovely Oasis in the City. Very beautiful grounds. Nice place to take a break from walking around Darling Harbor. Try the Jasmine tea...the scones are a bit on the sweet side.

A Mystical Place. What a delightful find in the downtown hustle and bustle of Sydney. This Chinese garden just transports you to another time and place when you step foot through the gate. It is a bargain with the $6 entry fee. You can walk through on or own, or participate in a detailed tour by a very knowledgable guide that can explain many intricacies of the Chinese culture and how they are demonstrated in the garden itself.
A Peaceful Oasis in the City. Relaxing and peaceful amid the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Lovely gardens and water features with a real relaxed feel about the whole attraction s

Peaceful. A very pleasant place to visit, very calming. Would go back again just for the peace & serenity. We very rarely travel into the city as it can be a nightmare & stressful so visiting the gardens did help to calm us for the rest of our stay.

Sanctuary in the city. Very calm and soothing place to relax while still being in inner Sydney city. I love the place as it provides a excellent opportunity foe relaxing and rejuvenation.Must see if you are working nearby or visiting Sydney.

An Oasis in central Sydney. What a perfect location to retreat from the hustle and bustle of central Sydney.
A very peaceful, relaxing place to spend time just enjoying the gardens,waterfalls, paths, plants and fish.
Well worth a visit. Very peaceful. Staff friendly and helpful. Make sure you try the Yum Cha and tea. Good time out from Sydney hussle and bussle
Beautiful gardens!. Very nice gardens with nice flowers, trees, ponds....do not miss this little gem in hectic Sydney. It is absolutely worth a visit.

Relaxing oasis. This is a really nice place to stroll around looking at the beautiful gardens before stopping for some refreshments. Very friendly ducks will keep you company while you have something to eat.
Tranquility. An oasis in the middle of Sydney, a great spot to rest your weary legs and enjoy lunch or afternoon tea. We enjoyed sitting in the pagoda as a thunderstorm rolled through.
Beautiful place . Calm, beautiful place, perfect for relaxing. In the very middle of the city, which makes it stand out even more. Must-see

A Must to See. This relaxing and stimulating attraction is well worth the $6 day pass which can be utilised throughout the day. The paths are well laid out and you can wander up amongst the rock and waterfall areas giving panoramic views.There is a kiosk area overloooking the various lily ponds . This was the highlight of our trip.

Beautiful garden. This is a beautiful, tranquil oasis in the middle of a bustling city, could have easily spent hours there enjoying the wildlife and plants or with a book enjoying the peace and quiet.

Peaceful place. It's peaceful sanctuary amidst CBD and there's a teahouse for evening tea. You can take picture using old dynasty costume too. But it's basically just a very beautiful garden and there's a charge to enter the place. It will be better if it's free

Chinese Garden of Friendship. Came across this place by accident when walking to Paddys Market . Really glad we went in as such a lovely quiet little place with lovely chinese buildings and horticulture . A definate good find and well worth a visit .

Beautiful and not expensive. The garden is absolutely beautiful, and cheap to get into. It cost $6 for an adult and $3 for a student which was a welcome change from the outrageous prices charged by tourist places in Sydney.
If you are on that side of the CBD it is a must see.

Lovely day out. I took a group of students to the gardens. As they are teenagers there were a few moans befoe we got there that they might be bored looking at 'plants and things', however all of them walked out having discovered a little oasis of calm in the middle of the city. Some have even said that they will be bringing their parents back. From my perspective they are very reminiscent of gardens that I visited in China. A great way to while away a few hours
Serenity in the heart of the city. These gardens are so beautiful it's hard to leave. The koi are huge and obviously well cared for, such an oasis in the big metropolis of Sydney. Well worth a look.

Gem in the city. I've been here a number of times.The garden is interesting and varied.Stunning oasis set right in the city, in the heart of Darling Harbour.As you walk through the stress melts away. We chose the entry fee "with café" option- lovely tea and scones for very little more than the modest entry cost all eaten while on a lovely terrace overlooking the gardens.Even in the drizzle we took lots of photos as it seemed every angle held a new view.Wheelchair/Pram access could prove difficult in some areas due to steps.

Perfect place to relax. We spent a lesurely hour or so wandering around these beautiful gardens. The beautiful fish pond fish are amazing & watching them being fed is a great experience. Great location, close to Darling Harbour and a must see in my book.Highly recommended.. It's like entering another world :)

Nice location in Sydney. The Chinese garden is close to Darling Harbour in Sydney, and offers a peek into the gardens that can be found in China. The garden offers a varity views to serveral water, plant and other elemants. It is also posslbe to have lunch / drinkd in the restaurant.

Beautiful. I liked that it is very well designed, beautiful, scenic park located in the CBD. That it charges a nominal fee to enter and peruse the gardens so that any one is able to enter and enjoy the garden.
walking distance. Short walk from Holiday Inn hotel Darling Harbour. Peaceful inner city retreat, culture and gardens lovely. cheap entry fee.
A PEACEFUL HAVEN IN A BUSY CITY. What a find. Quiet, beautiful gardens. Tranquility at its best.Sit down and enjoy the tasty delights and pot of tea at the cafe.
Tranquil Oasis. At the end of Darling Harbour the Chinese Gardens were an absolute delight. The hustle and bustle around you ceases to exist in this very special place.

Retreat in the heart of the city. I love to visit the Chinese Garden of Friendship in Sydney, it is always good to see how the garden is developing. I remember visiting when it had first been planted and now I see the maturing of the trees and areas as the gardens come of age. There are plenty of places to sit and ponder and take time out. A beautiful combination of water, plants and interesting walks meander thru the area. Worth a visit.

Peaceful change of scenery. This was a very pleasant surprise. We really enjoyed the break from the busy city and noise. It was very reasonably priced and the kids enjoyed the "scavenger hunt" that is in place. It was great to be outside in the lovely gardens on a beautiful day.

Nice place and cheap to visit. Very relaxing and beautiful. Went to China Town for a nice Lunch then walked to The Chinese Garden. Have been there be4 three years ago. It is a beautiful place to just walk around or sit and watch the scenery including the large sized Carp of all colours. Well worth a visit, then continue walking alon Darling Harbour to make a nice day. We also went to the Wax Museum, Madam Toussad's and have written a review on that.

Stepping into another world.... I've lived in Sydney for 14 years now and not once visited here. I've always known about it but until today was the first time with my partner.It is an amazing place to visit. Stepping into another world from the craziness / face pace of the city.We just wandered around the entire garden in total peace and tranquility for a good 1.5 hours then had a lovely milkshake in the cafe inside the gardens and was mesmerised by the waterfall :)If you are into this kind of thing you must visit, it's definitely worth it :)
A great spot to re-group. While visiting Chinatown, we took a stroll through this beautiful garden in the middle of the city. It was incredibly peaceful and relaxing. Highly recommended!

Worth a visit. This is an inexpensive way to spend an afternoon in the CBD in Sydney and it definitely takes you away from the bustle of the city. Not a must do, but certainly worth a visit if you are around Darling Harbour and you have a couple of hours to spare!

peaceful oasis in middle of busy city. My second visit to this beautiful place, I highly recommend spending some down time here instead of running around Darling Harbour, Chinatown or Paddy's Markets.Minimal entry fee and you can come & go as many times you want the same day.Interesting features to read about, find out about the Chinese calendar and what the animals are supposed to signify. Spot the lizards in the gardens, there are some big ones there. Spend some time staring at the water features or the koi, walk up the hill and admire the view.Shame when there is noisy shows on just outside, ruins the peace of the garden.If you don't get something out of this garden you are just tight with your money (complaining about having to pay to get in - there is a lot of maintenance required for the upkeep) and have lost touch with part of yourself. Highly recommended!
Tranquil. A lovely place to escape the hustle and bustle of city life. Will visit again when I'm next in Sydney

Welcome respite. This tucked away garden is a restful place in a busy noisy city. Beautifully constructed and maintained with lots of photo opportunities. Tea and scones delicious - and great value if bought at ticket purchase time.

Just beautiful. A lovely place for the whole family. Beautiful plants, waterfalls and delicious food too. My husband and I enjoyed the peacefulness while my son enjoyed climbing on the rocks and looking at the fish. Definitely a place I'd like to revisit.
Lovely. If this is a small glimpse into what China has to offer I want to go there. Such a beautiful place to sit and slow down for a while.

Looks nice through the gaps in the wall...but.... ...they charge you entry now, and to be honest, there is not enough of interest (personally speaking) to make it worth the entry fee. Just my opinion!

Most relaxing and beautiful garden. The entrance fee is $6 for adults, worth it ! it's cheap for the time you can spend in this lovely garden, which have a large pond, a waterfall, many little chinese buildings, and even dragons !If you get there on a special time like I did, you can have a free guided visit, which lasts about 30 minutes. It was very interesting and the guide was funny and nice. I had a lovely time, too many pictures and wish I had brought a picnic with me to spend more time in this garden. You can also eat at the small restaurant there, or have a drink facing the beautiful pond full of koi fish...

great for a lunchtime break. a peaceful place filled with the sound of running water with the contrasting hustle & bustle of the towering urban skyline.maybe spend an hour taking in the different flora and oriental constructions.the only downside was the inaccessible upper level of the garden for buggys and wheelchairs.
Peace in the city. What a wonderful place to sit, relax and contemplate. Hard to believe this oasis is surrounded by tall city buildings.
Perfect for read a newspaper :). Nice and quiet place, ideal for relaxing conversations ! Sunbathing, easy to get, close to China town!
Inner City Zen. Love this place, absolutely breathtaking, take a book or a picnic lunch give yourself time to explore :)

Zen. This was a hidden gem located close to the buzzing Darling Harbor. There was a $6 fee charge but it was well worth the money. It was wonderful to just sit on the benches and gaze at the waters, mini waterfalls and the pagodas. A good place to just be zen after a long day.
