Hidden gem. Well worth a visit. Large Chinese garden of peace just next to the city.Spend time and sit and relax in one of the many building. You can even hire costumes great place for pictures this s China in Australia.
Kids adventure playground. This playground is fantastic for kids - the waterway channels kept them amused for hours. Great playground equipment, well spaced for big & little kids alike.

A City Gem. This was an unexpected corner of colour and vision in a big city. The staff were very knowledgeable and helpful. The only reason I can't give it an 'excellent' is because of the large number of school children there, some of which just seemed to want to run around the pathways ignoring the fact there were other people there too.

Friendship Garden. This is a beautiful place and truly a gem in downtown Sydney. It is so peaceful and its asian inspired architecture and design will blow you away. This is also a backdrop in many big movies in the last 5 year too!

Tranquil and lovely. We almost didn't visit because we were running out of time in Sydney but I'm so glad we took the time to slow down and enjoy the peacefulness and beauty of this lovely, traditional Ming garden.

beautiful. my friends and I visited these beautiful gardens on a girls trip to Sydney
Despite the traffic along side they were very quiet and relaxing
We got dressed up in traditional costume for $10 each
A lot of fun and some amazing pictures
I highly recommend this garden

Wow.. I had seen the website for this place before visiting Sydney and had set my mind on going, my boyfriend had been sceptical. However, when we got through to gate into the gardens, it took my breath away. There was so much beauty and tranquility hidden away in there from the busy city surrounding (don't get me wrong you can still see the occasional sky scraper) but I fell in love with the place. It was stunning, slightly magical we found it really. So as you can probably tell (haha) - worth the money in my eyes. We could have happily stayed all day.

Chinese Garden Even Wolverines Been. The Chinese gardens in Darling harbour was donated by the Chinese government to celebrate Australia's Bi-Centenary in 1988. It's a little oasis, in the heart of the city, with tea rooms. Those of you who watched the last Wolvervine movie, staring former Sydney sider Hugh Jackman, part of the movie was filmed in the gardens.

tranquillity in the city. The gardens are a respite from the bustle of Sydney - adjacent to Darling Harbour and China Town, the gardens provide rest and tranquillity. A time to 'take time out' and simply forget the world and be.

Gorgeous. We try to get to this area every time we have a short break in Sydney. Well set out for walking and a million miles away from the hustle and bustle of the city, even though geographically it's only a short distance away. Very tranquil and lots to look at.

Beautiful. It was a lovely one and a half hour stroll around a beautifully laid out garden with lots of water areas and plenty of flora. Lovely areas for resting and enjoying the scenery. Strongly recommend it

Calm in a sea of hustle bustle. This is my second visit to Sydney. Last time I spotted the Chinese Garden of Friendship after closing time. This time I was afraid I wouldn't get there again but had an hour till my ride to the airport and it was very close to my hotel so I ran over. Ever so glad I did. This is a magnificent Chinese garden. (Very similar to one in downtown Portland, OR, USA). It is beautiful, serene and in October it smelled great too. In some places in the garden you would never know you are in a bustling city like Sydney. In other locations you can see the tall buildings looming overhead. As I said I only had an hour so didn't read much about the garden and the various venues inside. The few I did read were similar to the garden in Portland. I think this is a must see in Sydney.

Take a book rest and read an hour or two. Quiet, beautiful retreat in the middle of the city. Plenty of places to sit and read in a beautiful setting, meditate, or just enjoy the tranquil garden and ponds.

An oasis of calm in the city. This very pleasant garden has a variety of Chinese architectural features with lakes and plenty of birds and fish. Also a cafe. Nice for a relaxing stroll and a sit down away from the busy streets.
Tiny but cute. It's a quick walk until you have completed a circle but we sat down and really spent time in there enjoying the peaceful surroundings. Was cute but probably wouldn't go again.
So peaceful. So glad I went. Love wandering through gardens. This was something different. So tranquil. Excellent photo opportunities. Would go again if I went to Sydney.

Super relaxing. Went here in September, in not the best wether, with a few new friends that I had made in my hostel. Strange how peaceful and serene these gardens feel in the middle of the cbd. Lovely way to kills few hours, and very reasonably priced. Definitely worth a few hourson a sunny afternoon.

Great Family Fun. A beautiful serene day out inthe heart of sydney. Tranquil gardens, Fish feeding and dressups for all. Food is nothing to write home about, but that's the only thing that let's this place down.

Lovely peaceful gardens. Small but big enough to spend time wandering and soaking up the views. Good photo opportunities. When we were there lots of visitors had taken the opportunity to hire the classic Chinese costumes on offer in order to get even more authentic photos.

serene setting in Sydney. I thought this was a nicely done Chinese water garden near Darling Harbour. Very low-key, and you can have a bite to eat or drink in a nice setting. Some great photos. Great place to relax.
Not a venue for someone who likes more activity going on, they may find it a bit boring.

spiritually chinese. we were blown away by this attraction you can't believe its in the middle of a city, with its mature gardens, statues, ponds and pagodas and all for $3:00 also a chance to find 12 0f the animals of the chinese year see if you can find yours,you can sit in the grounds or sample original chinese tea and relax, well worth a visit for a couple of hours while your're in Sydney,

Priceless!!. A beautiful celebration of friendship. We have visited many Chinese gardens, both in China and North America - this one ranks up there with them - it can only get better as the plantings mature. A must do - just a short walk from Town Hall Station.

Beautiful escape from the city. Loved it here! So peaceful, quiet, with beautiful surroundings! Walked around here for about an hour and a half, taking photos and just relaxing! What a beautiful representation of Chinese culture in Sydney!

Lovely oasis in the middle of the city. Very beautiful and peaceful. Lovely photo opportunities but bring your own camera. The dress up photo ops are pricey. The food isnt much, toilet facilities OK for the middle of the city. It was a lovely peaceful restful visit during a busy day in the city.
Little piece of peace. Small but lovely. Nice little pretty escape in a busy metropolitan. very beautiful great place to go if you just want to chill and or think/ clear your mind :)

Amazingly beautiful gardens escaping the city buzz . Beautiful and tranquil, these gardens are a terrific way to escape the city buzz. Visit on a sunny day and you will get amazing photos. Entry is $6/$3 for adult or concession. Tours run throughout the day however in my opinion is probably best enjoyed with a solo stroll. Expect the entire garden to take about 45 minutes including a few photos. Great experience that I would recommend!
Peace in central Sydney. Had a lovely relaxing stroll around here one Sunday afternoon. Such an oasis of calm and serenity in the centre of a bustling city. You should go at least once in your life.

Beautiful. We only had a hour here but would have loved to have stayed longer. So peaceful and quiet. Beautiful place to take a book and park under a tree for a few hours. Prices were excellent but unfortunately we didn't have time for tea, would definitely visit again.
yeh ok. I thought this place would be better , because it had such a built up to it , no need to go back, it was pretty much the same when I saw it 10 years ago

A beautiful place. These gardens are beautiful and def worth a visit. We enjoyed walking around this garden admiring the flowers, trees and lake/waterfalls. A quiet and peaceful place in darling harbour. Def worth a visit to appreciate this beautiful space..

Chinese Gardens. Went into the Chinese gardens for my birthday.We thought it would just be a quick walk around BUT we ended up spending over 1 hour in there.It is really beautiful and you would not know you are in the middle of the city.
Good with guide . Very nice place, but better with the guide explanations. Otherwise you can't understand well the garden structure. And it's not so long, and not so expensive. Good time!

Beautiful gardens. Because we visited in Spring there were a lot of trees with blossoms just coming out. Around every corner there was a new vista opened up to view. It was a very pleasant way to spend the morning in the heart of busy Sydney. Very tranquil.

Peacefull. We stayed at Meriton on Kent St, and walked out and down to Darling Harbour and found this beautiful Chinese gardens to walk through. It was really pretty with the Chinese symbols to find,we had a great morning here.
Oasis in the heart of Sydney!. Quiet, tranquil place to explore in the middle of Sydney CBD. Nice fountains & landscaping to walk around.... a little piece of ancient China in the heart of Sydney!

Tradition and aesthetics. this is a wonderful place to pass an hour in Sydney. I took a camera and tried to photograph the dragon flies that danced jerkily around the ponds. Some visitors dressed in traditional Chinese costumes and enormous carp shouldered their way through the lily pads.

So relaxing!. This place is awesome. Right in the heart of the city and close to Darling Harbor is this retreat to go relax and enjoy the scenery and koi. It was quiet when we went and I took some outstanding pics. For 6 a person, it was cheap and one of the best things we did in Sydney. You only need 1-2 hours and you will love it. I loved the bonsai trees in the beginning and the layout is great with informative markers. Very serene
Best 3 Dollars ever spent. This place is totally worth it, is one of the most beautiful places in Sydney. If you are a student is only 3 dollars!

A little oasis from the busy walk. Enjoyed the quiet and tranquil part of the garden, great for a little rest and reflection on the way to the Darling Harbour. I found the architecture and water features interesting. Definitely with a stop there.

Tranquility aware from the hustle and bustle. While it was raining I decided to still head to the gardens and glad that I did. I took a moment to have morning tea on the terrace inside, with the breathtaking views that the garden had to offer. By this stage the rain had stopped and I pretty much had the gardens to myself. The gardens are well organised, with a self guiding map given as part of the $6 entry. The plants, structures, birds and rocks all were intriguing, and was lovely to be able to contemplate the beauty while reading the little plagues. This was one of my favourite things that I did during my one day in Sydney.

Chinese Gardens, Sydney. We were very impressed with these gardens. They were very big with lots of areas to explore, Our home City, Dunedin in NZ has a very similar one, however ours is a lot smaller. I believe these two Gardens have been made by the same Chinese people as there are parts that are very similar. it is well worth going to visit,
wow. This beautiful garden , so tranquil in the middle of the busy Sydney Darling Harbour was such a surprise and a place you just want to sit and appreciate. I loved it

A Touch of Serenity. Serene beauty in the heart of the city where you can also enjoy a cup of green tea and some dumplings. It's a small area but jam packed with peace...a gift to Sydney that just keeps on giving!

Tranquil Sanctury. We Love this place. So Tranquil and beautiful. Low cost and must see place.
The Emperors quest kept the little one entertained the whole time searching through the garden. And they provide the parents with the answers making it easy and pleasurable for all.

Nice. This is a beautiful little gem, very peaceful and quiet. However it is a lot smaller then I had been lead to believe and in my opinion a little over priced. Worth it though if you're looking for ways to use up your ozy dollars at the end of a trip.

A tranquil place. This charming oasis near busy Darling Harbour is the perfect place to stop, sit, wander and ponder. It is well worth paying the small entry fee to walk around the pathways, beside the water and under the trees. The brochure and the display panels in the garden provide information about the various structures, the plants and the garden features. On the day we visited a number of visitors had paid to hire Chinese costumes and seeing these 'dressed-up' characters walking among the shrubbery added to the charm. It's definitely worth a visit!

Hidden Gem. A brilliant garden well maintained with well landscaped areas and waterfalls. Some of the pathways are slightly hilly however plenty of areas that are flat for older people. Fantastic plants - great little place.

Beautiful garden. Very tranquil and relaxing garden. And worth the visit we enjoyed ourselves and took heaps of photos. And we dressed up and walked the gardens looking very Chinese, that is a must getting dressed up, the owner is very friendly and helpful for an extra 10$. It made the gardens fun and enjoyable.
A taste of China.. It is a good place to relax just down the road from the hotels. Nice chinese pagodas and ponds gives you a feeling of China , also Chinatown iks nearby.

Rude gardener. Took my Chinese friend here today Wednesday , as we were walking on the foothpath around a rude staff member who was apparently one of their Gardeners shouted " move move out of my way,he then started swearing.I will lodge a complaint about his conduct .Apart from that it was very enjoyable,you can hire costumes for 10 dollars to wear around.Cheap entry fee too.
Well worth a visit!. A beautiful escape in the middle of the city. The garden is amazing. $5 entry for an adult but we paid $11 for entry, tea and dim sims.
Paradise. We loved the Chinese Gardens. We wandered and relaxed there. It was a paradise in a busy city. We enjoyed a lovely morning tea in the little tea rooms there. Thoroughly recommend.

A peaceful haven in the middle of the city. We loved this place. It is so well laid out and has a really "zen" feel about it. There is plenty to see with a surprise around every corner. Well worth the cost of entry. A great place to escape your everyday concerns and just enjoy nature and peace.
Very Peaceful. Can highly recommend a visit here was very relaxing after a long day sight seeing. We paid the little extra so we could sit, relax and have a cup of tea and scones. Lovely!

So Serene and Peaceful. When we visited the garden, we planned maybe spending an hour, tops. But we ended up lingering for maybe three hours, exploring the different sections and searching for the cute Chinese zodiac creatures that were scattered throughout the garden. The architecture and landscaping is superb, with every single aspect perfectly designed to be beautiful from every perspective. The sound of running water from the lake and waterfalls cut through all the city noise, to the point where you forgot you were even in the city. The koi in the lake were fabulous too - one of them kept leaping out of the water! We also had pork buns and oolong tea at the little cafe on site, which was lovely. It was nice to be given a choice of different Chinese teas, rather than just one.The only negative I can think of was how many people had scratched their names into the bamboo.
Good memories. We visited 10 years ago and it seemed just the same,we even tried to take photos in exactly the same place, very peaceful, and then we stayed for fireworks.

tranquil place in the heart of Sydney. This is one of my favourite places in Darling Harbour. It is so peaceful, a nice escape from the city. The place is very well maintained and surprisingly quiet despite the busy surroundings. The little tiles of information and history is also very interesting.
Quiet escape. This is honestly one of the most beautiful and peaceful places in Sydney. Once you enter yhe gates the noise of the city and the busy pace just melts away.
different. interesting to poke around in for an hour but beware if you loathe reptiles as there are a few goannas around the place

Probably the best place to visit in Sydney. I can't believe my eyes when i stepped inside. Its like a totally different place that i was in. It looks small from the outside but there are just so much to see inside. Very quiet and calming place. Really recommended!

A wonderful escape from the city throng. You could walk around this park in perhaps 5-10 minutes and grumble about the skyscrapers. But that would be doing it entirely the wrong way.For a surprisingly small fee, you can buy an entry ticket with a cafe voucher that will get you some dim sims and a hot green tea. Step 1: Go the cafe first (counter-clockwise from the entrance), order your dimmys then relax for a while in the Teahouse outdoor dining area while you soak up the atmosphere.Step 2: Retrace your steps (clockwise) past the entrance and head up to the costume hire chamber. For just $10 you will be dressed in a rather impressive costume from one of two classic dynasties, whereupon you will be seated and photographed (with your own camera) aplenty. Step 3: Wear the costume for the remainder of your visit, wandering clockwise around the gardens, taking the side-paths were available, while discovering the myriad delights. Be sure to get some other tourists to take your selfies for you!Step 4: Return your costume, tip generously, and think about how wonderful it is to find such a treat in the midst of this bustling city.
Place to relaxe. The Chinese Garden, close to Darling harbor is a good place to escape the hustle and bustle of the big city. There is also a nice Cafe for lunch or just a cool drink.

Wonderful garden. If you are going to China Town then don't miss the Chinese Garden of Friendship. It is not directly in China town but just a very short walk towards Darling Harbour. Best plan would be to go to Darling Harbour for a few hours then walk to the Chinese Friendship Garden for a visit then continue on the China Town for a great Chinese banquet or Dim Sim.
A Scantury within Darling Harbour. A little quiet gem within the city. Great place to escape for a cup of tea and a stroll. An entrance fee is charged but hey, someone's gotta maintain the place.

If your looking for peace in a busy city then this is it. The Chinese garden of friendship was a recommendation from a friend that I should visit if I got time, well I'm glad I did it it a place that you carnt discribe on there than saying this is a beautiful place, I have not been to china yet but this visit wants me to explore the Chinese culture all the more, the views here are out of this world and it's so peaceful I would recommend this attraction to anyone visiting Sydney and I will visit again before I leave Australia, ITS A MUST !!!!
Good place to spend 1 - 2 hours. A nice garden within the city. Kids will love to find the Chinese calendar icons. We loved this place.

I JUST COULD NOT GET ENOUGH THE BEST!!!!. The best $6.00 l spent on this trip, a place that you could never imagine exists from the moment you walk in to the last track you take, a view never to be forgotten. I took about 350 photos because it was amazing. The animals, the exotic fish, the Chinese Dragons that wander around the gardens. the water falls, the rockery the ducks fluttering in the ponds, amazing a must see adventure. If you go get the $11.00 deal you get scones with jam and cream and coffee, and they have a best tea garden which overlooks the entire gardens. I must say l found it so hard to leave, it was peaceful, tranquil and all you hear is how over whelmed people are with this place A MUST SEE IF YOU ARE AT DARLING HARBOUR.

Worth a visit. Such a great, peaceful place right in the middle of the city. For $6, it's totally worth a visit and somewhere I bring anyone who comes to visit Sydney. The gardens are beautiful, well looked after and it's a bit surreal to see the buildings in the background. You can get some great pictures. I've never really spent more than half an hour here though - beautiful, but not really somewhere you need a great deal of time to see.
Nice to see. This is such a great, tranquil place in the heart of such a busy city, it is beautiful to see and spend some time strolling through.

Serene, sublime and surreal. This is somewhere we try to get to every visit to Sydney. We love that you are in the core tourist district of one of the largest Cities in Australia and you can be forgiven for expecting the cast of Monkey or Crouching Tiger to fly through the bamboo or stalk around the lake.We took the half hour tour this last time - it's free and we highly recommend it to learn more about the creation of the garden and the meaning behind some of it's features.If we worked close by - this would be where we would come for lunch or time out every day!If you are bringing your family - take the plunge and dress up in traditional costume for your time here - corny and funny but still worth it!If you are lucky, you'll get to see one of the many weddings the gardens host as well.

Peaceful and charming. I love this place! You feel like you are in China as soon as you step inside. Great value for money. There is also a brilliant tea room overlooking the water, I highly recommend
very quiet place. A good place to reflect and have some meditation. It is very quiet place at the same time lots of nice plants and flower.
chinese garden of friendship. The chinese gardenof friendship is situated along darling harbour stroll. It has trees and bamboos with beautiful flowers. Enjoyable and memorable

Solitude in the city. Best $6 we spent. Right in the heart of the 'hustle & bustle' of the city, the Chinese garden offers a little bit of solitude. So pretty & calming. For any photographers out there (professional or amateur), this is the perfect backdrop for photos.

BLISSFUL SERENITY. This place is an absolute joy - tranquil oasis in the heart of the bustling City. Well designed and well looked after, it offers you peaceful and relaxing time, whether you choose to stroll, or just sit in one of beautiful gazebos, or have a tea in traditional tea house. ENJOY!
chinese garden of friendship. It is a very peaceful place where you can take a quiet walk and have a relaxing time. I definitely recommend a visit to everyone
Chinese garden of Friendship. The garden is serence, calm and clean with trees, bamboos and wildflowers. It is free and a good tour for the traveller
A peaceful oasis!. This was a lovely tranquil place to visit in the middle of a busy city. There was still a lot to see despite it being Winter. I loved watching the fish and the ducklings .

Top Garden. I was really beautiful and tranqil - one of the best Chinese Gardens I have visited. It is hard to believe this peaceful and beautiful place is right in a noisy city. Loved the waterfalls and the Tea Garden too.
Many nice places.. It remind me of home and they do a nice place to see pagoda and water. You can relax and not hear cars but nice garden in middle of city.

Pretty and peaceful. This is such a lovely attraction in Sydney. It is a very pretty, tranquil oasis in the middle of a very busy city area. It is inexpensive and very good value for money. We spent over an hour walking through the gardens and there are some beautiful places to take pictures.
Peacefull and Beautiful Gardens. Have been a couple of times, they are so tranquil and a pleasure to wander through, stop as you please, amazing fish.

Very beautiful. The garden is a great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of Sydney. It is a very peaceful place where you can take a quiet walk and have a relaxing time. I definitely recommend a visit to everyone

great place to spend a day. I wasn't a huge fan of Sydney and all the construction and swarming tourists - as someone else suggested this is really a nice oasis. i was lucky to stumble onto a tour and i truly heart my tour guide!

Chinese culture in Sydney. When visitors land on Sydney, it is very strange to see that almost 60% of the population of Sydney is of Chinese origin. Sydney is mini China town. At Darling Harbour you can visit a special cultural place Chinese Garden of friendship and enjoy it in Sydney. Near to garden there is China town market (Paddy's Market) which is of typical of Chinese style.

Serene magic in the city. Having watched this garden develop since its beginnings in 1988, it is a delight to enjoy it now - with saplings grown to full shady trees and the vision of its builders fully realised. Right in the heart of bustling downtown city Sydney, the Chinese garden is like a Shangri La dream - and its visitors seem to treat it that way: quiet, contemplative and happy to be there. A lovely, unexpected oasis to be savoured as quintessentially Australian - because it's of another culture altogether!

Absolutely gorgeous.. I had walked past the Chinese Garden of Friendship many times on my journey from Darling Harbour to Paddy's Markets but had never ventured in until now. Wow, the garden is beautiful! What a lovely way spend a few hours - it is hard to believe you are so close to the city! Make sure you take your camera, the photo opportunities are endless.

Oasis in the middle of the City. You need to pay something like 6$ but you've a really good Chinese garden, you should ask when the guide is making a free tour so you can join him and enjoy and understand more each particular of the garden.
Beautiful!. These gardens are incredibly peaceful considering their location. Absolutely stunning, i've been here twice now!

Very relaxing,a must. After having time in Sydney at xmas'13-14 new year i was dissapointed that we never made it to see this garden so,i just returned at the end of July & i took my two daughters both 16 & it was so worth the entry fee!!! The gardens & wildlife are not to be missed simply stunning,& to be situated in the middle of bustling Darling Harbour is mind blowing. Whilst strolling around in the garden paths you really do feel like your in china with the rocks,water falls/features,massive koi fish & not to mention the several sml to quite lge lizards sunning them selves & wondering around making for excellent photographs? From the entry,staff to the exit it is amazing & a definate must see we loved it!!!!!!

A Gem. What a Jewel in the Crown for Sydney truly a Magical Oasis.Tranquil, peaceful watching the Lizards sunbathing by the pond ... You can even dress up in Traditional Chinese costume & have a photoshoot.
Serene. So beautiful and quiet you forget that you are in central Sydney. Well worth the $6, and you can easily spend a few hours taking it all in. Would recommend their tea and scones to go with it!

Dress up a little. Gorgeous use of space. Best of all for children is that they can dress up as emperors and empresses for 5 dollars a piece. Once in their costumes, they can wander the gardens pretending to be the owners.
Beautiful. The gardens are really lovely, with lots of water features and lots of photo ops. Really peaceful experience in the heart of busy Darling Harbour.
Great place to visit. Lovely peaceful place to visit .Nice gardens and waterfalls . Well worth the admission fee and some great photo oppertunities
Beautiful Landscape Amoungst The City. For $8.00 this is definitely worth a look if you enjoy Asian culture. Great photo opportunities throughout the garden!

An oasis in the city. This was such a serene place to walk around, the gardens are set out in a beautiful layout making the walk around quite easy some if the uneven surfaces where a bit difficult for my 85 yo mother but we managed to make it all the way around the cafe on the water at the end was lovely, we plan to go back in Spring for another visit to see the garden in flower.

Calming and Peaceful. A lovely place to relax and wander around any time of year. The gardens are simply stunning with water falls, koi ponds and many oriental-style plantings and sculptures. I will be visiting every chance I get to see the seasonal changes and soak up the calming vibes.
Peaceful way to start the day. Beautiful Chinese Gardens that are a delight to walk around. Well kept, quiet and away from the hustle and bustle of city life. Time to reflect.

returned visit. We enjoyed our last so much we decided to go back after a few years and one thing my daughter loved was feeding the fish. We came back today and found out they stopped this experience which upset my daughter. If I had known they had stopped this we would not of gone

Really nice experience. This was the second time I visited the Chinese Gardens and was not disappointed. The gardens are well worth a visit while in Sydney. The gardens are very tranquil and give plenty of photo opportunities.
Tranquil Escape in a Busy City. What a wonderful place to visit to escape the everyday city hustle and bustle. One could take a book and easily be transported back in time.

Absolutely lovely. We visited these gardens on a Sunday and had a lovely time. It is amazing how quiet and zen it can be while so close to the CBD. We spent a good 2-3 hours wandering around and we also dressed up for an additional feeq which was just so fun! It is totally worth the $6 entry as the plants themselves would be quite expensive and you can see it is well maintained. The staff are really lovely and help you take photos (bring a good camera). If I lived in Sydney I would be here weekly!!
Beautiful little oasis. Such a surprise find in this busy city,a peaceful delight amidst the sky scrapers. Do try and fit in a visit amongst all the other wonderful sights in Sydney .

In winter this was very good (imagine in summer its outstanding). Very nice walk through the garden in winter (late July) and there were still plants in bloom which was very nice. I imagine that in summer when everything is leafed out and blooming that this garden is enchanting. It's a short set of walks so take your time and contemplate the views. The tea and scones at the end was nice, so get the multi-ticket that includes the snack.
to relax. A garden really well put together, a really good place to relax and enjoy. Just outside darling harbour, very close to nice and cheap places to eat. Cheaper entry fee for students

Truly beautiful garden. Felt rejuvenated after spending time there. Of all the tourist attractions we visited while in Sydney, the Chinese Garden of Friendship was truly one of the most memorable and enjoyable stops. The entry price was too good for the peaceful ambience and beautiful up-keeping required. While the Garden looks small on the map, it is quite big inside. We easily spent 2+ hours walking through the trailwalk and checking out the ponds. Before exiting, we bought some tea and buns from the cafe. It was one of the best and "authentic" buns I've ever had. The staff was very lovely too. Quite simply, we had the best of times at the Garden, and will definitely visit over and over again everytime we're in Sydney.
Tranqil place.. When you had enough walking the city stop over in Darling Harbor at these nice gardens and lakes. Also pagodas.Just sit and chill out from all the walking here , so peaceful.
Beautiful calm respite. Was astounded by how lovely this garden is. Even though the garden is in the centre of Darling Harbour it is calm and beautiful. We'll worth the six dollar entry.
Interesting. Interesting and a lovely place to walk around, could quite easily spend several hours there. Easy access for everyone.

Not to be missed. This garden is an excellent point of reference for the mix that is Sydney and if you're a gardener, not to be missed. Built for the 1988 Bicentennial, it was a gift by businessman of Chinese background to their fellow citizens, a wonderful gesture. Much of the work was carried out by craftsmen from China. Being in the heart of a huge city, you'd expect noise and chaos. However, this is a place of beauty and peace. It doesn't take all that long to walk around the lake and garden but it would be to miss the point if that's all you do. There are many places to sit, observe and think. The garden has been built with all the traditions of Chinese landscaping present. The seas, mountains, rivers, islands are all there as well as a picturesque cascade. Most of the traditional plants have been included and I assume those missing are only because of climate restrictions. The lake is, as usual, the centre piece and it has been beautifully constructed and surrounded by many traditional built features; dragon wall, moongate, pavilions, bridges and the zig-zag bridge necessary to stop evil spirits. There are many koi, some are particularly beautiful. The stand of black bamboo is spectacular. There is a fine display of penjing (bonsai) as well as a cafe. Admission price is really quite reasonable. Before or after, its a quick walk to the rest of the Chinese section of Sydney with its many restaurants. To me, this place gives meaning to the old Chinese saying, "If you want to be happy for an hour, get drunk; if you want to be happy for a month, get married; If you want to be happy forever, build a garden."
quiet oasis. This is a lovely place to get away from the noise and crowds at darling harbour. There are some lovely plans and water gardens and cute little bridges. Lovely to walk around
Tranquility in the city. Lovely place to 'lose' yourself,Peaceful and tranquil.Lovely place for a wedding.A short walk from the restaurants of Chinatown.

A slice of paradise. This oasis is far more than you expect from the outside. We had a young guide who explained the garden as we walked through. I now understand far more about Chinese gardens and why they are set out as they are. A beautiful, beautiful place.
Beautiful oasis of tranquility in a bustling city. Stunning photo opportunities and a chance to sample chinese tea in the cafe. A wonderful area of calm at a fair admission cost.

Completely under rated!. This really is a beautiful oasis of calm in the middle of a busy metropolis. I love the creativity and calm of a chinese garden anyway but this really transported you to another world. It is small but you can spend a few hours relaxing and drinking up the tranquility of this place. A lot of planning and hard work has obviously gone into building and maintaining this venue and it really is something to be proud of, I cant describe the feeling of the place you just have to visit! Small fee for entrance.We also got to dress up in traditional chinese royalty robes for a small fee, definitely worth doing for the laugh and the photos.Do take half an hour at the end of your visit to sit and relax in the tea house,

City Retreat. Conveniently in the centre of the city. A place to rest from shopping through all the local markets in the area. Great place to take overseas visitors. Tranquil gardens with photo ops around every corner.. It's great value and very pretty, a nice way to spend a Sunday afternoon with friends.I will return over and over.

Sanctuary nestled in a busy city. Ive visited a few times and it still blows me away how stunning this garden is.And the fact that its right in the middle of the CBD yet still retains its oriental charm!! A must see for a cheap but incredible sydney experience! Plus for an added cost you can dress in traditional costumes and walk around the gardens to get photos in them!

Serenity. A beautiful place set in the middle of a bustling city. This is a highlight on many of my trips to Sydney. My partner and I walked through here mid afternoon on a clear and sunny winter's day last week. If you don't look at the buildings that surround the gardens, you certainly feel like you're in China. We spent close to 2 hours here, casually strolling through the gardens and getting plenty of photos. There is a tea house inside as well which adds to the peacefulness of the garden. This is a great place to come and unwind from a stressful day for a small fee. But worth every cent!
Quiet Oasis. A beautiful, quiet space in the middle of a busy city. There was something interesting around every corner. Staff on the door were very professional. Terrific place for photos.
Serenity. This place is beautiful to visit and just to hang out and relax in if you have the time. It does not feel like you ar win the hustle and bustle of Sydney.

A gem. My friend and I thoroughly enjoyed walking through this gem . What a beautiful relaxing gardens. A great place for any age to have a wander through . Loved it perfect end to a beautiful day for us :)

Peace and tranquility. A great spot to just wander, but we were lucky enough to be there in time to take a tour, very knowledgeable young man, the gardens were magnificent and we had great weather too, which is always a bonus. A cafe to sit and unwind.

Tranquillity in a bustling city. The gardens were across the road from our hotel. After a tiring time exploring nearby Darling Harbour, this was a perfect place to sit and enjoy the peace and quiet. The gardens are beautifully laid out and are well maintained. It was surprising to see and hear so much bird-life in the middle of such a vast city.

An oasis of calm. In the hurly burly of a modern city we enjoyed a couple of hours of relaxing oriental zen. Sited where is was we didn't expect the spectacular views we encountered. There was something different around each corner - water, rocks, plants, wildlife and even tourist 'wanna be' mandarins.
Not to be missed.

Loved it so much we visited Twice !. We took our 4 year old and 7 year old son's twice during our Darling Harbour Trip. What a delightful experience. The gardens are beautiful. You must do the dress up's. Time is unlimited, courtesy is endless, and the fun will last for a long time as a trip highlight. We dressed up twice ! Children are $5, Adults are $10. You can then take limitless photographs. The staff assist you. There is no further charge, and no official photo's or anyone selling you anything at all. It was purely a pleasure and the staff in the dress up area could not be more wonderful.

A Gentle Walk with Devonshire Tea at the end. We didn't know what to expect from the Chinese Garden of Friendship. We certainly didn't expect the amazing beauty and tranquillity of the place. Somehow all outside sounds were muted and you were in an oasis of peace and amazing gardens. The walk around was gentle and relaxing and the view at the top of the gardens and pond below was stunning. As you got to the end there was a lovely open plan tea room which served the most delicious Devonshire teas beside the pond. Devonshire teas = scones, jam, cream, tea or coffee. Another must see of Sydney.

A place of quietude and serenity. My wife and I spent nine days on vacation in Sydney. Toward the end of our vacation, we had seen many well-known tourist sites, and we wanted a break from our hectic pace. We wanted a quiet and tranquil place to relax and think about what we should do during our remaining two days. The Chinese Garden of Friendship was within walking distance of our hotel, so we decided to check it out. What a pleasant surprise! It’s hard to believe that there is such a quiet and serene setting in one of the world’s busiest cities. We spent about two hours just walking around the gardens, and we ended up having a cup of coffee in their attractive coffee shop. This garden turned out to be one of our favorite places in Sydney. We highly recommend it.
an Oasis in the city.... You have to pay to get in, but let me tell you it is worthy!!! Once you get inside, you feel you are in another place...

Calming & Peaceful. A great way to relax in the centre of Darling Harbour area. Pay an extra small fee to dress in Chinese costume and have your photo taken by your friends anywhere & everywhere in the grounds.

Relaxing Pleasant Diversion. A very pleasant garden area in the middle of Sydney. From the Japanese tea to the scenic relaxing waters to the exotic plants, it was a great experience.We even saw a wedding during our visit, and who could ask for a more tranquil environment.Definitely worth a visit

Relaxing. I first went to these gardens when first opened have now re visited them taking some family from New Zealand they are spectacular.Felt very calming relaxing as soon as I entered and not expensive either we had munchies in the tea house very nice staff very friendly would recommend a visit .

Tranquil oasis. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is a lovely little oasis contrasting with the modern Darling Harbour it is very close to. It doesn't take long to walk around but you can take your time and just soak up the atmosphere and tranquility. Every now and again you get views of the towering office blocks reminding you the city is just there, but a visit here gives you such a feeling of peace.The admission price was reasonable and there is a tearoom, although it had closed by the time we went. The costumes you can try on and have your photo taken were lovely.

Beautiful. After you have spent all of your money seeing everything else, stop in and just relax and enjoy the view and the walk. No rides or people trying to sell you photos. Just a nice place to gather yourself back together.
Chinese garden. These gardens are simply stunning and so peaceful and tranquil, hard to believe you are in the middle of the city take a chance to enjoy this beauty.

A very beautiful place. After visiting China Town and some markets, we decided to visit the gardens and have a relaxing stroll. The place was beautiful, although it is funny to see it surrounded by tall buildings!Tranquil and quiet - a lovely way to 'escape' the busy city.

Lovely afternoon walk. After spending the day cruising around the harbour, and exploring Darling Harbour, I thought it'd be good to have a walk around the gardens. It was so peaceful and tranquil. Just what you need after a long day out. I also found it quite special that you can hire Oriental costumes, dress up, and then walk around the gardens!

peaceful retreat in the city. the gardens are an affordable, relaxing destination that are well worth a visit. We went on a guided tour and learnt some interesting things about chinese culture and botany. There is a lovely range of plants including a cute bonsai garden. having a cup of chinese tea at the restaurant afterwards was nice but for chinese food there are much better places close by.

Great Photo Opportunities. We popped into the Gardens on the walk back from China Town after Yum Cha to our accommodation at Adina Harbourside. $6 per adult is a fair price. Family of 4 can visit for $15. This is a sanctuary to chill out from the hustle and bustle of a busy city. Hubby is into his photography and there were lots of great photo opportunities - no doubt some will end up on canvas in our home. Gardens are smallish, but I would say to people to use the self guided tour and take the time to read about the each section as you move through and take some time out to breathe and enjoy nature. This was an unexpected bonus side excursion to our day around Darling Harbour.

So Peaceful!. A great place to get away from the noise and bustle of downtown Sydney. It's a smallish place but they've designed it perfectly so you still get a good long walk in through the perfectly manicured gardens. There are waterfalls and brooks leading to the large central pond, complete with koi. There are also several Chinese-style gazebos and other structures in case there should be any rain. All beautiful and ornately carved. It really is a stunning place. We spent about 2 hours there and were quite refreshed afterwards. It's a photographers dream, too. Great lighting, and every angle has a good backdrop of trees, flowers or water. Really stunning.

well establish Chinese garden setting.. Awell established Chinese oriental garden setting in the Sydney centre. There are many places within; the Sydney Chinayown and The Darling Harbor. All these places are within walking and exploring distance. There are many eateries and restaurant that you can enjoy while in the area. Location is excellent and easy to find and get to. The surrounding area is very good. The only issue is the demolishing of the old entertainment centre and building of the new one can spoil the setting of the area at this moment. Otherwise, it is a good place to visit.

"Very tranquil". Beautiful tranquil gardens hidden behind walls in the middle of a busy city. From the outside it's hard to comprehend how this beautiful gardens can be so calming and private. There is a lot of traditional plants as well as Chinese structures and the place has a number of excellent photo opportunities. There is a number of spots to sit and contemplate as well as tea rooms. you can even dress in authentic Chinese clothes to wear around the grounds. Well worth a visit and there is a small entrance fee for the up keep

Blooming lovely. Not being a native of Sydney and travelling on foot in Darling Harbour was must, I took to pounding the pavement at every opportunity I could. I came across the gardens early hours of the morning however they were shut. They are open after 9am as are most places in Sydney. The opening hours aren't clearly sign posted for those not familiar to the area. Don't try the doors they are alarmed, a slight knock can set them off as my child unfortunately tried to open the doors thinking they were just closed, whoops. What a fright. All was well, we returned after 9am and the price for entry was surprisingly low. Made it cost effective and didn't burn a hole in my purse.If you have a family they do family rates dependent on the size and structure of your family. They even have a tea house, which again I wasn't aware of where you can sit down and enjoy the gardens whilst being refreshed. The gardens are well set out and are beautiful, for those with children, they have some large fish for little eyes to feast upon. There is information about the plants and gardens background together with a wishing well located inside. Its not very wheelchair friendly in the higher rocky parts of the garden but can be enjoyed from ground level just the same.I found it took about 1-1.5 hours to properly have a look around and take in the beautiful scenery that was hidden in amongst the concrete buildings. Prices at the cafe were very reasonable so it makes it affordable and a pleasurable experience if you are looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the city and zone out.Hope this helps.

Similar to other Chinese Gardens. These gardens are not any different than other Chinese gardens located in other major cities. Not to say that it isn't nice, but it's not exactly a unique experience. There is the cute option of dressing up in the traditional garb of the time, but obviously not for everyone, myself included. The scenery is nice, but the peaceful feeling of a Chinese Garden is difficult to convey in this location when you are surrounded by tall buildings and, at the time of our visit, assaulted by the constant noise of nearby construction. I would recommend to skip this unless you have a very particular interest in Chinese gardens.

My Favourite Place In Sydney. This is an AMAZING place. Surrounded by tall, grey office-buildings, the beautiful garden is brought to it's full potential as you have such a contrast between cityscape and lush planting. There is a small fee to get in, but it is more than worth it. The carp-pond is amazing as there are so many fish, and you can buy old bread at the cafe to feed them. I would recommend going to this place with a friend or loved one as you will want to meander through the paths, but may find yourself bored if there is no-one to talk to. A must-see for anyone interested in Asian gardens.
Tranquility. In the heart of the city, to find such a place is awesome. The rocks, waterfalls are created in such a way that it gives the place that tranquil feeling.

Amazing. What a picturesque setting in the middle of Sydney. My friend and I spent a few hours just walking around admiring this beautiful location.we also had lunch in the tea house.Don't miss this fabulous attraction.
Picturesque gardens. The Chinese gardens are a very nice place to visit very calming, with some very pretty views and easy to get to just down the road from the harbour.

Beautiful oasis to visit. Very reasonable and inexpensive admission fees. A central location within easy walking distance of the CBD (Central Business District). The place is beautiful and well kept, the staff are friendly. Lots of wonderful settings for photographs.

small but beautiful. Amidst the hustle and bustle of play parks, music venues, building sites, Darling Harbour and all it's attractions sits this little oasis of calmness and tranquility. Not that large, but one may amble round at whatever speed suits your mood, until refreshed enough to face the world outside. The waterfalls, ponds, plants, statues create an atmosphere in which one may easily "go placidly among the noise and haste". Well worth a visit

Special place. I enjoyed the silent place and was fascinated about the variety of plants and places I could stay - having had a nice cup of traditional tea for lunch afterwards to finalise my visit there.
cool little garden. Cool little chill out in the city near the harbour. not a bad little break from the hustle and bustle probably wouldnt visit again but it was interesting

What a delight in the city centre. During sunny days this place of perfect yin-yang showcase is unbeatable to find some rest (if there is no construction work on the former exhibition ground and no loud music from Tumbalong Park). Just looking at the Lake of Brightness and the vegetation around calms you down. I strongly recommend to sit down at some point and just embrace the atmosphere. This is a very generous gift by the Chinese sister city Guangzhou of Guangdong Province to Sydney and New South Wales.The leaflet provides you with information about all points of interest and some detailed stuff about highlights. They also offer a guided highlights tour through the garden. During the walk you can learn things about Chinese culture and the friendship between Sydney and Guangzhou - meaning there is more to discover than the beauty of the garden.Don't forget to try on the royal costumes for an extra fee. It is an awesome experience and definitely something to remember, no matter if you are coming as a couple or as a family. This place is also perfect for people who don't have much time. Definitely go!

'Tranquility versus bustle'. Beautiful gardens and peaceful waters. These gardens were delightful and extremely restful. Whilst we were there it was hard to believe that so many busy activities were happening beyond the walls. The entrance fee was value for money as you could leave and come back again throughout the day. Well worth a visit.

A tranquil setting. At the end of an active day seeing other sights of Sydney, I took my UK visitors here for some 'quiet time'. They were enchanted by the beauty of the gardens, by the tranquillity of the setting, by the discovery of this place in the middle of such a busy city. They enjoyed it so much, they returned another day when I wasn't with them. The layout of the gardens invites you to wander around or to sit in a quiet spot and enjoy them.

Paradise beside darling harbour. This gem is an oasis hidden in the city. Escape the city madness and walk around and take in the Asian garden. You can rent costumes if you want to get completely into it. So nice seeing tourists dressed in full Asian costume walking around.
Peaceful oasis in the city. The garden was so beautiful, and relaxing, and quiet. The visitor's map provides a great self-guided tour, and explained all the features of the garden.
Peacful visit. Very nice and relaxing visit while visiting darling harbour area. enjoy the atmosphere and take a drink at the bar

Definitely a must to visit while in Sydney. It's quiet, it's beautiful, it's entertaining and it's calming. Yes all of these things and more. We enjoyed looking at the people who decided to take up the option of dressing in Chinese costume and it gave the gardens such a sense of charm as they wandered about these tranquil paths. It's a haven really and it's situated right in the heart of the busy harbour. Definitely worth the small entrance fee!

Spectacular. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is an oasis in the middle of the Sydney's CBD. Once inside everything external seems to fade away. Every vista presents something different, the only similarity between them is peace and tranquility. A spectacular venue for a wedding but also magical for anyone visiting for any reason.

Great Oasis in busy city. The garden is close to the PowerHouse museum and a nice break from the city. The usual aspects of a chinese garden are there, waterfalls, bonsia, decorative pools and rocks and the atmosphere is very peaceful. The garden is elevated a bit from the surrounding area so that the noise fromt he surrounding area is limited.

Nostalgia. Definitely worth popping in and having a lookIts a little garden in the hub of Darling harbour. If you're into bonsai trees, there 's definitely many of those.We were lucky enough to watch a couple get married on the day we went. It's a popular location for couples to get married.I often visited this place when I was a child, enjoyed it back then and same this time.

Peaceful, relaxing. This was my 3rd port of call for today and I enjoyed every minute of it, from watching the red and silver koi carp in the pool to wandering the paths and sitting with a brown and gold lizard the length of my forearm.In fact, there were many lizards of diverse colours and various sizes, from the size of my little finger to the giant mentioned earlier. The most attractive colour were the dark brown with a line of golden spots down each side - what a fabulous colour combination. The sun was glinting off the golden spots; the lizards were quite active running hither and thither through the ferns at the water's edge, or just lazily sunning themselves on a warm rock.Later, a family came through who had opted to take advantage of the opportunity to dress up in Japanese Kimonos, complete with obis and in one case, a sword. They made a very colourful sight among the masses of cool greens of the gardens. This is a lovely oasis of calm in the middle of a very busy city, and well worth the visit. There's a café should you want refreshments. The entrance fee is quite small (can't remember exactly how much) and there is limited wheel chair access but still enough to enjoy the surroundings.

Peaceful break from the city life. The park is situated right on a busy Sydney street, but you would not know it or hear much of the traffic sound. The ponds are delightful and inspiring, the gardens lush and well cared for, its definite a place that you don't want to miss. Plenty of photo opportunities here.

Tranquility. The Chinese Gardens are a little area of tranquility surrounded by the tall buildings and hustle and bustle of Sydney.It is a stroll along from Cockle Bay Wharf at Darling Harbour on the way to Paddy's Market, if you do not fancy walking catch the small train that runs from Darling Harbour it will stop right outside.It will cost you $6 Aus to get in, this allows you to come and go all day. Inside it is so lovely, the Chinese have a way of blending plants and water together to bring out some very pretty vistas and a sense of tranquility.I should say that this is not a suitable place for people with walking difficulties or for wheel chairs and push chairs.It is a place to stroll around to sit and contemplate, to take loads of photographs and to forget the outside world for a couple of hours.At one point inside you come across a small building where you can go in and get dressed up in the most colourful Chinese outfits and walk around to find that special spot for a photograph.There was a wedding taking place when we arrived, lovely setting for such an occasion.There is also a lovely area for refreshments, anything from tea and coffees to cold drinks, snacks and cakes etc.This a certainly a place that is well worth taking a couple of hours out of your day to visit, recommended.

A must see. This beautiful garden is a treat for the eyes, with beautiful water features, rocks, steps, careful plantings and pagodas. Everything looks so natural and harmonious here, nothing appears contrived and just sitting here on a mild sunny day, resting in this peaceful environment is very refreshing. The pink camellia trees were in flower during March and I couldn’t help thinking how lovely it would look in Spring when the Azaleas are all out. Tours of the garden are also available and very worthwhile.

Beautiful oasis in the middle of the city. I am quite ashamed to say it in all my visits to sydney I have never been here---- so off we went, what a beautiful calming atmosphere in the middle of the city--- beautifully maintained and the use of rock and simple plants just adds to the magnificent specimen trees----- you just have to go and have a look !!!
Ok. It is ok, nice place to take photos but not many attractions or activites to do but walk around and breathe. ..................................

Beauty and serenity in a garden. Of all the world's famous manmade sites, this has to be one of the most breathtakingly beautiful. It is both serene and surprising at the same time and offers many places where you can sit and meditate or just breathe in the tranquility. Experts from China and Australia worked together to produce this amazing combination of plants and trees, ponds and streams, rocks and pavilions, walls and gates and statues. I visited in autumn when about half the flowers had gone, but there was still enough plenty of colour, but I was assured that the summer blooms are even more stunning. The numerous pavilions and gates offer eye-catching but varied views from every angle. Exotic waterfowl share the pools and waterfalls and stroll among the bamboo and peonies or go through elaborate mating rituals high in the treetops. Koi and other creatures add splashes of colour to the pools and ponds. I was lucky enough to arrive there on a Sunday morning just as it opened and so for the first hour I had the entire place to myself - as a photographer I was in heaven. If you can only visit one place in Sydney, this is the one I would recommend. Outside the garden's entrance is the Giant Ferris Wheel which offers some great aerial views of the gardens also.

Splendid Sydney Oasis of Tranquility. We ended a full day around Darling Harbor by visiting these Gardens and so very glad we did. Once inside, almost every corner brought a new, perfectly proportioned view which seemed to increase in peacefulness and tranquility as we progressed through the garden. I've visited the Forbidden City in Beijing and several urban "gardens" like this in other Chinese cities and this is what they aspire to be, without the smog and crowds.
Beautiful spot in the city. Beautiful gardens. Nice place for relaxation right in the middle of the city. Perfect for weddings or just to "get away". Nice cafe and reasonably priced

Lovely place!. It could be called the Garden of Relaxation! Walled in, the outside din is lost. Cleverly laid out, it seems bigger than it is, although it is quite large. It has well tended trees and gardens, including up a hill that overlooks the main entrance building. Also has stretches of water with coy, and contemplation gazebos along the winding path around the property. The buildings are very Chinese, as are the gardens. Lunch was v good, and inexpensive--a surprise in expensive Sydney!

Very fun afternoon. I went with some friends as a bit of a something to do before we went to the cinema and it was really good. You wouldn't thought it was in the middle of a major city as it was completely silent in there and the gardens are beautiful.Theres an area in there where they let you put on traditional clothing for free and you can go out and take pictures of youself around the park in your outfits. Well worth the entry fee!I was surpised to spot it in the film The Wolverine recently too!

In a different world.. If you had enough of the busy city and need some solitude this is the place to go. Although many people visit here it has been set up in such a way that you feel nearly alone. I forgot I was in a busy metropolis until I suddenly saw the sky scrapers and heard cars driving on the other side of a wall.

Tranquility amongst the noise. Odd as it may sound this garden which is set between the city with its roads and the Darling Harbour with its incredible hustle and bustle of eateries and people enjoying themselves, is an absolute haven of tranquillity. Yes, one can hear the noise of the city outside and yet suddenly that noise ceases to exist in one's consciousness. I spent a lot of time sitting watching the birds and the water dragons (there were some tiny baby ones too) and just appreciating the beauty as well as the sculptures and the plants.

A little oasis. It was nice to revisit this little oasis which features lots of chinese architecture, a large waterfall and lake, beautiful gardens and lots of winding pathways and stone staircases.The staff at the ticket office will tell you that 70% of the gardens are stroller-friendly but we ditched the stroller at the first pagoda, there are just too many uneven surfaces and little steps to negotiate. Much easier to let the toddlers out and explore on their own as long as you keep an eye on them.Its not expensive to get in ($6 adults) and you can easily spend an hour or more in there (plus dine at the café). There is a room where the kids can dress up in chinese costume too which would make some great photo opportunities.A nice spot for wandering, photography, and peaceful reflection.
A little piece of Heaven. If you are in Sydney for a day and want to take time out to relax I suggest to visit the Gardens for some peace and quiet, also to share a nice Pot of Tea in the Tea House!!

Peaceful retreat. This is a lovely peaceful venue in the middle of the busy city. Very peaceful, lovely Chinese buildings, with flowers, trees and pools to wander around. Worth having a cup of tea in the tea rooms as well. Very pretty spot hidden away in the heart of the city.

Peaceful and pretty. A lovely peaceful place to visit in the centre of Sydney. The tea rooms are great and an amazing place to catch a cool breeze on a hot afternoon. Lots of pools with fish and we spotted several large lizards.

Beautiful. I was in Sydney on a business trip so was trying to find things to do in the CBD that wouldn't take a huge amount of time. I've done all of the typical tourist attractions last time I was in town so wanted to visit somewhere a little different. I found the Chinese Friendship Gardens and was blown away by their beauty! It only costs $6 to get in and you could easily spend hours wandering around and having lunch at the tea house. Highly recommend a visit to anyone - a haven of tranquility within this busy bustling city!

Beautiful Oasis. The gardens are just gorgeous, so quiet and peaceful and beautiful to look at. You can also have a lunch or morning or afternoon tea at the tea rooms. We had the scones but they were not really scones they were cake like, I would recommend the other options.

Beautiful Garden. The docent provided an excellent tour and explanation of all of the design features of a Chinese garden. The plants, the water, the buildings, rocks and artwork were exceptional. The plants were well identified. The sister city in China contributed the design and some plants. Previous reviews almost prevented us from visiting which turned out to be one of the highlights of our visit to Sydney. Great place for people who like to walk slowly through a garden!
Stunning. So peaceful and beautiful, right in the heart of Sydney's Darling Harbour. My favourite part was watching the fish as we had afternoon tea in the teahouse.

Nice walk around with Sydney friends. Very tranquil and allowed us to natter and share experiences as we walked around and share the gardens. Then a nice snack in the tearoom - nothing too great but what we wanted.

Very peaceful. This is definitely worth visiting. The layout is fantastic and oozes peace and tranquillity. Despite being in the middle of a very busy area, you are not bothered by outside noise. The tearooms offer a good range of Chinese tea which you can drink while sitting by the lake. Wonderful!

Beautiful garden. Definitely a hidden gem right in the middle of the city. As soon as you walk in its like a whole different world(even though you can still hear traffic etc). Only $6 per adult, there's so many different spots where you can just sit and enjoy the surroundings. We didn't expect it to be as nice as it was but it really was beautiful. There's also a café there that does sandwiches and also yum cha so you can eat there overlooking the pond. Not for everyone but if you like this kind of place you will love these gardens.

Gorgeous Garden. This is definitely a hidden gem in Sydney. You can believe how quiet this place is even though it is next to a major road. The greenery and stone is great. There is also some great art pieces spread throughout the garden.

Picturesque Chinese garden right in the middle of downtown Sydney!. Not too expensive ($6/per adult, $4/child) compared to other attractions in Sydney, this picturesque paradise is the perfect park to unwind for 1-2 hours max – BUT DON'T expect it to be quiet – remember it is downtown with city and traffic noise that just can't be helped. I love Asian-themed gardens to enjoyed this a lot but it isn't for everyone. You need to like this style to thoroughly justify the cost to get in. We were 3 adults with 4 kids total so it was $34.It's fun for kids because you can rent traditional Chinese clothing here and get pictures taken among many Chinese artistic features and temples throughout the park.We were lucky to be there when a lot is in bloom and beautiful Asian-style water features are everywhere. There is a nice cafe in the park to have afternoon tea. It's a cool contrast to see the water, rocks, birds, carp, lizards and plants of this natural Zen garden surrounded by the skyscrapers and office high-rise buildings of Sydney.If once you leave here if you still seek the Chinese experience, China Town is not even a 10 minute walk away and worth a walking tour (and unlike here it's free). If you aren't into Chinese-themed gardens but like plants I definitely recommend you visit the Botanic Gardens rather than here.

Afternoon Tea. What a tranquil place to visit . We paid $11 each entrance which included tea and scones with jam and cream . beautiful place , lots of lovely plants and exotic Black Headed Ibis birds strutting around . And only a short walk from the hustle and bustle of the city .

A beautiful, peaceful place to get away from the city bustle. Next time you are in the Chinatown end of Darling Harbour take the time to visit the Chinese Friendship Garden which is now 25 years old! We visited it last in 1989 when it was first built and on this visit we were amazed at how it has developed – it is such a lovely place now with its established plantings. Beautiful views open up wherever you walk and it's a great place to take photos.A new aspect to us was the fact you could hire Chinese costumes to walk around the garden in and take photos. Very reasonable price - just $10 for adults and a lovely girl puts you in costume. There is also a café on site for afternoon teas.

A big WOW. Whilst the Garden is not extensive and can be navigated, quickly, in a few minutes, only a philistine would contemplate such an action. This Garden needs time for you to wander and wonder. They are, quite frankly, lovely. According to the brochure provided at the ticket office, there are "waterfall, lakes, hidden pathways, traditional carvings, sculptures", and a heap more. The brochure, if anything, understates the attractions. I visited the Garden in the early 1990's when plantings were still young. Now, everything is well-established and beautifully maintained. Unfortunately on my recent visit the weather was in a rainy mood so lingering without an umbrella was unwise, however the weather actually added to the serenity. Street noise is muted.Given the proximity to Chinatown's main restaurant area, about a five minute walk away,a visit to the Garden is a must if you are in the area. Entry costs $6.00 for an adult with lesser prices for Pensioners, Concession holders and children. My entrance fee was $3.00. A bargain! If you feel like lingering longer, The Teahouse provides a "range of Chinese tea, dumplings, pastries and steamed buns". There is also a café style menu.Unfortunately, this attraction is not "disabled-friendly". Most of the Garden pathways are stones, although access to the Tearoom would be possible.

Peaceful and Happy Experience!. My partner and I were celebrating our 5 year anniversary and decided to visit Sydney and see some of the sights around Darling Harbour and the Rocks. Our hotel was situated near china town and was only a short walk away from the Chinese Garden of Friendship. We walked straight past it and it looked wonderful. We went inside payed the entrance fee. If you are a student be sure to bring your student card as they offer discounts (we only ended up paying $6 for the two of us). The garden offers guided tours two times a day, but the garden is just as good if you walk it at your own pace. There are lots of photo opportunities as the garden is full of lovely flowers, trees, Chinese architecture and water features. The garden also offers traditional Chinese costumes to hire and professional photography if you want to dress up - it looked quite fun! The garden is a cheap but lovely place to spend a few hours relaxing!

Amazing place for day visit. Great place for a day trip. The scenery is truly amazing and hard to believe that this garden is in the CBD amongst all the buildings. The entrance fee of $ 6 per person is well worth it as it includes a guided tour twice a day. Once you get in you can spend the whole day inside the gardens and looking around at your own pace. Really enjoyed the informative and friendly guided tour as well. Don't forget your camera.!! The only complaint I have is the greenery and water attract a lot of mosquitoes and if you stay still long enough you get bitten.

Very peaceful. I last visited this beautiful garden several years ago but recently directed our overseas visitors to this peaceful oasis in the city, in December 2013.It is amazing to find this oasis right in the middle of the city and now I know why it is called the 'secret garden'. You can stroll through the gardens at your own place and then sit and take it all in. I could have stayed here for hours in the cool if not for the fact that there was lots of other things to fit into my day on my short visit to Sydney. If you are planning to visit this place then you should allow a few hours so that you can also have tea. If I had known previously about these amazing gardens I would have allowed more time. The entry fee is cheap if you are on a budget. This will definitely be one of the very first 'must do' things on my list when I next visit Sydney. It is only a short stroll from Darling Harbour.
Amazing. That place is so nice, take you in a travel to China, flowers and lakes, ducks, lizard, butterfly, waterfall. If you love take pictures, you shold visit this place.

Beautiful. A quiet little sanctuary in the middle of the city, well payed out and maintained , pretty gardens, great customer service, good place to chillax and have cuppa after strolling through the gardens and water features, well worth a visit when visiting darling harbour Sydney

Lovely Serene in the Hustle and Bustle. This place is a quiet serene garden in the middle of a busy bustling city. The plants are truly beautiful and it is well worth the visit. It was many years ago when the gardens first opened that I visited and then again recently it is still a treat.

Beautiful views, enjoyed the dress-up experience!. We enjoyed the garden and its views because it is well done and offers some tranquility among the business of the Darling Harbour area. However, it was truly the dress-up experience that made it so exciting for my group of 6 (3 couples). You can pay to be dressed up in beautiful authentic Chinese outfits that you can wear around the gardens while taking any photos you desire. These outfits and experience along with the photos we took while in the special outfits truly made it a wonderful visit for my group.

Cool and tranquil garden oasis surrounded by the modern city.. We often visit here when we come to Darling harbour,enjoying weaving our way through the maze of cobble-stoned paths,finding hidden pergolas,overlooking watery features and spotting water dragons,koi and ducks that inhabit the garden. Finish with a Chinese tea and dim sum at the tea house while relaxing in the cool and tranquile surroundings,especially on a hot summer's day in Sydney. We will be back to celebrate The Year of the Horse while immersing ourselves in the traditional funfair... and noise.

Peace and Serenity in a busy setting ... and very cheap. Lovely peaceful gardens. Small but big enough to spend time wandering and soaking up the views. Good photo opportunities. When we were there lots of visitors had taken the opportunity to hire the classic Chinese costumes on offer in order to get even more authentic photos. Pleasant café overlooking water.

Just Right. Have visited before but had to leave earlier than planned. Returned with the family and though some may complain of the price I would say compared to what other Sydney tourist attractions charge this was excellently priced and again if you want to hire the authentic costumes and spend your time in the gardens. Very peaceful, very picturesque and very calming. Focus on what is in front of you not what is beyond (buildings etc) and you'll enjoy it to its fullest. Will certainly be back.

So beautiful!. We visit the Chinese Garden of Friendship whenever we are lucky enough to be in Australia. It has matured over the years into one of the most beautiful gardens you could wish to see. The vignettes through masterfully placed windows showcase the plants and features. Don't forget your camera!

A Beautiful Oasis. Visiting this beautiful garden was our last activity before flying out of Sydney. What an oasis in the midst of the city. Well designed with helpful signs that helped to explain the philosophy underpinning it. I consider it a "must see" of Sydney not only as a visual attraction but for the sense of calm and tranquility it evokes.

a gem. This is a beautiful garden. The visit is enhanced by the helpful explanations of the design of the various water and pavilion features which are set out in a free leaflet.It is a true oasis of calm in the city.A visit is highly recommended.At 6 dollars the entry fee is a snip.For photography purposes it is recommended that a visit is made as soon as the garden opens (1000 when I was there).
a beautiful place. a beautiful garden. a great atmosphere. you could stay there all day. the flowers are wonderful. the café tea house is lovely. complete with a visit from the ducks,

An Oasis midst the hustle and bustle. The contrast between the calm, green, watery, sheltered friendship gardens and the nearby Tumbalong Park is stark. As is the green and lush garden landscape against a backdrop of modern high-rise hotels and office blocks. However, I wish they had spent a little more time in explaining the symbolism of the exhibits and they can lose the Disneyesque dress up like a Chinaman to get your photos taken.

An oasis of tranquility. On a steamy January day we were looking for a light lunch and stumbled upon the tea rooms at the Chinese Gardens. For an inclusive fee of $16.50 you gain entry to the Gardens where you can easily spend hours wandering the winding paths and a set lunch consisting of a sandwich, a cake plus tea or coffee. Despite a limited selection on offer, the sandwiches were fresh and delicious and the cakes superb. The tea was loose leaf in a tea pot and the coffee was also very good. Sitting in a pavilion on the edge of a lake we were able to watch the carp chasing each other around, ducks waddled past our table and into the water and a beautiful water dragon nibbled crumbs from under the table. We spent a couple of hours just soaking up the peace. What a wonderful lunchtime refuge from the bustling city.

Chinese Gardens. Lost in paradise in the Chinese Gardens. You forget that you are in the heart of all the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Beautiful gardens that are tranquil and a please to kick back and enjoy.
What a lovely spot. What a glorious destination. A s erene and lovely escape from a busy city. Shows the wonder of Sydney's soul.
An Oasis in the heart of the city. A beautiful place to walk through and chill out, very well done. Nicely laid out, now just to shut out the noise of the traffic. Good Luck!

tranquil paradise. A beautiful garden in the centre of the busy city centre. Was surprised that there was an entry fee, however once inside the cost is justified. The gardens are set out wonderfully, and offer some great photo opportunities, a stark contrast to the bustle of darling harbour on the otherside of the walls.

Lovely peaceful gardens. Lovely sanctuary nestled between Chinatown & Darling Harbour. Very peaceful (well, it was before we arrived with the kids in tow) & beautiful gardens and lakes with various birds, giant carp and the odd lizard to look at.We took a stroller to the gardens, but found it too difficult to get around as there are many steps and uneven paths. Best to leave the stroller at the entrance!Was surprised that you had to pay to get in, as I thought it was free. Glad we went though.

Beautiful, tranquil, and peaceful.. Had an enormous amount of fun here. A mate and I just wanted something to kill some time, and the entry is cheap, so we checked it out.
Before too long, I'd taken over 100 photos, and we were even putting on Chinese costumes and getting our photos taken.
The place is beautiful, and is worth the time.

Interesting and good value. For $11 I obtained entry into the gardens, a pot of green tea and dumplings - very good value.The signage around the gardens offers interesting information about why things have been placed as they have, the dragon walk in magnificent and the huge koi in the lake are fun. Sitting having a pot if tea a dragon lizard wandered past the table - cue much photo taking.Most of the garden has steps and non-smooth paths, not suitable for wheelchairs or pushchairs.

Peace and tranquility in the heart of Darling Harbour. What a beautiful gardens. Water everywhere and a traditional style Chinese tea house serving dumplings, cakes and a variety of Chinese teas.
