Some of the tables overlook the lake filled with Koi fish and ducks. We visited twice in one week just to escape the business of Xmas festive season. I loved this oriental delight.

Chinese Garden of Friendship. The Garden of Friendship is a magnificent gift from the Australian Chinese people to the city, it is hard to believe you are in central Sydney. The garden design and the tranquil surroundings give one such a sense of peace that you come away totally refreshed. We will return when next in Sydney.

Chinese Garden: an oasis in the urban environment. This tranquil and soothing garden is just what the doctor ordered. Everywhere you turn there is beauty and enchantment, from the pool with fish, to the waterfall. You will get so much from visiting this site. We can't recommend it enough.

A tranquil haven in an otherwise bustling city harbour..... The hour or so we spent here has to be one of my favourite hours from our whole trip of Sydney, such beautiful and lush surroundings, and so peaceful. I could imagine proposals and weddings taking place here! We took many photos here amongst the tress and flowers, really beautiful. Loved it here - definitely worth a visit.

Nice for a short walk around. Friendly Staff, and nice gardens to walk around there is also a coffee shop to relax in if you have time.There is also a shop that allows you to dress in a Kimono but it is not always open, check for times if you wanted to do that.

beautiful!. When I lived in Sydney, I was constantly visiting this garden. My favorite (yes, I am American) part was sitting down and drinking tea and watching the koi. It's beautiful and well for a visit for the small fee!
Saranya. Good !! i loved the garden .. they maintained very well !! small trees were awesome and never seen anywhere .. don't miss it and have fun !!

Surprisingly Fun. Tranquil and cool garden closely located to the CBD. There is a small entry fee and a tea house on site. The gardens offer a lot for photographers of all experience levels. For an additional fee $10 for adults and $5 per child you can be dressed in traditional Chinese robes and stroll the gardens and take photos. This was great family fun and the staff were helpful in taking photos with our cameras.
Serenity in CBD. Do visit! You will not regret it. A lovely contrast to the Darling Harbour experience and incredibly beautiful gardens and waterways. A cool and tranquil place.

Beautiful & Tranquil. Very beautiful, and picturesque. A nice peaceful spot in the middle of a city. Entry is cheap but you can find a deal so it's included in a bunch of other tourist spots. Beautiful if you can stop but not a must see in the city.
Oase of tranquility. In busy city, this is an Oase of tranquility and peace.you may borrow Chinese cloth for whole family for great pics.nice place,3 dollars entry fee

Serene Experience. A lovely garden to symbolize the friendship between Guangdong and NSW. It has a very serene and tranquil ambiance to it. Do make it a point to visit these points of interest which depict the rich Chinese tradition and architecture: Hall of Clear shade, Dragon Wall, Lake of Brightness, Peace Boat Pavilion, Mountain Gate, Clear View Pavilion, Waterfall and Water Pavilion of Lotus Fragrance.

Amazing. The garden is in the middle of the city in the darling harbor. It is a very calm and nice place to visit. The entry is cheap ($6 for adults and $3 for students).There is a chines place which rents you chines customs to wear which was very nice.You MUST visit it.
Great Gardens. Beautiful gardens, water features, fish, birds, lizards, peaceful bliss and a reasonable tea and scones.

A beautiful place to sit and contemplate. These gardens are an oasis of peace in the middle of a busy city. They are so tranquil and just invite you to sit and absorb the beauty. What a great find. Lovely place to have lunch and just take an hour or two out of your busy day.

Peaceful. We were not expecting too much, but it was beautiful inside and worth admission. There are other interesting things to see in Sydney if you are short of time, but if you have time I can recommended to stop by for a little visit. It is peaceful and a good place to sit and read a bit.

Wonderfully peaceful oasis in the middle of the CBD. A visit to the Chinese Garden of Friendship is like a trip to another land with exotic landscapes, lakes, quiet corners for meditation and a Tea House for refreshments. Absolutely beautiful! A very popular place for weddings but also if you just need some time-out from everyday life.
Beautiful and tranquil walk. We enjoyed our walk through the garden. Very serene, beautiful. A nice little walk in the middle of the city.

Don't miss this gem in the heart of Sydney. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is an absolute gem in the heart of Sydney at Darling Harbour. We were astounded at the spectacular blend of architecture and natural design. There were peaceful walkways and places for silent meditation, and everywhere the scenery was really wonderful. A must-see attraction -- if you have time, grab lunch or afternoon tea at their café.

A city centre haven. Right in the middle of one of the most bustling lively energised, and energising, cities I've ever visited is this haven of peace and tranquillity. I was so lucky that this amazing garden was on the doorstep of my hotel. Go for a run around Darling Harbour and then cool down and chill out here. My only complaint? I was visiting it solo :(
Beautiful quiet place. In the midst of a busy city, this was a gift of silence. Just a beautiful place to sit and have a cup of tea.

Tranquility in the city. Remember to bring your insect repellant as quite a few Mosquitos but otherwise a lovely relaxing garden with lots of little pathways to explore. Lots of lizards and Koi Carp that are fed a couple of times a day.....

What a jewel. Full disclosure - my wife and I are serious garden geeks. This is an oasis on the edge of Darling Harbor. It's beautifully designed and planted with nice pagodas. It is a simply beautiful design and a pleasure to walk through. This garden is about architecture as much as it is plants.
Nice. Not the best of weather but my parents enjoyed it and i enjoyed seeing them relaxed during their visit to Sydney. Definitely more relaxing during the week than the weekend.

Tranquil and beautiful. We visited the garden on a hot afternoon and it offered a serene and shady escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. It's beautiful. Watch out for lizards and bearded dragons!
Beautiful. The gardens are beautiful an have a lovely cafe. Right near Darling Harbour and markets. Some beautiful photo opportunities.

A pocket of peace in a frantic city.. Do not miss this beautiful spot. Although small, the garden is beautifully laid out, with many turns and twists. The cliff face is made use of to create levels of interest. For those who want to live the experience, you can hire Chinese costumes.

Great service, beautiful gardens. We found this place by mistake and couldn't resist going in. Staff on the front desk were very friendly and helpful (plus we got a student discount).The grounds are very well maintained with clear walking paths, but still feeling like you're part of the garden. We were provided with a map for information, and the subtle signage around the gardens provides more information on the buildings and plants.Very relaxing, highly recommended after a busy day in the CBD!

PEACEFUL RELAXING PARK. I spent and hour and a half peacefully walking around in this Garden. I went early in the morning and there were very few people there .Even when the people started to build up there was still peacefulness and serenity. The gardens are immaculate.The waterfallsare beautiful and all this in the middle of Sydney's high rise buildings.The gardens are kept in immaculate condition and the trees,plants and bonsai all in very good health.There are a large number of coor fish which have a beautiful and peaceful home to swim around in. I will visit this again next time in Sydney as cheap entry fee as well as a relaxing place in amongst the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Loved it.

The Chinese garden. This is a very nicely landscaped garden with lot of greenery and waterfalls and lakes with elegant chinese architecture.Also some history of china is on display.There is facility for one to dorn the traditional chines attire and be photographed amidst the chines backdrop.A really nice plca amidst the busling city of Sydney/

Another good Sydney park. This is such a beautiful quiet place in the middle of a large city. The design was such that you can look in just about any direction and see a different view of the slightly hilly landscaping. This was one of the best places to take photographs. A leisurely hour and a half walk. Pay the cheap entrance fee instead of using one of the tour package options if you have the 3 or 5 tour packages.

Great spot for a walk and afternoon tea. In a city full of tall buildings, the Chinese Gardens is a hidden little oasis and definitely worth a visit. The garden has been designed to appear larger in the inside than it actually is and there are lots of little hidden annexes and corners all designed with Chinese symbols and history in mind. Great for taking interesting photos, and I highly recommend spending a bit extra and opting for the afternoon tea package (tea and scones, or green tea and dumplings - yum!!)

Amazing Retreat. This little garden is an amazing retreat from the busy city. I visited on a very hot 35 degree day, and was overjoyed to find spots of shade to sit, relax and enjoy. A beautiful spot and a great way to spend as little or as much time as you want!
serene spot. Lovely, well laid out gardens and ponds that were a quiet, cool place to wander . We had a look around and then sat and had a yummy afternoon tea at the teahouse.

Peaceful gardens. Beautiful walk through the peaceful gardens. Our daughter loved the ponds & waterfalls & there was lots of wildlife including ducks & water dragons. Beautiful oasis in the middle of the City
Serenity Now. The crowds around Darling Harbour can be exhausting. The Chinese friendship offers a brief serene respite and a chance to rejuvenate in peace.
Very Peaceful. In amongst the hustle and bustle of the city, this garden is a very tranquil and peaceful place to be. You can easily lose yourself for hours looking at the water.

Peace and Tranquility plus. Something special in Darling Harbour, great time spent so calming and peace of minds shear beauty at it very best in such a busy town waterfalls lush green area great flow from the huge fish lizards, turtles, ducks with there ducklings and more I was a little reluctant at the fee to enter but once we were in had no regrets well worth every dollar !!!!!!!!!

Good value visit. We were initially surprised that you had to pay to visit the garden but once inside we realised it was much larger than expected and it took a good hour or more to walk around (or longer if you stop for something to eat or drink in the small cafe).A lovely calm oasis amidst the hustle and bustle of Sydney and well worth a visit.

Lovely Garden. Great place to visit to visit and found it a relaxing get away within the City. The gardens and buildings are beautiful though some of the buildings seemed a bit run down. Was surprised there was a fee to enter but was happy I visited.

A Piece of Tranquility in the City. Well worth a visit. always beautiful and serene with something new to see every time we visit. Nice to have a break from the city bustle and then take the little train back to darling harbour for a coffee.
A gem in the city. If your in Darling Harbour its well worth the couple of hours to visit this lovely garden. Its beautifully constructed.

Calming, interesting and beautiful. I have wanted to go for at least two years but none of my friends wanted to pay the entry fee. Luckily I finally found someone who would go with me there.I know the CBD backdrop is part of their concept, but I can't help wishing the tall towers weren't there because honestly they destroyed the pretty pictures the garden made.There is a group of ducklings with a mother duck in the lake. They're too cute.I like the pavilions, with all the carvings. They're really beautiful as well. I wish the garden was bigger but it was really nice overall.

Worthwhile. We have been to china a couple of times so I was hesitant to visit yet another garden. But to my surprise this is a beautiful garden. Very nicely layed out with a variety of nice spots: bridges, waterfalls, pagoda's, even ponds,complete with large Koi. You can dress up in traditional Chinese clothing for picture taking too. This is a worthwhile visit
Beautiful view. It was part of our tour to Darling Harbour and the general feel about the garden was very positive! There was plenty to see as well as areas where you could get a well earned rest.

Loved it!. This is chinese garden in the middle of Darling harbour. Its so pretty you wouldnt realise it was places in a city. I visted here a few times during my stay in Sydney. Its only $6 and $10 to dress up as a chinese empress!! Which ic fun running around in the out fit.There also a cute tea room too.
Dont waste your money. Its nice but nothing special. Keep walking. Not much to see. Dont waste your money. Enjoy darling harbour people watching instead.
overestimated, but nice. The only special fact is that it is in the heart of a downtown. Anyway, it worth to take a cup of the with no hurry

Friendship and cash. The main garden in the Chinese Garden of Friendship is a pay per entry garden locked down behind a tall wall. You can see through the wall from the outside and the garden itself seems quite small. The upside of the whole adventure is that the garden is sandwiched between China town and Darling Harbour, both of which offer hours of browsing and entertainment of all kinds for whatever you are willing to pay.

Peaceful, Beautiful Garden. Established about 25 years ago, these Chinese Gardens are a welcomed sanctuary from the CBD hustle. The many traditional elements built into the design really make it a tranquil and relaxing space. Take your time, enjoy the many nooks and features, and you will be recharged. Take a book and relax, and relax in the tea gardens. Recommended for a recharging experience.

Lovely. We stumbled upon this purely by accident and decided to go in on a whim. So glad we did, it was $6 to get in, but wow it is simply breath taking, We saw a lizard of some type which we figured was fake but nope that was real.Perfect place to just take a deep breath and have a wee wander and time will seemingly stand still.Check out the koi's and the awesome waterfalls. Highly recommend
Pretty place to spend 40 minutes. Cheap entry compared to other places in Sydney. Pleasant walk around the gardens.fantastically tranquil place in the middle of a city!

A quiet retreat. One of the best gardens in Sydney.A perfect retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city.Spend half an hour in this garden and all your cares will fade away and calmness will envelop your being.
Worth a visit. Fantastic gardens and setting, lovely cafe as well. Look out for the water dragons.Great place for photo's.

Peaceful setting in the middle of the city. Walked to the garden from our hotel because it was recommended by the receptionist. We thought it was free but there was a $6 fee. We decided to go for it. The gardens are beautiful, peaceful, serene. Water features, stone gates, huge koi in ponds, ducks, brick paths are here and there in the garden.You can rent costumes to feel like you are in Imperial China and take pictures throughout the garden. There is an areas where you can order tea and sandwiches and then eat them next to a pond.Would recommend visiting if you are in the area.

Stunning place to visit. The grounds were stunning, they had a lot of beautiful flowers, and wildlife it was so peaceful. There bonsai trees were the largest I have ever seen. They had two Japanese ladies there. I could not resist the opportunity to dress in the tradition Japanese way.
Oasis in the city. Love these gardens, very restful in the bustle of the city. Cafe was also good value. Wish we had something like it in Melbourne.
Peaceful and free. Good for a relaxing walk. Near to the shopping areas and chinatown. A nice respite amidst a bustling city

Lots to explore. This is a remarkably SMALL garden, but with landscaping genius, there seems to be endless new vantage points. Each twist of the path brings a new perspective. Very beautiful. There is a small entrance fee, for just a bit more, you can buy a "package" that includes a pot of tea and some dim sim (dim sum). Very pleasant break from the city.

An oasis in the city. We visited the Chinese Gardens which are situated on Darling Harbour. Cheap entry fee which was nice considering a lot of attractions are expensive to get into.A very serene beautiful garden to enjoy with pathways that lead through small temples around the lake. A good place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. There is a small tearoom on site where you can sit and relax and you can also get dressed up in traditional costumes.
Peaceful and relaxing. Although the garden isn'T particularly big it was beautifully laid out and there was so much to see. There were sunny and shady spots, lizards, turtles and huge fish

Beautiful and serene.. Spent a good few hours relaxing and walking around the gardens after a busy morning at the nearby attractions, very peaceful and calming in comparison to the surrounding Darling Harbor.I would definitely recommend paying a little bit extra on entry for tasty dim sum and jasmine tea at the cafe.

Beautiful oasis in the middle of the city. My sister recommended an afternoon in the Chinese Gardens and I was not disappointed! The gardens themselves are beautiful, and we paid a nominal fee to get dressed up in traditional kimono and stroll around - something I won't forget for a long long time.

My favourite Sydney attraction. This is an unspeakably beautiful place. I come here every time I visit Sydney because it's stunning, tranquil, awe-inspiring. A huge amount of planning and artistry must have gone into creating and maintaining this garden and it shows. Everywhere you look is a different but spectacular view, it's almost too good to be true. You don't have to be a garden lover or even interested in Chinese culture to appreciate the dazzling natural beauty of this place.It's easy to get to - wedged between Darling Harbour and Chinatown. If you are staying anywhere in the CBD you can probably easily walk there. It's only $6 entry for adults and there are deals where you can have lunch and drinks included in the entry price (though I haven't tried the food). For this visit, the costume shop was open and I was able to pay $10 extra and be dressed as a 15th century Chinese princess!! You are expertly dressed by people who are obviously passionate about their job and their culture, they then use your camera to take photos of you (don't worry, they tell you how to pose), then they send you out into the garden, in costume, to take more photos for yourself! You can stay in the costume for as long as you want. There are costumes for men and women of all sizes, the women's costumes were gorgeous and the men's looked so cool!! I truly felt like a princess flouncing around the lovely garden in my pretty outfit. Opening times for the costume shop aren't on their website but I'm pretty sure it was from 1pm onwards most days. Koi feeding daily at 11:30am - they are the fattest, biggest koi I have ever seen! Not wheelchair friendly at all.You're a fool if you skip this garden on any visit to Sydney. Please don't deny yourself...

Peaceful little gardens. A thoroughly enjoyable little spot just past the children's playground at Darling Harbour. These gardens really invite you to walk a little, then sit and reflect. You do get the sense that peace and tranquility are foremost here. For seniors or concession holders the cost is only $3.00 so together with the public transport ticket available to seniors for only $2.50 per day (including travel on trains, buses and ferries) this can be an amazingly cheap and enjoyable day out. We did notice a family in Chinese costume and later found that it is possible for both children and adults to hire these costumes and wear them whilst visiting the gardens.
Nice Sanctuary. We started our morning by visiting the Chinese Garden of Friendship located close to the hotel and Darling Harbour. It is a nice sanctuary in the middle of a buzzing city.

oasis of tranquility. Beautiful gardens, peaceful and calming. A breath of fresh air in the madness of the city. Make sure you visit the tea room and enjoy a cup of tea in the lovely surroundings. A great way to recharge your batteries.

Stunning. This garden near the Powerhouse Museum is simply stunning. From gorgeous fountains to amazing nature, this garden made me mesmerized the entire time. Come to this garden to experience the wonder that this attraction has to offer.

Stunningly beautiful. Loved it , Loved it, Loved it! What a gem to find in the middle of a busy city. Very cheap to enter. $7 or $11 with tea and either scones or dim sims, If I come to Sydney again I will definately come again.

Peaceful. What a tranquil place to visit and the photographic opportunities there are endless. There is a cafe there as well so it is very easy just to sit peacefully and enjoy. Definitely worth a visit

Great Chinese Garden. I already got a sense of splendid when I walked from Darling Quarter to the Chinese Garden of Friendship. A portion of the garden is not blocked off by the tall white Chinese walls so you can see what the garden inside looks like. I and my mom walked to the entrance where we paid our 6 dollar entrance fee each to get in. I had thought that the 6 dollars entry price was fairly expensive for a garden, especially when you are a visitor from Africa, and 6 dollars can get you so much more in Africa. Then again, this is Sydney and it is the 3rd most expensive city in the world. The garden is 100% well maintained and is everything you would expect of a chinese garden. It was pristine and the garden flowed so well, probably because of feng shui principles incorporated into the garden when it was first designed.Enter into the garden and instantly you will be guided by the footpaths to various shelters spots, waterfalls and temples. The paths are well designed with rocks, bamboos growing on the sides, and the reasons for the placements of various objects are well explained on boards placed around the garden. Be ware of swooning birds - they have them in the garden according to the signage, although we were never affected by them.I and my mom took photos everywhere we went. It was just stunning. Before you know it, our garden walk was over and we had reached the exit. The garden is fairly small - similar to all the attractions in Sydney - and therefore it might not have given me as much value for money as I had thought (remember, I'm from Africa and I'm more use to money going further). If you are on a tight budget, I would suggest giving this garden a miss - the reason you are in Sydney is to experience Australia and I think your 6 dollars would be better spent on going to a pub, such as the O Bar at Australian Square where you could see the whole of Sydney.

Beautiful landscaping. It's worth the price of admission to get in... Especially if you have a nice camera. Even during the winter time, the grounds were very beautiful. The leaves on the trees were in fall colors (yellows and oranges). I could see that this would be a great place to take wedding/engagement photos.

A Sydney "Must-See". Wonderful Chinese garden and tea-room presented to the City of Sydney by the Chinese community in celebration of our Bi Centential in 1988.The gardens are a tranquil and colourful retreat displaying all manner of exhibits and facts relating to Chinese spiritual culture and flora. Well designed around water features and falls.The Tea-House offers light snacks and luncheon overlooking the main lake teaming with carp and bird life.For Concession Holders, entry plus Jasmin Tea and 4 dumplings each is $8.00 - great deal in a simply lovely environment. For those who are not into Jasmin Tea and dumplings regular tea/coffee with scones are the alternative.

Beautiful!. Our spur of the moment decision to visit this place was well worth the $6 entry fee. Everywhere you looked there was something magical to discover, from the Koi to the waterfalls to the small paths leading to secret quiet places. There was always a moment to be captured on camera, when we went there was a shop that hired traditional costumes, which added to the experience. A great place to take kids, we would go again.
Garden Lovers a must see attraction. These gardens are really a great attraction in Darling Harbour is a must see attraction in Sydney especially the garden lovers without travelling overseas,

Stunning natural magic, The friendship garden is amazing to wonder with a friend!. The Chinese Garden has an amazing history and was a gift to Sydney! A beautiful gift that can be treasured for many years to come. Its such a tranquil and beautiful spot that allows maximum soul searching as you are allured into the depths of a quiet functioning garden that lives and breathes amazing dreams! I was in awe of the ponds and took plenty of pictures of the Coy!Its a nice touch to that I always make time to see when I visit Sydney.!

Peace & Quiet in a busy city. Situated near Darling Harbour they are a step back in time, a good place to spend a couple of hours away from the hustle & Bustle of a busy city, easy to get to easy to look at well worth a look

Serene Garden in the Middle of Chaos. The Chinese Garden was a gift to the city. You can have tea and walk around the grounds. There are falls, pagoda type structures, walkways and art to bee seen and enjoyed. We found this place very relaxing. On a humorous note, there was a girl dressed in traditional Asian costume walking on a walk near the shop. I thought a picture of her with the scenic background would be perfect. My wife said wait, wait till she puts the cell phone away. Also, some guy, a visitor, was doing a combination of Tai Chi and karate near a pagoda. We thought he must have been inspired by the atmosphere and scenery of this attraction. Still not any worse than characters Los Angeles. The Chinese Garden is worth the time and there is very minimum admission fee.

A piece of Paradise in the Center of the City.. This is a must visit if you are visiting Darling Harbour, this is right at the Entrance of the Darling Harbour, it is nice to do a slow stroll around theTranquil and peaceful Gardens,finish off your visit with a nice Pot of Tea at the Tea House. Regards, Marion.

Pleasant enough, probably went at the wrong time of year. $6 entry is fairly cheap so you can't go wrong. I'm sure Spring would be the best time to visit. If you walk slowly it will take you about half an hour to walk the circuit around the gardens.

hidden paradise in bustling city. After 4 years in Sydney, I've only just discovered this gem. Just gorgeous. In the middle of the busy city, a little pocket of quiet beauty and peace. Take your time, go for a wander, enjoy the serenity. Can't wait to go back in spring to see the blooms (although amongst all that green splendor, I nearly forgot it was winter!). Well worth the $6 entrance fee.
Lovely Garden. Beautiful and very serene. A beautiful sight at every corner. Totally awesome. Enjoyed every minute of our visit.

Just lovely & peaceful. Love this garden. In the midst of the city is this superb beauty and quietude. I truly wish we had time to return for a second look, sit, visit to the cafe to absorb the remarkable delight of the garden. It was worth every penny of the small fee (in Sydney prices terms). If you enjoy an oriental garden you will love this one.Don't miss this - we are very glad we didn't.

Worth the time. I am not a real garden person but we went based on some reviews. This is a beautiful oasis in the middle of a very tourtisty area. The gardens are truly beautiful and unique. There was even a travel show being filmed there when we were visiting.

Tranquil oasis in the heart of Sydney. A photographers paradise with beautiful gardens, pavilions and water features. Lovely coffee shop/restaurant where you can enjoy a cuppa whilst watching the thousands of carp.

Lovely even during winter. Tranquil spot with beautiful trees and ponds and chinese buildings. We walked around and really enjoyed ourselves. If you Get hungry they serve chinese tea In a tea House In the garden. Well worth a visit.

tranquil yet central. For sheer peace and beauty in the centre of the city, make sure you visit this attraction. At $3 for seniors admission you can't beat the value. Whatever time of year you go there, the gardens are sure to impress. It's quite awesome to see these beautiful gardens and and water features with high rise buildings in the background. We were very happy we visited.

Oasis in city. I visited the gardens recently and they were a real surprise such tranquility and great value.There is a lovely waterfall and for a fee its great to dress up in traditional clothes.This is a nice place to just sit and relax for awhile.I would recommend visiting on a sunny day.There is a little cafe for snacks and a drink.You can combine Darling harbour attractions and shops with these gardens.

A litle peice of Heaven. Me and my family visit the Chinese Garden every time we visit Sydney. It is such a peaceful, tranquil and welcoming place. Truly magnificent to find such peace right in the heart of Sydney. W ell worth visiting

Wow Excellent and Peacefull. These wonderful peaceful gardens are right in the heart of Darling Harbour. We didn't feel as though we were in the city at all but as though we had taken a mini holiday to China.
A must for Sydney-siders. Tranquil gardens and good signage. The coy and the waterfalls are still my favourite parts - A nice relaxing place to look around for an hour at a reasonable price

Stunning. Ive always wanted to visit this place and it didn't disappoint the gardens are beautiful.
for a place in the middle of the city its quiet and peaceful and nice spot to take a walk or relax

Garden of tranquility and beauty. If you are interested in garden art, landscaping and beautiful scenery, go see the Chinese Gardens in Sydney.
They are just beautiful and so serene. A beautiful counterpoint to the bustling city.

21 years ago. Went with my sister for her birthday she had not been for 21 years she loved it and enjoyed tea by the water. I felt it was a little dull no colour nice waterfall and lots of places to rest but very plain and not much colour or variety have seen better.

Haven of peace. With the roar of the traffic and the insane activity of Darling Harbour only a step away it is a real pleasure to slip into this peaceful garden, stroll amongst the plants and sit down for a cup of tea by the water.

Sunday Afternoon Tea and Scones. Had an amazing Sunday walking around the Chinese Gardens, the grounds are Beautiful and well maintained, the staff are helpful, and the Garden features are great, I highly recommend seeing the Gardens, it is great family day out.$11 entry with Scones and Tea or DimSim and Tea is something to end the visit on a high, sitting at the cafe by the water is amazing and a Local resident (Lizard) is a good surprise.

Gorgeous. You can forget that you are in the big city when you visit this lovely attraction. It is such a contrast to busy Sydney-quiet, relaxed and sooo beautiful. Perfectly clean and peaceful. You can take a nice little walk, sit on the benches watching fish and birds or even have tea and some snacks. This place makes you relax. Great for taking pictures. Admission fee is low so do not miss the opportunity to see it. Good location-just in Darling Harbour.
What! A peaceful spot at Darling Harbour?. The gardens are wonderful but the most attractive aspect is the peace and calm that descends as soon as you enter the gate.

A place of peace. We went here recently as looking from the outside walls we could see it's beauty. My 4 year old was more interested in looking for Koi fish (and yes they are there). however, my husband and I enjoyed looking at the gardens and strolling along the beautiful pathway. Such a peaceful spot in the middle of Sydney. They also have a café there which looked fabulous (right on the pond) but we arrived late in the afternoon so missed this.

Almost out of place in its location. Such a contrast to its neighbouring environment, it is a haven of peace and tranquility.A very pretty garden and definitely a peacful alternative to the stress and bustle that goes on around it.
Impressive . Very nice garden and worth the low price of admission. Amazing what they achieved with such a small area, great for taking photos, lots of pretty peaceful backgrounds.

Do not miss this Oasis of Tranquility!. Modest entry price for which you can spend as long or as little as you like in there.We paid a little extra which included afternoon chinese tea and dim sums in the waterside cafe which were excellent (scones and cream were also available). This is a real tranquil garden in the middle of the bustling city, and whisks you away to a different world. There are so many nooks and crannies, differing levels, waterfalls, pagodas all set around the main lake. There are a number of areas to sit and contemplate the world together with great photo opportunities. We had our group photo taken by the Emperor complete with ceremonial sword (you can hire costumes and really become immersed in the experience). There is a great deal of flora and fauna to photograph as well. All in all we had a great afternoon. This is a 'must do' whilst in Sydney!!

This is really a must see. In the middle of the city the most amazing peaceful spot I think you could find, it is simply an amazing place and every aspect is a joy, so well laid out, make sure you take a good camera and spare SD card.
Chinese Garden of Friendship Sydney. After a hectic morning in the City shops these gardens were a beautiful oasis of tranquility. The food great, as was everything about the venue. A must to visit.

A peaceful respite from the city trappings.. It costs $6 AUD for an Adult to visit for as long as you would like (single entry though).Despite seeing the huge buildings of Sydney looming over you, this little Oasis strips all cares and stresses away. It’s easy to pretend you are not in the city, until the odd siren pops you back into reality.There is a little café (with limited food selection at average Sydney prices) which is very lovely to sit in and have some of the teas they have on offer, while watching the coy and ducks fight for any scraps tossed their way. You can also bring your own food in.The grounds are so meticulously preserved and surprisingly extensive. It is a wonderful opportunity for any one who enjoys photography of landscapes and wildlife; being home to a wide selection of birds who roost here and some of the beautiful eastern water dragons.Always a great place to pop into on a day off.
Amazing. right in the centre of town once inside it seems like you are a world away with trails and paths to follow the plants, fish, birds & lizards in the garden are great to watch DO IT.
Peaceful city oasis. Very peaceful despite its city location. The price was very reasonable at $6 for an hour or so of quiet respite from the masses at Darling Harbour. Simply beautiful.

A bit of paradise in a busy city. This garden is well worth visiting at only $6 AUS per adult. Care has been taken when designing the garden with well laid out areas, places to sit, water features (complete with large carp) and a couple of surprise iguanas/lizards who popped out of nowhere to sit on the rocks nearby. It is conveniently located in central Sydney and is within walking distance from many of the other attractions.

Beautiful garden. I had read about the Chinese gardens as a must see place to visit. Best $6 dollars i ever spent! What a beautifully lanscaped garden, a real oasis of calm right in the middle of busy Darling harbour. A very zen place to see. The waterfalls, the ponds, the koi fish, you name it, it's all beautiful. There is a small cafe where you can buy tea or lunch and sit by the pond to enjoy. Nice experience all around. Do not miss !

slowing down. nearby darling harbour and darling quarters lies the chinese garden, and for a small entrance fee, you reached a sightseeing where you can slow down, it is carefully constructed to "educate" about chinese traditions of gardening, using as a guest the gardens with their pavilions and their ponds. the variety of gardens which had been put into the entire complex is impressive - really a to-do if you are interested in gardening!

A little gem in Darling Harbour. After visiting most of Sydney's attractions this is a refreshing site. Beautifully landscaped with twisting pathways & plenty of waterfalls, pond & sculptures. Easily located - short walk from Darling Harbour. Entry fee reasonable & available discount for pensioners etc. Matured plants & trees are a real gift to the eye & the spirit. Photograph "paradise" as you discover all those special corners & garden rooms. Chinese carvings & motifs including a jade sculptured coach which is breathtaking at the end of your visit. Typical Chinese costumes are available for hire for children as well as adults & these rich colours together with the magnificent background of such a peaceful and relaxing garden is more than a snap shot of your visit. Weddings are also held there & you can find Tea-rooms either inside/outside while you look out & see the fish, pond, water plants & trees around to frame your beautiful view.

Tranquility and calm-- lovely place to relax. Heard about this little garden -- the biggest Chinese garden outside of China--- on the red Sydney Explorer bus. This garden was a gift from the city of Guangzhou in southern Chin to the city of Sydney to mark the 1988 Bicentenary. It is located in Darling Harbour. I decided to visit one afternoon and was not disappointed. If you want to relax , be still, sit and think, or just listen, this is the place to go. There are lots of rocks, plants, trees, water and a small hill with an impressive waterfall, representing the landscape of southern China. There are lots of winding stone pathways and benches to sit. There are many pavilions and sculptures etc. if your would like to dress up in imperial costumes there is a little shop where you can hire silk gowns and pretend you are an Emperor, a princess or a Chinese warrior! If that makes you thirsty , there is a nice tea house also. There is a small admission fee-- 6 Australian dollars when I visited-- well worth this. Highly recommended.

Peace in the middle of a busy city. Right in the heart of Darling Harbour lies this nice chinese garden. Nothing trilling, just a quiet stroll for an hour along a twisty pathway. Time to relax and feel the peaceful location. Certainly cheap for the money spent. If you have nothing to do, this is certainly recommended.

Oasis to escape city buzz. I love this garden. It is such a nice space, with little meandering pathways, bridges and sculptures. There are koi ponds and water features and it is a very relaxing place so it's great for a break if you have been doing all the really touristy Sydney sites.There is a Tearoom onsite so you can sit and look out over the pond and garden, really tranquil.Highly recommended.

little place to meditate. This place is very unique:-) its a quiet place where you can just meditate :-) my partner and i came here and found a little stall where u can rent costumes and pay for it :-)
peaceful oasis in Sydney. lovely gardens near to Darling Habour , go there to relax and chill out - there is also a nice tea house where you can watch the Koi carp.

Beautiful oasis of calm. We really enjoyed our visit here. We bought the ticket that included lunch which we had in the Tea House overlooking the pond watching the fish. Very tranquil. The path in the gardens twist and turn making full use of the space. Wonderful atmosphere. Highly recommended. Don't forget your camera.
beautiful sanctuary. the gardens have matured beautifully in the 25 years since it was completed. I took a group of interstate visitors through it the other week and they were very impressed

piece in the buzz!!. I've been there with my mum for the first time in years that i'm living in Sydney and i have to say... i couldn't expect anything like that!The place is huge, extremely well mantained, full of native plants, trees and flowers!A big pond in the middle full of fishes makes the atmosphere even more relaxing!The little walk around it gives the opportunity to have a piece of peace during th busy Sydney days!I couldn't even hear the traffic!It was amazing!A real japanese garden in the centre of the city!It's the perfect spot for escaping and relaxing a bit, reading surrounded by nature and calm, and there is a small caffee as well, if you feel thirsty on a hot summer day!It's definitely something to be enjoyed by sydneysiders and tourists, not only once, but every time you need a bit of peace and you can't have a holiday!It's worth and cheap!!
Not that great. As far as Chinese gardens go, this is a small but good example of one. It's in need of a bit of an update but is nice enough for a brief walk and break from the city noise.
Amazing. Absolutely amazing and a must do to escape from the city for a quick moment of serenity (and a few fortune cookies)
Tranquil. Beautiful gardens, relaxing, quiet, great water falls and small lake, both indoor and outdoor features.

Hidden gem. I was not expecting to find such a tranquil place and was so suprised by the beauty of the gardens. I felt like i was actually in china. There was a calm relaxed feeling about the gardens. I loved the sleeping budha, i couldnt find it at first but folllowed the map. I had a drink and sat in the cafe looking out enjoying the beautiful scenery.

Hidden gem, not to be missed!. The most beautiful tranquil place in the middle of a hectic city, the wildlife is fantastic, the architecture is breathtaking , for a small fee, you can wear authentic Chinese outfits and take pictures around the garden ,

Wish it was my backyard!. We visited the Chinese Garden of friendship last weekend with our family of five. Entrance fee $15. Such a beautiful, well maintained garden. Kids enjoyed exploring and looking in the ponds at the numerous fish and turtles. It is suprisingly quiet as well considering it is right on a road and Darling Harbour. You can dress up in traditional Chinese costumes for a fee and then take your own photos throughout the garden. Would definately recommend this as a highlight of Sydney's attractions. Well worth the visit.PS There are steps throughout the garden so a good half of it you can't use a pram. There is a place where you can leave your pram but it is not secure.

Nice. Its a nice Chinese garden in the middle of the city. Very close to Darling Harbour and China town. Has a few architectural items and a (very) nice waterfall. This is the only thing that I liked about it. Apart from that, the huge lake is nice to sit around and relax, but I think the whole place needs a bit more clean up for the amount we pay.

refreshingly relaxing and tranquil. wow what a find. hard to believe this is in the heart of sydney. such beautiful gardens, waterfalls, temples. a lovely afternoon spent walking around the gardens, taking photos and having afternoon tea. a must see.
Lovely spot. This is a lovely quiet spot to come to and wander around. Very relaxing with all the water. Beautiful plants. Very nicely laid out. Good coffee shop too!
Peaceful. The chinese garden is such a lovely peaceful place to visit in such a busy city. Such a pleasant attraction to visit with lovely greenery and water to take a leisurely stroll .

Chinese Garden of Friendship. One of Sydney's highlights, this is not to be missed. I was lucky enough to be there on a Sunday morning just as it opened for business and for the first hour I had the place to myself! Such peace , tranquility and beauty to enjoy without being disturbed! Whether you are a fan of Chinese culture, architecture, horticulture or just a lover of beauty this is the place to visit. The vistas are breathtaking from every angle - pavilions, pagodas, gateways, trees, plants, pools, rock gardens - this place has it all. Black necked storks thrive here and add to the glory of the environment. Even in winter, colourful flowers abound. There is a serenity here that cannot be found in too many other places.

A serenity and beauty on the edge of the freeway,city. These gardens are amazing !Absolutely beautifully set out and maintained . Every individual garden is so well designed . Terrific value for money at $6 a head.Do yourself a favour and spend 1 hr or 2 relaxing and enjoying this wonderful garden.

The most beautiful place I've been. I absolutely loved the Chinese Garden of Friendship and if I'm ever in Sydney again I will definitely be going back! It's very tranquil and beautiful. It only costs $6 entrance which for what you get is an absolute bargain! There's a little restaurant that you can get dumplings and tea, which unfortunately I never tried but it looked really good. I would highly reccommend you visit this place if you are going to Sydney, it's one of my favourite places I've ever visited.

Chinese garden. This is a must visit ,it is located in the Darling Harbour district, the gardens open at 9.30am. we paid $8 entrance which also gave us a cream tea at the end of our visit, yummy.The gardens are just so beautifully designed and maintained,with a walk around path taking you past a lake full of large Coy Carp and some Turtles, at the end of your walk you can enjoy the cream scone and tea and sit in such peaceful surroundings.John Bryan Liverpool Englan

Tranquil wonderland in the middle of hectic city. What a perfect spot to reflect and enjoy the Chinese culture after a hectic day! Wandering around ponds full of colourful fish, taking shelter under the beautiful trees while watching tourists and locals enjoying dressing up in traditional Chinese dress! Taking in the culture of a different land right in the middle of Australia,s most interesting city, Sydney. Well worth the small entrance fee for a full afternoons dalliance.Easy to get t either walking the small distance from the city centre, ferry stop in Darling Harbour or you can take the tourist train and see all the extractions of beautiful Darling Harbour before you enter this paradise called The Chinese Garden of Friendship.

Gorgeous gardens in the city. We so much enjoyed the beautiful peaceful gardens in the heart of Darling Harbour. We really enjoyed the tea deal we bought with our entry ticket it was delicious. One of us had the dim Sims, the other the scones and shared all was great. The gardens are beautifully kept and maintained. We had the bonus of a wedding while we were there. Keep up the amazing work.

A little out of place but a gem. These Chinese gardens, as spectacular as they are, are in an odd spot. Regardless, they're beautiful. If you've got some spare time and are nearby they're definitely worth a visit but if you're strapped for time you may be better giving it a miss.

Beautiful!. Visited the garden right when it opened in the morning. What a delight! There are several vignettes within the garden and all of them are gorgeous! The garden is not that large, but it is very interesting and gorgeous. Well worth the cost of admission.
Absolutley stunning!. These gardens are indeed magical. Very beautiful and tranquil. Located at one end of Darling Harbour, accessible by Hop-on, Hop-of bus, monorail, and ferries. Bring your camera!

SUCH A PEACEFUL PLACE. In the midst of such a busy city, the Chinese Garden of Friendship is an oasis of peace and tranquility. We had visited the gardens on an earlier visit to Sydney and just had to go again as it was somewhere that had stuck in my mind as being so beautiful. We spent over an hour wandering around the various paths leading to one beautiful vantage point after another. Clicking away, it wasn't long before I'd taken around 50 photos. The water is full of beautiful carp and we were also lucky to see a bearded dragon and turtles. The gardens are immaculately cared for and there's a couple of beautiful waterfalls which block out the sounds of the city. There are bench type seats in lots of places so you can sit and take in the whole experience.We went on a Saturday morning and it wasn't busy at all and for the price of entry, it's got to be one of the best value attractions around at $6 each. There was a wedding booked for the day we went but that didn't make too much difference to our experience and we were lucky enough to see the bridal party arrive just as we were leaving. I can't imagine a more perfect place for wedding photos. I would highly recommend a visit to the Gardens when visiting Sydney - you won't regret it.

Pretty and calm Chinese garden. I went to visit the garden with my son on a Sunday, but it was not too busy. The garden is very nice and tranquil. It's quite small, but I guess it's already good being in the harbour area. As you'd expect, loads of plants, trees, water and Chinese structures. It did feel like we were in a different place for a moment. Very well kept indeed.

Hidden Gem Found In The Chinese Garden Of Friendship. In March, 2013, my wife and I visited the Garden of Frfiendship located at Darling Harbour in Sydney, Australia.We almost did not get around to it, but went with a couple of days to go in our vacation. We were delighted we included a visit to this oasis of peace in the frenetic world of the city.The entrance fee was a mere $6.00 each and once in there it seemed like a magestic fairyland of beauty, grace and peace. We spent about 90 minutes there and took probably about 75 photos. It was awesome, clearly one of the best things we did on our 23-day trip to Australia. I highly recommend it ... very highly indeed.Part of the way through this marvelous experience, I realized some of the tension I carry with me had left. It felt so good. My disabled wife and I felt much better. It was uplifting in ways I cannot adequately put into words. You really need to experience this "oasis of peace." I highly recommend it. Set aside an hour at a minimum while in Darling Harbour and visit this place. You will feel better in my opinion.

Chinese Garden of Friendship . In a busy city what a wonderful place to spend 1/2 A day and with so much around to see , with so much in such a small place the different levels ,the walkways ,lots of water ,fish ,water lilies .

Tranquil and different. Such a nice tranquil spot amongst the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Lovely to walk around and see all the different areas, look out for the Carp and water dragons. A little full of tourists but can't help that - its a popular place! 6 AUD great value.

Peace in the centre of all activity. This is one of the best places I visited while in Sydney. There is an entry fee of $6 and the garden is located at southern end of Darling Harbour. I spent two peaceful hours in the garden. The ambience is amazing and you feel relaxed. There is a small shop from where you can rent Chinese traditional costumes to take pictures in the garden (around $10-15).There is also a small cafe at the end of the garden which has many varieties of tea to choose from. It takes about an hour to go around the garden but I would recommend enjoying the experience in about 2 hours.

One of the best things in Sydney. Highly recommended, a good hour spent there. Apart from the gardens being visually very beautiful, the gardens gave an insight into the friendship between China and Australia. The pathway was strewn with information plaques describing the symbolism of the garden and the stories behind its creation. The tea house at the end of the walk is a beautiful place to sip tea overlooking the pond and the gardens. You forget you're in a city or even Australia.

Tranquility in a City of Hustle and Bustle. Located on the fringe of Darling Harbour and opposite China Town. Easy to get to by Monorail or City rail and walking distance from other Darling Harbour attractions like the Paddy's Markets, Tumbalong Park, Madam Tussauds etc. We had a lovely time in the Chinese Garden of Friendship. There were 3 entry options. Basic entry is $6 per person. If you want entry and tea and scones in the Tea Garden then best to buy the $11 entry ticket. Then I think there was a $17 ticket which included entry to the gaden and sandwiches and a drink. We paid $6 for my husband to enter and I paid $11 to have the tea and scones. We decided to go to the Tea house first and take in the view of the garden from there over a cup of tea and the scones. The pot of tea was large enough to make 3 cups of tea - so we shared a cuppa with no probs. The scones although lovely and served with jam and cream were on the small side and not the traditional scones we're used to. Nonetheless there were 2 on the plate and enough for us to share. Near the cafe there's a room with a carriage made of jade - the history is astounding - 300t of jade were cut to make the carriage and the finished product only weights 2 tonne. We then enjoyed the journey through the gardens meandering through the different rooms and along the many pathways. This is a magic place to spend a few hours (perhaps reading a good book or sketching while here would be nice too) and best enjoyed when you don't have to rush through it. Access for people with limited mobility could be awkward. Be prepared to see birds, bearded dragons and skinks along the way. The sound of the water cascading over carefully placed rock formations was soothing. There are several pavillions where you can sit and just take in the surroundings. There are so many wonderful photo vantage points. Fish and turtles were seen in the ponds. Weeping willows, jasine, bamboo and frangipani were abundant. Costumes could be hired for $10. We saw 2 lovely girls hire costumes and walk through the gardens and have some fun taking photos.
Nice gardens. this is a beautiful garden asian style located in the heart of sydney cbd, its not the best garden but its nice if you have spare time do visit this place

Beautiful and Peaceful. The garden is beautiful, the Tea house is fairly priced and very good teas and treats to sit and eat with a great view. Good walk around and great photos. Also you could dress up in traditional clothing for your visit, which seemed like great fun, (it was closed when I went as it was raining)

scenic and peaceful. This place has such a serene atmosphere and will provide the perfect photo opportunity for any photographer ... novice to professional. The way the garden is landscaped gives beautiful dimension to the garden wherever the sun is when you visit.

Andrew [nz]. would highly recommend a visit to these gardens. they are located in darling harbour across the road from china town a very pleasant hour spent walking around and sitting watching all the gold fish there are some big ones there

Had a Peep. Was close for maintenace but just a peep inside and a glimpse I managed to catch, it just looked so natural and oriental. One should visit this place as its only 10 min walk by the fountains from Cockle Bay at Circular Quay.

Nice Well Designed Compact Garden. This is a traditional Chinese Garden in the middle of Darling Harbour in Sydney. It is compact but well thought out and informative. It contains all the elements of a traditional garden including the obligatory lake with carps and water lillies, a pavillion, bridges, a waterfall, stone gardens, bonsais, etc. Worth the $6 entry price.

Don't Miss This Hidden Oasis. It is hard to find a quiet oasis in a large city but right in the busy Darling Harbour area of Sydney is a truly hidden gem. This classic Chinese Garden was the result of a collaboration with the Chinese City of Guangdong. It must be among the best of urban Chinese Gardens in the world and is a wonderful place to go for a peaceful escape and moments of contemplation. Despite bordering a busy city freeway it is hidden, cool, and quiet. It is reasonably priced and there is a nice area for tea or light meals. We would never miss repeat visits in this wonderful city and a good plan is to go by ferry from Circular Quay to Darling Harbour. You can combine it with visits to the many amenities around Darling Harbour including the National Maritime Museum with Cook's replica "Endeavour." There are lots of restaurants and coffee bars along the way.if you don't eat at the Gardens.

Serene oasis in the heart of the city. Chose your season - spring, summer, fall - all offer a beautiful garden, with a walking path, pools and a tea pavilion. You can find a quiet corner for your meditation or just enjoy the views.

What a surprise. I visited the Chinese Garden of Friendship as part of a morning in the Darling Harbour area of Sydney. This place is like Dr Who's Tardis! The main entrance gives little clue as to what lies behind. After the hustle and bustle of dodging the tour groups in the other areas of the harbour it was a welcome opportunity to just sit and relax. The garden is beautifully designed and constructed and admission fees are very fair. Didn't eat in the Tea Room but it looked lovely.
Little yu garden of shanghai. I like it being a Chinese blood myself the park is so peaceful and well spread! I was in a hurry for this visit, give yourself at least one hour for this attraction

A peaceful garden amidst the City buzz. Take the time to stroll through this peaceful and serene place to get away from the rush of the city. Meander along the pathways over bridges and by pavillions and streams around the lake. Don't miss the Emperor's Jade Carriage and the Dragon Wall. The atmosphere for us was increased by a Chinese wedding party taking place in one of the pavilions.

Tranquil haven in the CBD. The Gardens are extraordinary - you can't see the entire layout from any one point so are enticed to explore all the different nooks and crannies. Words don't do this place justice - go and see for yourself.

An oasis in the middle of a busy city. You MUST visit the gardens if you like beautiful places! Everything about them is just stunning. The rocks are all specially chosen because they resemble animals, and everything is placed carefully according to feng shui. There are beautiful water falls, still pools of clear water with koi swimming around and beautiful lily pads. All the buildings are traditional Chinese style with pergola roofs and paper lanturns, and then you look up and see the Sydney sky scrapers and it feels really surreal! You can have scones and tea, or dim sum in the garden, which unfortunately we were too late for, but the benefit to visiting the garden late in the day was that there were not many people there, and after being given the '5 minutes til closing' warning the whole garden emptied and we were able to get our best photos! I think it cost $6 each to get in or $13 plus tea/scones/dim sum and is definitely worth it! While you are there look out for huge lizzards as we saw a couple just chilling in the sun!
Peace and serinity within the CBD of Sydney. A magnificent garden in the heart of Sydney. Beautiful gardens with lots to see and a place to sit and feel tranquil.

A great getaway in the hear of the city. Tucked away, behind Chinatown and Darling Harbour, I was very pleasantly surprised when I entered into the garden. It really is a very calming and tranquil escape from the chaos of Sydney, offering a glimpse into the amazing world of Chinese gardens. It offers up some very beautiful views of nature intertwined with traditional Chinese design. The garden offered up some much appreciated shade on a blazing summer day, and it took about an hour to wind through it. In addition to the garden, they also have a tea house and a stunning jade carriage to admire. Given its central location, low cost, and ease of passing through, I would highly recommend this to any visitor of Sydney, or even to a resident who needs to take respite from the daily grind.
a little China in Sydney. I have never been in China but it is close to what I see in the movies. Very well taken care of. it's a nice walk that cost so little and worth it.
Chinese Gardens. A very nice spot to walk through you never feel like you are in a very busy city very relaxing and interesting

The Best Place in Sydney to take a relaxing break from the hustle and bustle. This garden is a beautiful peaceful oasis in the sydney CBD not far from Darling Harbour. It is best to plan for 2 hours at least which will give time to stroll through the garden and have a cup of tea in the tea house. One can witness Carp feedings in the mornings at 11 am and also dress as a chinese princess or warrior in stroll through the garden in full character. great fun for the kids. It is a very peaceful place with little pockets where one can just sit and contemplate. There is a very reasonable entrance fee and one can choose entrance with food packages which makes it very reasonable. Highly recommended as a must visit.
Beautiful Compact Gardens. Lovely, chinese buildings, ponds and waterfall in a lush garden with a nice restaurant and plenty of places to sit and enjoy the views and relax

Beautiful spot for a leisurely walk. Unfortunately for me, my kids were not up for a leisurely walk, but preferred a sprint. I would highly recommend a visit though. The gardens were larger than I thought, I interesting signage appeared to explain the placement of different items (I couldn't read most of the signs during my sprint.) Some people rented costumes and could walk around the gardens in them. The cost seemed quite reasonable.

Peaceful Oasis in the city. A very lovely and well designed Chinese garden right at the base of Darling Harbor. My ticket included entry plus tea and snack which was eleven dollars so pretty reasonable. I was slightly disappointed they only take Australian students for concession- not international students. Still, the garden was really lovely and peaceful with very large coy, amazing rock forms, and diverse plant species. Although we did not take advantage of the authentic dress option, it was fun to see those who did wandering through the garden! Recommended.

Great Time Out. A group of 6 of us had an hour to kill and this was lovely way just to chill out int he heart of Sydney. You could take longer but just to walk and chat and hear the running water. Didn't use the cafe so can't make any comments. I am not a city boy so really liked the sense of calm. I have walked past it so many times when working in Sydney. Would happily go back
Tranquility. I love it here. Take some time out, clear your head in this inner city sanctuary. It doesn't matter how many people are here it is always so very peaceful.

A great oasis in the city centre. A lovely spot to wander and not too expensive at $15 for a family. Beautiful calming waterfalls, paths winding through trees and resting places. The lotus flowers are spectacular and the carp are massive. Great break from the city hustle and bustle.
beautiful oasis in the middle of the city. To spend 30 minutes wandering through these gardens is pure heaven, it is a beautiful oasis. Also take your camera there are great photo opportunites.

A piece of China in the CBD. These gardens are beauitiful. I got in on a student ticket so I think it was like $4 entry. The gardens make you feel liek you are in China, so much so that when my friends saw pictures of me there on facebook they commented saying "when did you go to china??" There is an operator in there where you can rent traditional chinese costumes which is cheap and a fun experience to roam around the pagodas in traditional silks and headdresses. I'd say this was a fun experience for anyone wanting to do something a bit different in the city!

Nice and serene in the centre of the city. I've walked past the outside many times and wondered what it would be like inside. It is very well set out with lovely paths and different plants throughout the garden, plenty of places to sit down and take in the scenery. Nice tea room as well.

Amazing garden in the middle of the city. Very nice chinese garden on the middle of the city.The kids loved the lakes, water fall and big fishes.It is a place to go trough and spend a small time with the kids taking some photos.

Peaceful garden with admission fee. Small peaceful garden in the middle of the city. Note: there is an AUD$6 admission fee which may be worth paying if you're only going to be in that part of town but consider visiting the Royal Botannic Gardens instead which are only a short stroll from the Opera House.

Possibly the best visitor attraction in Sydney. This place is possibly the best attarction in Sydney. The gardens are just beautiful and so very peaceful. We had expected to have a wander through and move on but we lingered for hours. There is a costume hire in the middle of the gardens which allows you to dress up as emporer and Emporess for just $20 and it really changes your deportment and experience of the gardens. well worth the money.And when you need a rest for relaxing pop over to the tea room and have some Chinese delicacies and obviously tea!

oasis in the city. i was a bit put off paying a fee, but its less than $8 and these gardens are truly amazing. im not sure how they compare to other chinese gardens, but the landscaping is breathtaking. it can get a bit busy though.

The poor fish!. This is one of those places you should go to by yourself, especially without small children because it is NOT pram friendly. You will be free to meander on the path at your own pace, stopping to smell the roses at your leisure. However, I will not be returning. The water is dirty and opaque, so the poor fish were all huddled together at the waterfalls trying to get some "air." I saw several dead koi floating about where there was no movement in the water. Sad.

Small but good. It is quite small, won't take up much of your time. It is quite authentic to what I have seen in China. I'd recommend it for a change of pace if you're in Darling Harbour, but not something I would go out of my way for.

Nice change of pace. I enjoyed a stroll around these gardens although my 2 and 4yr old were not so keen to spend so much time looking as I was. They are beautifully maintained and worth the small admission price.
east meets west. very peaceful place to go and unwind if needed.been a couple of times and love it.took my wife there for a 1st date and she was thrilled

how many chinese gardens can one see?. how many chinese gardens can one see? there is more to sydney in a unique sense than a chinese garden, but if this is what you like, then stop at the macdonalds that is is 50meters away for a feed, just to be different
Heaven. Heavenly escape in the heart of a busy city. Absolutely beautiful. Don't look up at the tall buildings around you and be taken away by this beautiful garden

Nice but small. The gardens are nice but they are on the small side. I have to be honest and say I don't think the entry fee is really worth it. I have only been there once because of the price, but would go more often if it was cheaper.

Worth a visit. Fantastic gardens and water features. relaxing and peaceful. Wondered about the number of people in Chinese dress, then realised that there had been a Chinese wedding in the gardens which added to the ambience immensely!

Chinese Garden. This has got to be a must for people visiting Sydney if they want some peace and serenity away from the hustle and bustle of the city. This is a beautiful place in the middle of the city where you can relax and enjoy some well deserved downtime. It is only £6 dollars per person so well within most peoples budget
I liked it. The $6 was fine. I thought the garden was lovely. It had a cafe so that was good. Took heaps of photos. Some kids were playing dress ups in Chinese clothes!!
Blissful. Worth the small admission- you'll feel re-energized and miles from Sydney's chaos. Also a good digestif after a delicious China or Thai town lunch.
oasis in the middle of CBD. its such a beautiful place, calm, & great place to catch up afternoon snack, in such a surrounding, love their selection of teas

Rest A While. Visiting Sydney with an old friend I hadn't seen for 30 years, the Garden of Friendship seemed like an obvious choice. Wandered around and sat for a while between the hustle of being tourists in a busy city. Makes a good rest stop in itinerary if you are "doing" Darling Harbour. Cost $6 entry.

Absolutely beautiful!. Wonderful garden close to Darling harbour. The garden is beautiful and has a lot of places where you can sit down and just enjoy the views. Take the self-guided tour and read the signs that are placed around the garden and that gives you a good idea of how a Chinese garden is planned and why. An interesting contrast is the tall-rised building you see around the garden, the city meets zen.

Peace in the heart of Sydney. This is one of the best places in Sydney as far as I am concerned. It is a beautiful, peaceful place where you can step away from an hour or so and forget the crazy, noisy city life. The gardens are beautiful and there is a great tea room where you can sit and look out over the water and have a bite to eat.

Good chillout spot.. Just arrived on the red-eye flight? Five hours to wait before you can check in to your hotel?Tired and irritable? Then this is the perfect place to relax and close your eyes in a tranquil, quiet haven.

A Place to Lift Your Spirits. Beautifully laid out, totally magical and inspiring. A place to meditate and shut out the world! I've been here when the workmen were outside with their pneumatic drills, making a complete ruckus - and yet, if you let the energy of the garden get to you, even this loud noise disappears. Highly recommended. And if you want to get dressed up in Chinese garb for the traditional holiday snap, go for it! Read the signs as you walk around to learn about Chinese myths, legends, and culture.
Magical. I'm so glad we decided to go inside. Beautifully done, nicely designed with stone and water and felt like a magical place.
Nice, boring. Very beautifully laid out, but when it's all said & done, it's a Chinese Garden. Erected as a symbol of Australia's friendship with China. No more.

Absolutely beautiful and tranquil. This is such a little haven in the city. Perfect to wander around in for an hour or so to get away from the hustle and bustle. You can even dress up in amazing traditional royal Chinese costumes for a photo and then they allow you to walk around the gardens all dressed up - great for you and also nice for others to see as adds even more colour and authenticity to the garden. It's not very big so you won't be there for hours, although there are some lovely little spots next to the pond that I intend on going back to on a nice day with a book as its such a nice place to relax.I've not eaten at the tea room but the menu looked lovely with traditional dim sum and other treats. Highly recommended, will definitely be back.

Serenely Beautiful! Worth a Detour to Visit!. I went out of my way to find this serenely beautiful garden. It is surrounded by imposing walls that make finding the entry a bit of a challenge. Once in the graden, I appreciated the walls since they cut off the rush, bustle, and noise of the downtown area surrounding the garden. It is a quiet oasis of peace and one of the most beautiful chinese gardens or even Japanese gardens that I have ever seen.
tranquil and pretty. very beautiful and peaceful place considering it is in the city. very well looked after and can really make u forget you are in australia

An oasis of calm in the busy city.. This beautiful garden is right at the end of Darling Harbour. It is not huge but paths wander up the hill, always near water and you are insulated from the traffic outside. It is tidy, well maintained with carefully chosen planting. This is a wonderful antidote to a day on the tourist treadmill. If I worked in the city I would have my lunch here every day.

Gem of Darling Harbour. I generally find Darling Harbour tacky and charmless, but this garden is like stepping into a patch of ancient China. So peaceful and tranquil, despite the surrounding traffic and buildings. Just wonderful. I had to laugh, though, when the tea-room girl said she couldn't serve scones because the 'kitchen was closed', even though there was a plate with scones, jam and cream in the cake cabinet. Ah well.

Serene, beautiful, and a must for any Sydney visit. I recently visited the Chinese gardens after having not been there for 20 years. They were beautiful back then, but are wondrous now that the trees have grown, and the care to develop and tend them shows. There is a path that winds around a lily lake, past waterfalls and pagodas and fascinating rocks and features. The gardens attract birds, and the lake is filled with some of the most fascinating carp I have ever seen. Indeed, as we sat in the cafe I swear they were playing with each other, and with the ducks that seemed unbothered by having fish nip at their feet. A truly marvellous place that I will visit every time I am in Sydney from now on.
Always Worth A Visit. I visit most trips to sydney for a peaceful break. Well kept and beautiful with plenty to see and relax in.
fantastic day out. one of the most beautiful gardens i have ever seen in my life , well worth the visit and take time to spend every moment you can to take in the breath taking views april 2011

An oasis of calm and tranquillity.. Every time I visit Sydney I try to visit the Chinese Gardens. It provides a great escape from the hustle and bustle of Darling Harbour. Sitting with my pot of green tea was a wonderful escape.

Cool place. It is a beautiful garden and really cheap tickets (like $6) there is also a package for entry + Tea + some meal but we just bought the entry ticket. Lost of Koi fish in the water, beautiful waterfall, we was a little disappointed because some parts were closed, but we enjoyed in general.

Serenity in the City. The Chines gardens are beautiful, they have been carefully crafted and just so purposeful and peaceful. If I worked in the City and was close enough, I would spend every lunch hour here in complete serenity. Kids might get a little bored after awhile, but for those looking for a 5 minutes wind down time, this is the place in the hustle and bustle of the city. Enjoy

Cosy little place. Located between Chinatown and Darling Harbour this little garden is a cosy place to rest and relax after a tired day of touring the town. Though its not huge, however it did resemble a typical Chinese villa with the decor and the vegetation.

Chinese Garden in Sydney's China Town. This is an interesting feature on the edge of Sydney's China Town. Well worth a visit as it is typical of the Classical Gardens I have visited in China, a meandering path featuring the five elements of earth, fire, metal, water and wood. The Garden is a place of tranquility and .contemplation. It is well worth an extended visit of several hours - sitting down and enjoying the immediate view, as each area is a separate view, The pagoda on the top of the 'hill' is beautiful, as are the several pagodas.

love the garden!. It's small but beautiful, a different view from the whole 'modern' vibe Darling Harbor neighborhood.Have a walk around the garden, no rush, and just enjoy the view. There are several great spots in this garden. The admission fee is quite cheap, especially if you are a student:)I took some photos in chinese costume, it was fun!:d
Stunning but small. Really very stunning but on a small scal. Tranquilty in teh heart fo teh city. The koi were a huge hit. Great for back drop photos.

Feng shui in Sydney. This attraction is authentic in its recreation of a proper Chinese memorial. It's situated on the eastern (i.e. city) side of Darling Harbour, and is easily reached on foot or - for the time being - by Monorail.

Beautiful garden. The admission fee is well worth this beautiful garden in the heart of Sydney. There are several great picture spots, and walking around leisurely provides a nice break from the usual rushing about of a large city. Only blemish was one of the temples surrounded by large potted plants that were all knocked down (strange sight).
Wow, a little chinese garden in the middile of a huge city. Beautiful and tranqule, felt like we were in china, I took some photos and they turned out beautifully

Beautiful... beatiful and more beautiful. I was not sure what to expect from a Chinese garden in the middle of Australia, but after reading that it was built to emphasize the economic and political bonds between the two countries, I could not resist. Never been to China, so I don't know how authentic it is, but it is most definitely BEAUTIFUL.And this aint no tiny garden either. It has quite a few different sections and miniature versions of what I suppose you'd see in a real Chinese garden, complete with explanations. There was a couple just lounging under one of the trees, which I found odd for a tourist attraction, but guess that's what some people do. Another couple was taking wedding pics through out with their photographer and entourage. Excellent idea.I, on the other hand, loved going up and down the various walk-ways and mini-hills. The garden has clearly been built with much TLC and they maintain it quite well. I enjoyed all the water features and mini water-falls. The best thing about the garden is that it is in stark contrast to the rest of the overly commercial elements in Darling Harbour.

Was closed!!. We were looking forward to visiting this and upon our arrival we found it was closed for the filming of Wolverine but who cares we got to see Hugh Jackman and he was very polite to the young ones in the crowd who asked for photos and autographs.
Worth a trip. So relaxing was worth the trip, the little one loved walking around the park and seeing the fish in the lakes, just a shame we only did a flying visit
Absolutely PERFECT. Its vacinity to China Town as well as its peaceful atmosphear right next to a thriving area. The people who initiated this should be highly comended & honoured for their efforts.

Well worth a visit.. Always gorgeous, no matter the season, these gardens are great for a short visit, or a slow contemplative walk. I love them, and visit whenever I have time in the Darling Harbour area.

Great place to relax. Last weekend, we went to visit a hidden treasure of Sydney, in the middle of the city in Darling Harbour.Initiated by the local Chinese community to share their rich cultural heritage and celebrate Australia's 1988 Bicentenary, the Chinese Garden is the result of a close bond of friendship and cooperation between the sister cities of Sydney and Guangzhou in Guangdong Province, China. The Chinese Garden of Friendship was designed by Sydney's Chinese sister city, Guangzhou.Even though I have been living in Australia for so long I have never been inside the Chinese garden. I have walked past the garden numerous times but for some reason never thought to go inside.
