Last weekend the weather was so good that I and my husband decided that we must go out and enjoy the sunny day. So we took a train to the city and walked to Darling Harbour from Town Hall train station.We were in the garden by 11am and there were only 3 people on the queue to get tickets to go inside. We got the ticket and it cost us just $6.00. We started our tour from the right hand side door of the garden.The whole garden cannot be seen from any one point within the garden. It has a number of features including the Dragon Wall symbolizing the bond between New South Wales and Guangzhou, the Water Pavilion of Lotus Fragrance, the Twin Pavilion and The Tea House that offers traditional Chinese tea and other refreshments. The garden is a popular venue for weddings, providing many beautiful backgrounds for photographs.We were there to enjoy the day so we just walked around the garden and enjoyed the sun taking photos from time to time. There was a big pond in the middle of the garden and it had big colourful fishes. I actually forgot that we were in the middle of the city once we were inside. As spring has started here, there were so my beautiful flowers in the garden. I just loved everything in it: the trees, well-trimmed plants, beautiful spring flowers, calm lotus pond and the magnificent temple.It was peaceful, serene, beautiful and calming. There is a waterfall which gives the feeling that you are in some national park. There are some alcoves to rest and overlook the whole garden to just soak in its natural beauty. We took so many photos as wherever I turned there was a beautiful view. The garden isn't large but there are plenty of places to sit and take in the views. It took us about an hour to meander through the garden.We saw a beautiful bridal carriage which is the imperial bridal carriage was used by Chinese Emperors in ancient times with extremely ornamental decorations. The jade carriage is typical of the historical carriages of past dynasties. It is believed 100 skilful artists were engaged in the laborious and intricate carving work. Over 300 tons of raw jade were used, the finished weight approx. 2 tons.The carriage has a canopy decorated with entwining dragon motif with two lanterns in front. The main body of the carriage is carved into elaborate openwork of dragon, phoenix and fairies which are the symbol of Luck, Prestige and Authority. The two front shafts are cut as two lively charging dragons, guiding the carriage. Behind the carriage are two ornamental fans, which symbolise Royal Dignity.The age and the cost of the carriage are unknown, however it is believed the carriage came from the Chinese Province of Guangdong and it is said to be the only carriage known to be outside China.As we were walking around we saw a few people wearing traditional Chinese costumes and taking photos so we decided to find out more about it. We found a place in one corner of garden where you can hire a costume for $10 and pretend to be a Princess/Queen/Emperor/Empress. They let you roam the garden with the costumes as long as you like and parade around the gardens and take as many photos as you like.So me and my husband decided to dress up as well and become Chinese for a while. I choose a red dress and the lady in the shop helped me to do my hair. AS choose a dark blue one and even got a long white beard to try with his costume. Once we were dressed, the lady from the shop took a few of our photos. From there we walked the whole garden taking photos in different locations. We felt like we were in some movie walking around in the costumes and taking photos. Lots of people stopped to look at us and a few even asked us to pose so they could take a photo of us . It was a really interesting experience to feel like we were in China. If you feel hungry there is a teahouse. You can also hire a 45-minute audio tour in English and Mandarin, if you like.For the price, we had an amazing day, relaxing and wonderful.

OK way to spend an hour or two. This place was very pretty - I'll give it that. It was smack dab in the middle of a busy area but felt very serene. But, given the chance, I don't think we'd choose to pay to walk through this again. It was basically a small walking tour of a pretty garden, and for that, I felt it was overpriced at $6 a piece. If it was free, or even just a couple of dollars, we'd probably give it higher reviews because it was really very pretty. But, I just don't know that I see the value given what we paid.

So beautiful and so peaceful. So beautiful and so peaceful and so unexpected in the middle of the city!!There were 6 of us ranging in ages from 5 to 69 and everysingle one of us thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the gardens, which are easily accessed from Darling Harbour, the monorail or a 10 minute walk from Central Station.It is so stunningly beautiful with so many different areas to explore and wander around, with many areas that you just feel so totally compelled to stop and just be.....

So peaceful in the middle of a busy city. We thoroughly enjoyed our time spent wandering around the Chinese Gardens. Admission was only $6.00 per adult and it was money well spent. It was peaceful, serene, beautiful, calming, spiritual. A real oasis in a bustling city. We had morning tea in the tea house and could have sat for hours listening to the waterfalls and bird life and watching the fish swim by in the water.

Serene & beautiful, a must visit for garden lovers. Lovely place to appreciate flowers in this little hideaway within a concrete jungle. Once you're inside, you'll soon forget that you're in the middle of the bustling Sydney CBD, it is just so peaceful and serene in side. For a small fee, you and your family can dress up in medieval Chinese costumes and pretend you're a Princess/Queen/Emperor, they also let you roam around the garden in the full costume so you can pretend you owned the place like they do in China. Loved every minute of it!!

Peace. There is nothing to dislike about this oasis of serenity in the middle of very exciting Darling Harbour. My heart felt at peace, I could feel my heart rate slowing as I breathed in the sensuous beauty. It was remarkable.

A must for garden lovers. Truly a little gem with the beautiful gardens in the city well worth the small entry fee , has restaurants inside for dining in, very peaceful and serene a touch of paradise in the city

Serenity, Gardens and Koi Fish. I went there with my wife a little under sufferance and was I surprised! This is one of the most serene places in Sydney. Lovely gardens very well laid out and so, so well looked after. It seems to shield the traffic noise and offer complete relaxation. The waterfalls, rocks, yes rocks are fascinating and give the feeling that one is in China. The Koi Carp are beautiful and I understand very valuable. Make sure you are there at 11.30 on most days to watch these fish getting fed. This is a very good value for money place to visit.

Loved it. Will return.. This place is a little oasis in the middle of a big city. If you want a peaceful place to visit this is it. Look for the lizards and the turtles. If you have time, have a cup of tea in the restaurant. Our daughter got married here in 2009 and it was just perfect.

A Little Piece of China. We spent 2 hours in this magnificent garden in Darling Harbour. Tranquil and peaceful, beautifully planted and maintained, it's the perfect place to unwind from the hectic pace of the city. As well as ponds and waterfalls, it features several picturesque pavilions. This unique garden is truly a photographer's dream!

Peace and Tranquility in the city. The Chinese certainly know how to create an aura of peace and tranquility in their gardens. The harmony between water, rocks and plants was very soothing. I took so many photos my camera battery gave up but wherever I turned there was a beautiful view. It is a perfect place to chill out after the noise and hurry of the city. The garden isn't large but there are plenty of places to sit and take in the views. The backdrop of huge skyscrapers on one side and the harbour on the other emphasise the relaxing atmosphere.

Chinese Garden of Friendship. It is amazing to have such a stunningly beautiful peaceful garden surrounded by high rise buildings and busy traffic. I loved this place, it is most definitely worth the time to wander around. It is not that big, but here it is quality not quantity. The care of this garden is fantastic. The Chinese tea with pasties was also excellent.
Garden of calm. It was like walking into the Last Emporers palace. So much care and attention has gone into setting it up. So peaceful
Pretty Average. A small garden between Chinatown and Darling Harbour, its not that grand but if you have sometime to kill it wouldn't hurt you to stop in and relax for a little.
Serene. In the heart of Sydney it is a little oasis of serenity. The gardens and surrounds are stunning and you can hire national dress and photograph yourself amongst the bonsai.
Tranquility. Very Tranquil, lots to see but also lots of the same. Really enjoyed the walk around the gardens and up to the top point. Lovely trees, awesome fish pond, very relaxing

A nice green enclave between Chinatown & Darling Harbour. Tokyo has its Hama Rikyu Garden & New York its Central Park, but this paid attraction smack in the middle of Sydney CBD has its serene charm. The central lake is soothing and you might even be greeted by friendly horned lizards along your path.

An unexpected treasure. A gorgeous, serene place. We stumbled across this friendship garden and was surprised at how cheap it was. Adults get in for $6 and children under 12 get in for free throughout August. There isn't a lot to do but it's just beautiful and peaceful. You can also pay extra and get into costume. Would go again (and the food looked good too).

Cultural contrast. Apparently 17% of Sydney's population is Chinese so it's fitting to have a Chinese Garden of Friendship. We like the fact that it blends in with everything else - yet it is different - and easily accessible. Worth a visit.
bored. paid to get in to see nothing what a waste of space right on the harbour. not much to do once in side thje walls

Tranquility. This place is beautiful - such a tranquil place to visit and hard to believe it is the heart of the Sydney CBD. Wandering around the garden was so relaxing. You could just sit anywhere and take time to think, meditate, just enjoy the surrounds. Refreshment stop at the small take-away cafe down stares a 'sticky pork bun' - the bun was very average and the choice of foods here was very limited. The cafe upstairs was closed due to preparation for a private function. I would visit this place again. Entry fee into the garden was low cost and well worth the visit.

Relaxing in the middle of a huge city. I have been to the Chinese Garden of Friendship both times I have been to Sydney. It was most relaxing and inspirational. I spent 3 hours there just sitting taking in the vibes of the grounds. Would recommend a visit there even if its only to walk around.
City Oasis. What a suprise to come upon this lovely garden in the middle of a city.Great place to stroll and get sway from the crowds and enjoy the beautiful garden a real plus to Sydney sights.

A touch of serenity.... I've been there a few times during my 3 years of residency in Sydney, it's a chance to take some time out from the hustle and bustle of the city, unwind and find some 'calm'. Plus, it's beautiful!

Enjoyable Afternoon. My family and I apent a great afternoon here wandering and enjoying the peace and serenity. Would definetly recommend and visitor to Sydney to go there and make a little break away from Darling Harbour/ Cocle Bay Wharf

Peace in the CBD. A relatively small area of land in Sydney's CBD has been transformed into a Chinese horticultural and architectural paradise., with streams, waterfalls, pavilions, and enchanting gardens.

A little piece of paradise. Delightfully planted and landscaped, this well maintained area is well worth a visit by tourists and sydney siders alike. There is a cafe here or you can just walk around the grounds enjoying the view from every spot.
Tranquil and interesting. These gardens are beautiful, with tranquil hidden corners and beautiful ponds. They run lovely events throughout the year such as at Chineese new year and buddahs birthday.

Relief from Chinatown and Darling Harbour. The hustle and bustle of the surrounding precincts can be a drain on your energy levels. The peace and tranquility of the garden is excellent in helping me to restore inner peace.

Peaceful and relaxing garden!. I would advise going here, only $6 and well worth it, looks quite small but when you get in there is more to see than you thought!!! Very relaxing, well worth a stroll!!

A Beautiful Oasis!. Little did I know this place was assembled from scratch. You would never know that if you are visiting this place. It has such a pleasant and calming effect on everyone. You can see people quietly admiring this place. I loved the walk around the place. You would get lost and forget this is right in the middle of a big city.Please do visit this place!

Therapeutic to the souls!. I took an after-meal stroll to the gardens after feeling tired and weary from all the walking around the city. I must say that it is indeed lovely, that soothing Chinese music that calms your senses whilst admiring Chinese art and sculptures, you will leave feeling refreshed and energized! I did!

Very pretty. Excellent design in a surprising location. A tranquil place not far from the busy Sydney CBD. Traditional Chinese clothes can be rented from a shop inside for a short period , no professional photographer, so photos are taken by personal cameras.
Nice but not amazing. Nice but it is quick (30min) and it costs $6. Nice garden and water. Not the bestthing to do in Sydney

What a peaceful place to enjoy.. This beautiful garden take you to another world,you can experience the natural beauty,the waterfalls, lakes and exotic plants. A short distance from the Hay Market o from Darling Harbour, Nice to hire a costume and be transformed into a emperor ,princess or warrior.We have a nice time an the entry were well spent.

A pleasant and peaceful stop. After a very long series of flights from the central US to Australia, we were stuck with quite a few hours before we could check into our hotel, so we were hoping to use the time for something fun but not too straining. This was a great choice. Incredibly beautiful, tranquil, and calming, we wandered around the gardens taking loads of pictures. The water dragons were friendly enough to let us get very close and take some interesting shots. The garden is not very large, but it was an enjoyable stop and I was glad we made the choice to come here. Compared to most Sydney attractions, this place was also not too expensive. Check out the many Asian restaurants in the area, too, there are plenty to choose from.

Peacefully Beautiful. I enjoyed the peaceful walk around the garden, was reasonabiliy priced for a Sydney tourist attraction. Very calming and beautiful location, you forget where you are while your in the garden (This is in the middle of the Sydney city)

Tranquil Change of Gear in Sydney. Whilst visiting the vibrant, modern and busy Darling Harbour we took an hour out to wander the Garden. Was not huge but very pretty and with the lake, waterfalls and pagodas was a diverse change of pace. Not over expensive and gave us a chance to re-charge, the Jade carriage was lovelly.

Brilliant staff!. My friends and i happened to go there on a rainy day and initially they could not let us wear the costumes cause of fear that the rain would ruin them. However, upon hearing that it was our last day in Sydney since we're from Perth, they opened it for us and was really nice and friendly throughout, taking photos for us without any complains. Also, when my boyfriend left his photos in the room thereafter and could not obtain them cause the guy with the key has left, they sent it to his home very promptly and even called to ensure that he had gotten them! It was such exceptional service provided by the staff.

Highly recommend. Such beautiful gardens and kind staff! Sam went out of his way to dress us in wonderful traditional Chinese attire which made for some great photos. In addition to this after leaving Sydney the team at CGoF went out of their way to mail instant photos of my friends I that I had accidentally left in the gardens. Forever greatful, 谢谢！
Lovely Gardens. We love visiting these gardens, they are so peaceful and beauifully presented
Nothing less than lovely. When Darling Harbour was built the gardens were one of the initial places. Lovely to stroll through and be at peace. Gotta go.
love it. I really enjoyed this.So many ideas for your garden.I have wanted to go here for years and never had the time.Glad I went on Saturday,don't miss the jade carriage. WOW.
Beautiful but not enough!. The gardens were lovely and I even dressed in a chinese rented garment... But the space was too small and not much too see
Fun!. Loved getting dressed up in Chinese gear and the women are so friendly! They let you take loads of pictures in the very pleasant gardens for a small fee. The Koy Carp there are huge!
Beautiful and tranquil. An enjoyable place, close to the city but feels like you are 100miles away from the hustle and bustle.

Lovely, peaceful place. The Chinese Garden of Friendship was one of the first things we encountered on our first day in Sydney. I had read reviews that said it was worthwhile, and we definitely found it to be so. Later, when locals asked where we had been and we told them about the garden, they generally said they'd never been, or even never heard of it! The Garden was a gift to Australia upon their bicentennial in 1988. It is quite large and features lots of "bone" (big rocks, bridges, buildings and earth formations) and "blood" (water). There are also many birds, turtles and fish. Oriental gardens are always peaceful and thoughtful places, and this one is quite large and yet extremely private. Highly recommended. Also, don't miss the Jade Imperial Wedding Carriage!

Peaceful Oasis. It is amazing to think that the main road is just the other side of the wall. It is so tranquil in the garden, with lots of waterfalls- well worth a visit. You forget you are in the middle of the city

A great spot, tranquil and photogenic. I really enjoyed my visit here, a great spot, tranquil and photogenic. It is very well designed, a tranquil oasis with the modern city looming around it. Don't forget your camera!

Nice, big gardens. The $6 entry fee might be a little off-putting, but I would say that the Chinese Garden of Friendship is worth it. The gardens are quite large and extensive, with a nice central lake and interesting buildings, gardens and fauna. There is plenty to see and the gardens are good for an hour or so of exploring and just enjoying the view. A nice little oasis in the centre of Sydney.
Enjoyed the contrast to the city. The gardens were quite enjoyable and provided a real contrast to the busy streets next door. Quiet and natural.

Take some down time....... If you find yourself with even just a half hour free do visit The Chinese Garden of Friendship what a tranquil place and a real retreat from the madness of darling harbour. But in saying that the morning we decided to visit it was as if every young child from the sydney suburbs had come to visit boys and girls of about six seven years of age, I think they were on some kind of "Schools Program" as there were specif notes tied to trees for them. They were so cute in their uniforms and were well supervised by their teachers. The gardens are so beautiful not huge and not at all difficult to work through, great for photos, and there was even an opportunity to dress up in the national costume and have a photo taken. A small few souvenirs are on sale and a delightful quint tea shop. Very relaxing.
SERENITY. It was a great place to sit and medidate, in the middle of the hussle and bussle of Sydney. Quite beautiful.
Tranquil...... It a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city. I like popping in when I'm there.

Bhudas birthday. My apologies if I have misspelt Bhudda, but we were lucky enough to time our visit the same time as the festival celebrating the birthday of the Bhudda. Great place with an amazing vibe in the middle of sandstone and concrete

Typical of a Chinese city garden. Having toured China, and visited a number of city gardens there, I found this to be typical of those gardens. A quiet, tranquil and reflective oasis in the middle of the city.My only criticism is, having arrived at the gardens later in the day, I was allowed in, and my peace with my surroundings was shattered when I was asked to leave as they were about to close, but on checking my watch after I left, I noticed that it was still 15 minutes before closing time. I loved the garden, but think there should be a last entry policy, which allows enough time for you to walk round without rushing.

Stunning. The Chinese Gardens are simply stunning. Loved the garden walks, the teahouse, especially the koi ponds and for such a small space they have attained much out of it and looks bigger when you walk around it. Also a great place for a wedding I love going back every few years to check on the trees and gardens etc and I've never been board with it and its always new and exciting

Beautiful Garden. LovelyI absolutely love it when there is hardly anyone there - first thing upon opening is best.It really is an amazing peaceful oasis in the middle of a noisy city.However, like anything, less of an oasis when overrun by tourists and children!Pity you have to pay to get in. I would go every day if it was free.

A great escape from the busy city. We spent about 2 hours looking through the Chinese Gardens. They are well worth a visit if you are looking for some peace and quiet from the busy city. The gardens are magnificant and would be perfect to visit on a hot Sydney day. A lovely cafe serves Chinese and western food. The option of dressing up in traditional Chinese costumes and take photos in the gardens was well worth the money.

Peaceful oasis in the middle of the city. An excellent place to walk, sit and chill out in the middle of the city.
Chinese Garden is well maintained, peaceful and tranquil. There is an option to book the place for a special event (wedding, celebration, function).
The only drawback is that it is not open in the evening, except for special occasions.
Excellent. When visiting this beautiful garden it is hard to believe you are almost in the centre of Sydney. Beautiful, relaxing and well maintained

Secret Garden in the City. This is the absolute most peaceful spot in the City. Hidden down the bottom of China Town it is so relaxing and beautiful words can't express. The gardens are landscaped to perfection and it is actually sad when you get to the end of the garden path. Make sure you try dumplings at the cafe at the end - they are to die for!

Tranquility in the city!. A very good example of a traditional chinese garden in the heart of a major city. It is on the edge of chinatown and is easily accessible from Darling harbour (which is a must for any tourist.) Small entrance fee at the gate but a beautiful area to relax and take time out from the hustle and bustle of city life.

Beautiful gardens, water features and buildings in the heart of the city. The gardens are tucked back from Darling Harbour and are a beautiful place to visit while in Sydney. There are stunning water features, a lake, lots of flowers and plants, and Chinese style buildings. It really is like a little oasis in the city centre, although once inside it is like a tardis and seems to go on for miles!
Relaxing. The gardens were a beautiful serene area right in the middle of the city. It doesn't take long to see the whole gardens, but its nice to spend some time just relaxing.
Sydney Chinatown. This was originally a great place to visit, but it has become a little tired. The upside is the number of excellent Chinese restaurants in the area - something for most budgets.

An oasis of peace.... The garden is a must experience...the quiet solitude in the midst of a bustling city is remarkable. Dress in authentic Chinese period clothing and snap some pics. Best value in Sydney.

Bit of China in the middle of Sydney. I visited this place with my two year old son, who really enjoyed wandering in the garden. I think admission is reasonably priced - compared to several other attractions in Sydney - and it is lovely to feel the peace that lingers in the area among the tall skyscrapers.

A quiet corner to recharge in. I first visited the Chinese Garden in about 1997 and fell in love with the startling juxtaposition of its graceful trees and traditional architecture, against the gleaming, modern outline of Sydney. It's a place I still like to visit as it's a quiet corner of greenery where you can relax and recharge away from the busy streets. Paths meander pleasantly through the garden, taking in lovely vantage points and making it seem much larger than it is.I like the garden in all seasons, but, its a garden, so some might find it a bit miserable when the leaves of Chinese deciduous plants have all fallen in winter, and not so much is flowering. Spring and Summer are full of delights.The only downer at the garden is the teahouse - could be an opportunity for a delicious Chinese tea but unfortunately the food, when I've had it, was rather dry and pre-packaged. It's a shame when you know how good Yum Cha could be.
disappointed, but can be improved. car park problem, very small, not worth going there unless they can expand the garden
tranquil escape in busy city. what a lovely place in centre of city. very similar to garden in Vancouver...nice opportunity to take breath if you are seeing sites...take tea and relax....dont rush

Excellent. I highly recommend a visit to the Chinese Garden of Friendship. While in Sydney it is a nice respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. It is so serene and peaceful inside the garden grounds you forget you are in the heart of a major city.We've visited similar gardens in several Chinese cities. It is obvious the architects and designers went to great lengths to create a space that mirrors those in China.Well worth the $8 admission price.
Do not miss it. Absolutely a must see in Sydney - superb and well worth the nominal admission charge

View from our Hotel. We had been looking over at the gardens from our hotel room and wandered over on our last morning. A peacefull and beautiful spot if you are looking for a quiet moment with spectacular planting, take you coffee or lunch and spent some time in this garden.

A peaceful sanctuary. I would not miss this on any visit to Sydney. It'as such a quiet, peaceful sanctuary in the heart of a very busy, noisy city. Allow at least an hour, stroll around and make lots of rest stops to let it sink in.

Peaceful and tranquil garden oasis in city. We have lived in Sydney for years and never visited this attraction, and it was such a pleasant surprise. It is so beautiful and tranquil, laid out very well, and the gardens are lush and so picturesque. The pond and waterfall are really pretty and the buildings fit in very well. Would defnitely recommend.
A place to relax. Lots to see and do and shop in Darling harbour , these gardens were a good retreat from the hussle of the city.

Serenity in the city. We arrived rather late in the day and would have spent more time if not for our schedule.Well laid out and kept in good "nick", the garden is an inexpensive diversion from what can be a hectic and frenetic area. Close to Chinatown and Circular Key as well as Darling Harbour, the garden is easy to find and worth the effort to visit.

Beautiful & serene. Considering this garden is smack bang in the middle of the city it's amazingly peaceful & quiet. You leave feeling at ease & in wonder of the carved buildings, decorative stone work & choice of plants.

OUTSTANDING. Well worth a visit, inexpensive. It is a real treat to find this little gem tucked away in a far corner of Darling Harbour. This is a must visit, also enjoyed by my husband who would normally have to be dragged into something like this kicking and screaming.......... but not this time.

Takes my breath away every time I visit. A sanctuary from the city in the bustle of Darling Harbour. For such a small fee, take an hour out of your day trying to tick off all the tourist sites, and step inside. It's much larger than it appears from the outside, so incredibly peaceful, lots of nature (wildlife!) and a great spot to have some afternoon tea.As another reviewer said - it's a perfect oasis in the middle of a busy city!$6 adult entry, $15 family.

Place of peace and tranquility.. If you love gardens, peacefulness and reflection, this is awesome... probably not a kids place though. A bit expensive at 16.00 each, but otherwise a must see in Sydney.
Beautiful!. Beautiful scenery. Very oriental and traditional. Amazing and very peaceful. Would recommend for all visiting Sydney.

A little peace in the midst of the bustle. This was a refreshing break in the middle of our day around Darling Harbour. The garden is quite large, and full of calming views and soothing water noises. An enchanting oasis in the middle of a busy city.
A nice oasis in Sydney. A well-designed garden, which is very peaceful. A nice place to wander around.

Full of Eastern Promise. This was a revelation, and on a sunny day must be one of the most pleasant spots in the city. Calm and screened from the traffic by very clever design and lots of trees, it is an oasis of tranquillity in a delightful setting. It is a very picturesque area, with ever-changing views as you progress through the gardens, and there are lots of places to stop, sit, admire and reflect. Great for the young (Mandarin Chinese costumes for hire) and the old (a quiet and welcome tearoom), the modest entrance price should not put you off one of Sydney's loveliest attractions.
A real gem. A wonderful find, beautiful and peaceful. Take a relaxing stroll and have a light lunch by the koi pond.

Relaxing spot in the middle of the city. What a fantastic attraction! It cost $6 per adult to enter and it was worth every cent and more. The garden is stunning with numerous paths taking you into different types of gardens. The lakes are magnificent and full of fish, ducks and birds. If it wasn't for the high rise buidlings surrounding the gardens you could easily forget you are in the middle of a large city. You can hire emperial costumes to dress up and have your photo taken in the garden. There is also a teahouse at the exit of the garden where you can purchase a drink or snack at reasonable prices. Most of the gardens are accesible with a pram which I had with me. There are steps at the back of the gardens which a pram will not go up, but overall I was able to walk around approximately 3/4 of the gardens pushing the pram (there is always the option of leaving the pram and carrying your child up the steps as well).

Very ZEN. Read the first time about the chinese garden of friendship in tripadvisor. It's offers a good break from the city around it. Located near the Chinatown an darling harbour, there's a pleasent contrast between the skyscrappers and this bucolic athmosphere.

It's a garden, that is Chinese. The garden is nice, though relatively small and typical of a Chinese style garden. If you're dying to see this type of thing, it might be worth a visit. The admission is a bit much for what it is, but that's a personal value judgement so you might get more mileage out of it.

Serenity in the city. The entry fee is appreciably modest for such a gem. It's serene and beautiful! Hard to believe it's in the middle of a bustling city. It's easy to get to and a great place to recharge the soul.

A special Place. We spent a few special hours here. It was Valentines day and Romance was definitely in the air with young couples dressing up in traditional costume for photo opportunities. That said, it was not to full that you couldn't find quiet corners alone to just enjoy the peace. You completely forget that you are in the middle of a city. So many beautiful views and a pretty tea room as well.
An oasis in the city. This is a beautiful and most peaceful garden in the midst of the city. Well worth a visit.
What a beautiful place!. This is an excellent attraction near the Darling Harbour. There is so much to see in such a small area. Everything is fantastic to see.

Piece of tranquility. A bit like a tardis when you go into the gardens.Beautifully laid out. My husband said he could have spent hours in the gardensexploring, watching the massive Koi and we saw a turtle and a large lizard.My only disappointment was the tea ceremony area which was like a glorified cafe. I thougt you would be served sitting at low tables sitting on cushions like in a China Tea House.Very peaceful.Can get dressed in traditional costumes if you want to, I don't know if there is an additional cost.

Good one!!!. Good one but don't go with family after 6PM. As it is very close to the Darling harbour and the drunk guys are playing on the kids activities. It is ridiculous and they behaved rudely. It is dangerous for the kids at that time. But all other time it is a good.

Fantastic oasis. It's a great escape in the middle of busy Sydney. There are nooks and crannies that offer great photo op, or just to sit and soak in the relaxing peaceful ambiance. There's also a chance to put on traditional Chinese garb (for a fee) and take as many pics as you want around the area.
sightseeing. Very pretty and unusual. Situated in an easy to reach area with other attractions in same locality.
Great on a fine day. Good for a picnic. Enjoy!!!!. Loved the Chinese way of relaxation. An oasis in Sydney

So photogenic. I went several times. You can dress up in costume and wander around, taking photos. My daughter had a birthday party doing so. The girls (8) all loved it and still talk about it. So relaxing. So pretty.

Delightful spot. It was probably the best Chinese Garden we have seen and we visited some in China itself. The best use was made of the space
available to create beautiful vistas.
Chinese Garden of Friendship. A really lovely surprise; a beautiful intriguing garden with a backdrop of highrise buildings.There is a nice tearoom. Well worth a visit!

Absolutely Brilliant. We were recommended to visit here by a family member and they didn't disappoint! What a beautiful little treasure hidden in an amazing city! The garden is well set out and cleverly arranged with little nooks and crannies awaiting to be discovered. The tea room was lovely with a nice selection of food to offer. The best part for us was dressing up in authentic chinese clothes, there is a small fee to use the costumes however you can roam the gardens in full chinese dress. The staff at the dress up area were brilliant, they came outside and took photos of us and really made us feel special. A word of warning though( I would advise young children against using the head dress as my daughter had nasty visitors in her hair afterwards!) Apart from that, this was in our top 5 places to visit in Sydney!

So peaceful!. This was a delight (gardens are not always my first target) Very uplifting, to amble through reading up the philosophy of the gardens (contrasts between land and water etc) Don,t MISS the jade carriage which is hidden away near the exit (almost seems like it's in a store room - it is exquisite!!!)

Quick moment of oasis. A lovely place for a quick breather after touring the city all day. Went with parents and friends visiting the area. Really feels like you are in a tranquil oriental garden, very calming. Only thing is that some areas need a bit of renovating and others such as the pavilions are a tad dark and could do with lantern/ lighting.

Stunning and Peaceful. I love this place - it is just stunning and so very peaceful. The gardens are magnificenly laid out and when in flower just beautiful. There are so many photo opportunities here - you can spend an hour or three and walk around it again .
Gardens beautiful. We arrived half hour before closing and we got in free, it is a beautiful tranquil oasis in the city.

Photographers Paradise. If you love photo opportunities then this is your place. The garden is peaceful and gorgeous. You need to give yourself at least an hour and a half to full appreciate what the garden has to offer.
Overpriced. Small pretty garden but overpriced for what you are paying for
Better than Shanghai. The Garden is beautiful to see, and admirably maintained. I enjoyed it much more than the 3 gardens I recently visited in Shanghai.
Beautiful. It was a peaceful and beautiful oasis . It is extremely well built and transports you to the far east

Wonderful oasis of beauty and serenity. Nestled between the bustling city and the hard landscape of the Darling Harbour precinct, this garden is a real delight. It is quite small but cleverly designed pathways, a 'mountain' to climb and lovely little structures, one could profit well by taking at least half an hour to explore its many features that make it seem larger than it really is.
chinese garden. Beautiful peaceful place to visit. Nice food in cafe. The other extreme is Paddys market which is close by.
Beautiful. Lovely gardens in the city. Quiet and clean with some astounding architecture and culture. A visit is highly recommended.

Exquisite oasis of calm and greenness in the city. A wonderful place of tranquility, where we spent several hours wandering the snaking pathways through lovely pagodas, fantastic plants, shrubs and trees, The thought to choice of rocks was fantastic to see so many animals and dragons depicted. The koi in the lake were brilliant, and very nice to see them gather when you clapped at the bridge. The school children visiting were charming, and charmed by the sense of calm. A brilliant place not to be missed, and if you are lucky, you can catch a glimpse of people in Chinese costume! Much better than the 2 minutes to view the Opera house. A stunning place!

Serene. This garden costs $6 for Adults to enter..money well spent as these gardens are truly magical...Lovely water features, rockeries, buildings, artworks, fish in ponds and the lake, waterfalls...cafe for snacks and drinks...very peaceful and serene..lots of beautiful plants well looked after.

EXCELLENT. The day we visited there was a traditional Chines wedding, situated in a pagoda overlooking a tranquil pond, what a moment it was lovely. The gardens & pagodas are really beautiful & very traditional, there is a lot of water with plenty of water plants & lots of bamboo. Well worth the visit.

right in the middle of town. a quick walk from sydney harbor and you find this little garden. it was amazing to see how much they fit into the space. koi fish, waterfalls, gazebos, you name it. the koi were HUGE! wish it were bigger. someone was having a wedding in there so i didnt get to see as much as i wanted (fear of being in the way). fun to do and to see the different plants, and we even saw a huge lizard and spider.

Tranquil Stop. It won't take you long to visit this beautiful garden, but it is well worth the admission price. As you wind through the paths to different areas, you will be surprised at how much atmosphere and serenity can be packed into a small space. I would have stayed longer to admire the shape of the trees and the shimmering koi, but my husband isn't one to dally. You may even want to go by yourself so that no one controls the speed at which you can enjoy every small vista. It is truly a world apart.
nothing special. Did the trick - food wise, although it was a catered event. Gardens are lovely. Nice for an afternoon out.

Worth a visit. Located a short walk from Darling Harbour the Chinese Garden of Friendship is worth the visit on a trip to Sydney while in Darling Harbour. You feel as though you are transported to another country & almost forget you are still in the CBD. We saw giant lizards & fish. The waterfall is gorgeous & there are some great photo opportunities. $6 each per adult. We're cheap so this was a bit pricey for us but glad we finally made the visit.
Excellent Little Garden. A little garden hidden in the heart of Sydney and inside Darling Harbour. Definitely worth a look.
Oasis in middle of city. Worth the entry free and you can have afternoon tea in the beautiful surroundings

Hitting its stride. The garden has had a considerable time to get itself established and has an strong and authentic sense to it, being created and overseen by experts from China. It is a haven of peace and tranquillity in the bustle of Australia's largest and most dynamic city and well worth a visit. I grew up with my grandmother's blue Willow Pattern dinner service and this garden always reminds me of that.
is nice. nice place to go... bit expensive though...the cafe they have inside is nice for afternoon tea
beautiful place. we went during chinese new year when it was free. It's really beautiful inside, perfect for those who love to take photos.
Chinese garden. Have developed over the years into a very interesting Chinese garden.
really takes you away to another place. the gardens are really nice to see and the ceramics on display i really liked the dragon with buright colours

Chinese Garden in Sydney. This garden is Beautiful. I'm originally from Oregon and here is a Chinese Garden of Friendship in Portland. The one in Sydney is much larger. The Jade Wedding Carriage is amazing, don't miss it! You can also rent traditional costumes for "authentic" photos.
calm and peaceful surroundings in the hustle and bustle of the city.. A. great place to unwind and enjoy the tranquility of the gardens.The cafe offered a pleasant selection for casual dining

Room within a Room within a Room. The moment you step inside the gates you are transported. There are rooms within rooms & views within views. And it's all within a room in one of the busiest cities in the world, but who would know. You are transported to other worlds & other serenities. Love to go more often.
Boring. Sorry, but you can skip this one. It's a quiet little garden with green plants and fish. It will not rock your world. Perhaps if they had some sort of place where I could take a nap.

A good way to spend an afternoon. A nice quiet walk around the gardens is like going to a different planet!Its nice and quiet in the gardens itself, there is a great pond, waterfall, tea house and many many attractions within the walls. There is a lot of information available about how the garden replicates a traditional private garden. The tea rooms at the end of the path have a beautiful view over the "mountain" area of the garden and its great just to sit, sip some tea and enjoy the afternoon.

Beautiful spot in the middle of the city. I love this place - beautiful gardens, a large Koi pond (well, practically a lake!) Lizards can be easily spotted basking in the sun. Beautiful Chinese decorations, and a lovely tea room. This is one of my favourite spots in Sydney. I highly recommend a visit!

Amazing cultural trip in the middle of Sydney. Absolutely beautiful gardens in the middle of Sydney. Really fun and you can dress up as a Chinese official and get your photos taken. Totally recommend this - it is a quick visit.
So Peaceful.. Loved it. Very peaceful enjoyable place to visit

A Chinese Corner in Sydney. Tucked behind Darling Harbour is a tranquil garden donated to celebrate Australia's 1988 Bicentenary, by the city of Guangzhou in Guangdong Province, China. Stone pathways carry the visitor past ancient doorways, waterfalls, lakes and whispering clumps of bamboo and exotic plants. A traditional Teahouse supplies the appropriate refreshments.

Pretty but small. You just cant escape those sky scrapers in the background, for the money they ask, you expect to linger longer, but you just don't want to as not big enough to forget what's all around you (noise of flyover not good).
Big Fish. Amazing gardens with fantastic man made water feature with the biggest carp fish I have ever seen
One of "Sydneys " best tourist attractions.. 2nd time Ive visited these gardens, & theyre never cease to amaze. SO tranquil walking around.

Don't bother. Yes its very pretty but its small and expensive to visit.
I'd say dont bother and spend your money walking round many more free sites in Sydney. There is so much to see in this city that unless you have a special interest in Chinese culture, its a waste of otherwise valuable tourism time.

Wonderful and well worth the entrance fee!. Don't hesitate even if it is weird to pay admission for a garden. It is completely understandable that for the maintenance of this wonderful garden you need some money and you will not be disappointed if you are looking for an oasis in the middle of the city.You can take wonderful pictures, enjoy the calm atmosphere and watch the fish swim around in the big lake - there is a waterfall and a cascade and you are being guided through with some quiet, relaxing chinese music! Totally recommend it for a good weather's day! I wasn't sure whether it will be worth it but it totally was! It's completely different than the Botanic Gardens but soo relaxing! Enjoy!

Garden of Peace and Weddings. Located at the far end of Darling Harbor complex, the Chinese Gardens of Peace are truly a refuge from bustling Sydney. Popular for those seeking a quieter moment, it's also an ideal spot for a garden wedding. And the wedding party doesn't mind the onlookers surrounding their little ceremony.After the intense moments at Paddy's Market, this is a calming place to regain your thoughts before continuing on to the rest of Darling Harbor's attractions.
Very lovely. A quiet spot in a busy city.. The gardens are very relaxing and lovely to visit.
Fabulous!. Feels_like_you_breifly_leave_sydney_into_a_peaceful_gardin!
One of my favourites. Tucked just in behind the skyscrapers of Sydney, but seems a million miles away. So peaceful. Always a favourite place to visit in Sydney

The best $6 you will spend. Beautiful, well planned gardens and you would not believe you are in the middle of a bustling city.With a bonsai garden to start and work your way round small streams, pagodas, lakes and waterfalls. Huge Koi carp hoping to be fed, and local birdlife preening theirselves. If you are there at midday you can hire a japanese costume for 10$ and take your own photos of yourselves. We had to be somewhere else so we missed it.
Very pretty. I loved the chinese gardens, well worth the $6 per adult to get in, also if time permits i recomend the scones and tea for an extra $5 in the tea house
So peaceful. Until you look up and see the skyscrapers you cannot believe you are in the middle of a city. So much bigger than I expected from the entrance. Don't miss.

Nothing special in a city that has lots to offer. I've been to the Garden of Friendship twice, once by myself, and once when my parents came over for a visit. Both times, it was pleasant, but really nothing special. There is no real atmosphere of calm, mainly because it would be impossible for any garden to shield visitors from the noisy traffic. There is a nice pond, and a few nice trees and plants, but nothing that will wow you in any shape or form. If you're running out of things to do after a week or two, it's probably okay to visit, but otherwise, there are plenty of more exciting things to see. If you're into plants, rather visit the Botanic Gardens.
Beautiful. yes well worth taking some time to sit in a beautiful calm setting. And even enjoy a Chinese tea. A deceptively big garden so much detail. Well looked after.
peace & harmony in a city. being in a busy city it is a breath of fresh air to find such a tranquil place to calm ones self, away from the frenetic tourist path.

Chinese Garden Magic. This oasis in the city is well worth the visit. The trees and plants are exquisitely laid out and it is easy to forget where you are.Are you in Chinese heaven, or two blocks from the megacity of dust and crowds,Sydney. The illusion that you are in the former makes you want to stay and savour its magic.It was especially cute to see a Chinese family with little children in the Gardens, laughing and playing in the little houses and spots where perhaps a dragon or princess might lurk.

An oasis of calm in a very busy city. Took a short hour to savor the wonders of this international collaboration between China and Oz at the initiation of the local Chinese community. Beautiful sight lines reflect the detailed planning that must have occurred. Interesting contrast with the helter skelter layout of Paddy's market and the rest of Sydney's very modern Chinatown.

A lovely oasis in the city. Depending on the time of the year, the gardens can be filled with colour, or quite plain, but the pavillions and ponds are delightful either way. A lovely spot to go for a stroll and have some time out, especially if you want a break from the ugliness of Darling Harbour. Also worth a visit to the tea house for a selection of traditional tea and chinese delicacies. I really love this garden - worth a visit.
Very nice gardens. When we visited this garden it was a lovely day and we were impressed with all the different kinds of plants that were in there would recommend a walk through it to friends

Very tranquil. Each time l go to Darling Harbour l walk from Liverpool Street down past the chinese gardens l feel very at home when going to these sights. l must say if l did not have the commitments that l do in Melbourne l would live in Sydney just for these sights. Must see.

Great gardens. This is a wonderful place to spend a few hours in the middle of a busy city. The gardens are beautiful , enjoy a relaxed stroll or take a book and sit inonne of the quiet benches and read. Easy walking distance from the CBD or Darling Harbour

~A Gem in Sydney & You Can Dress Up In Traditional Chinese Costumes Too!!. ~This place is just lovely! The gardens are beautiful along with the ponds with Koi Fish, and the Pagodas. I really felt like I was in China, and not in Sydney at the southern end of Darling Harbor. The surroundings are just stunning, also there is a tea house to have Traditional Chinese Tea. As we were walking around we noticed people dressed up in gorgeous Chinese Costumes. We were directed to a building where you can dress up, and the kids in Traditional Chinese Costumes (such a bargain I believe it was $5)...just BEAUTIFUL! We got some gorgeous pictures of our kids dressed up with the perfect background! Such a tranquil place. Definitely worth a visit for a nominal fee.

So so peaceful inside the hustle and bussle of Sydney. this is one of my favorite place in Sydney, it is so peaceful. Beautifully maintained and you just get a sense of calm when you are there. Love it

An Oasis. Saw this when it first opened and then again recently - wow how the plants and trees have developed. It is better than i remembered. A quiet oasis in the hubbub of Sydney. Go see for yourself.

Breath of fresh air in smog laden city. Take you time to dodge the hectic pace and slide into the tranquility of some perfumed tea and bikkie on the serene bank of the duck ponds in the middle of the bustling CBD- Charming
little culture. so pretty and you feel like you are in china so beautiful and majestic.

Peaceful, beautiful and relaxing.. Really pleasant environment to experience and be part of. Really is worth a visit. The gardens seem to change with the seasons so it is worth visiting several times.
Relaxing garden in the middle of Sydney. We stumbled upon this place when we walked through Darling Harbour. It was a pleasant surprise. Relaxing garden, nice pictures and a cool atmosphere.
A little oasis of calm.. It was pouring with rain the day we went, but it is a beautiful place...very tranquil, with plenty of places to stop and reflect.
An oasis. On the edge of chinatown and close to the CBD and Darling Harbour, it is an oasis - quiet and restful.

A peaceful oasis in the centre of Sydney. This place is a lovely surprise, once you're through the gates, you're transported to another world, and city life fades away for a little while. You can journey around the gardens at your own pace, which makes it easier to explore all its nooks and crannies. Take the time to sit quietly for a while at one of the seating areas dotted around the gardens.
I go there everytime I'm in Sydney. I just love the gardens, the ponds, the plants and the sense of tranquility.

Dress ups for young and old. Good fun for adults and kids. It is very beautiful and you can hire a traditional Chinese costume and have tea with your kids in the traditional Chinese robes. My kids (girls) love it.
Very nice. Nice and relaxing break from the city heat. Free costume trials were great for children

beautiful peaceful garden. Wow we had no idea how beautiful these gardens were or how big they were. We totally underestimated them and didnt allow enough time to really appreciate the peace and calm of the gardens. Definitely going back next time I am in Sydney to have a better look

A peaceful oasis. A great find for an hour or two out of the city bustle. Lovely water features with waterfalls and small lakes stocked with large koi. Chinese sculptures and informative descriptive plaques help set the scene. This is close to Chinatown so convenient for a visit before or after lunch there

Little haven within busy area. Good place to waste an hour or so of your time. I went with my girlfriend and we found it to be a lovely little tranquil place. People were getting dressed up in full Chinese gear, which looked like fun. THere's not a lot to do though so no more than an hour i would say. Nice little place would go back.

Must do..... We nearly didn't go in as it was the end of the day , our feet were sore and the teens were weary, but we were all so glad we did. It is paradise in the middle of the city. So much to be in awe of and so peaceful . The teens clicked away on their phones more than I did! Do not walk past this sensational place.

An oasis of peace in the middle of the city. Entry is cheap, gardens are awesome in design and looks and loads of info on the design if you wish to read it. We enjoyed the peace, tranquility, green, and the waterfalls in the middle of the city.
Tranquility in Sydney. This place is truly wonderful. The calm an atmosphere is awesome.d relaxing

Brilliant!!. So peaceful & quiet...in the heart of the city!!You can't even see the skycrapers above the trees!A cup of green tea in the Teahouse, watching the birdlife on the lakes. Gorgeous gardens, relaxing walk....right at the doorway to Darling Harbour!

A tranquil place in the middle of Sydney. I visited the gardens about 20 years ago and was not disappointed with my second visit, beautiful gardens and costume hire for visitors is a great idea at a very reasonable price.

Quiet Oasis in a Busy City. This is one of the few Chinese Gardens outside of Asia.It was designed and built by Chinese landscape and gardening craftsmen.It was a gift to Australia on the occasion of its Bicentenary in 1988A small fee to enter and visit the Tea House for a drink and a snack.Great place to relax among beautiful gardens, pagodas and water features in the middle of a busy city.Pick up a self-guided tour brochure.Located next to Chinatown and Sydney Entertainment Centre at the southern end of Darling Harbour complex.Easy walk from the Monorail, LightRail, Central Station or Railway Square Bus Interchange. Worth a visit.
Peaceful oasis. Beautiful tranquil gardens away from the buzz of Darling Harbour. Tea rooms very good.

Serene and lovely and right in the city. This is a beautiful place---I have watched it grow since it was given to Sydney----lovely reflection pools, pagodas, lush greenery, I have taken foreign visitors and they have been impressed also.
Cliche but really is oasis of calm. Even when there are lots of people (and that's is most often) the quiet seeps into the air, and a surprising calm pervades.
Peaceful. This is such a tranquil place to wander around. Beautiful surroundings, nice little pool full of ducks in the middle. Love it!

Fantastic, so serene and in the middle of the city. The gardens are just beautiful, a great place to relax and get some peace and quiet in the city. There is a cafe inside and you can dress up in traditional costumes and get photos if you wish. A small fee to get in and very interesting to do a self guided tour with a brochure. From here it is only a short walk to darling harbour.
Great if you love a garden.. I love this place,makes forget you are in a big city.

Peaceful sanctuary. It's amazing that a Chines Garden right in the middle of Sydney could be so tranquil but we loved it with traditional Chinese pagodas, water features & even some type of water dragons living in the ponds with the koi carp. A small tea room at the end offered nice refreshments.

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens and water features.Our 2 girls loved it - they choose to get dressed up in Chinese costume for $5 each (bargain as it was the highlight of their day). They then wandered through the gardens looking fabulous in their costumes!

Go on a quiet day. This place can get very busy, but on a quiet day it is really spectacular. Gardens use rocks and water very creatively. You can dress up in classic Chinese garb. Makes for nice photo ops throughout the gardens. Tea and admission seems like a good deal, although we didn't try it.

Highly recommended if you love gardens. The Chinese Garden of Friendship must be over 30 years old and is now well established. The area is small, beautifully designed and landscaped, and a quiet respite from the inner city. This garden is located close to Chinatown and Darling Harbour. It is well worth a visit. I enjoy it every time I go to Sydney.

It's surprisingly big. This garden looks smaller but once in the way it is laid out give you a sense it's bigger, it was relaxing and peaceful and interesting to see the different Asian influence and how they set out their gardens. Not a must see but don't rule it out worth it if you need to restore some of your ying or yang.
Many better sights in Sydney.. It is a pleasant place, but if you have a limited time in Sydney, there are many more interesting places to visit.

Nothing Great. The Chinese Garden of Friendship is located close to Darling Harbour, Maybe I have been spoiled from my times in Asia but I really didn't see anything that would make me do more than walk through it, I found it pleasant but uninspiring,
Tranquility in City Centre Location. This was lovely. Very quiet relaxing and tranquil in a city centre location.

Don't miss it. Located at Darling Harbour we visited this small and quiet spot right in the middle of Sydney. Will you need a place to unwind yourself after a hectic day, go there. The atmosphere is so relaxing with a small lake, several waterfalls and beautiful trees. There is even a small place where you for a small fee can be dressed in classical chinese outfit and take a walk in the park to imagine how this would have been 100 years ago. We enjoyed it highly.
OMG. This was amazing, and this is coming from a 19-year old man. Well worth the $5 (I think it's less...) and so calming.
chinese garden. Very peaceful within the city of Sydney. Thoroughly enjoyed walking around at your own pace.
Peace, tranquility and great garden design. The whole experience, from start to the Tea House finish was wonderful. Well worth spending about an hour when in Sydney city.

Something different. This is a fun place to visit. It won't blow you away, but it's a nice oasis in the city. For a bit of fun, you can rent traditional Chinese costumes and get your picture taken. Good for the kids.
Peaceful, lots of Coi carp in the ponds. Good for a shady walk around, but not outstanding like some other gardens we have visited
West of Darling Harbour, Chinese Gardens are well worth a visit. Cheap entry and very nice inside - lots of photo oprtunities, a place many visitors like us will enjoy.
LOVELY PLACE TO STROLL!. Good for something different - wish it was my back yard!

Quiet and serene. Yes, take the time to visit these gardens - beautiful. Take the time to have a cup of tea or bring a coffee in with you so you can just sit and watch the world go by. Brilliant ambience and one of the best spots in the harbour.
Make the effort to see this slice of heaven. Honestly the most peaceful place I went to in sydney
A Lovely time. It has been around 20 years since I was at these gardens, and it is just lovely. The children loved following the map and looking all around the gardens. A nice way to spend 1-2 hours.

Second visit with overseas visitors. I've been here 3 times and it looks beautiful and well cared for. Watch the lizzard, if you are lucky.
Dress up for photos and wonder around the gardens. Very peaceful

An authentic Chinese experience in the heart of Sydney. I have been to Suzhou and Shanghai in China, and these gardens are as Chinese as any you will find there, with the exclusion of crowds and noise that is. The gardens were designed by the Chinese and many items were donated by the Chinese Government. The price is very reasonable and there are some absolutely beautiful spots, particularly near the waterfall. The garden is deceptively big. Take your camera!

The admission is a rip-off but the gardens are beautiful. I came to the gardens not expecting to pay to get in, the price is not worth it! But, we had gone all the way to get here from Sydney city area so we paid it. The gardens are beautiful! Lovely waterfall and temples. The place is a bit small, but you could spend at least a few hours here wandering and relaxing. I must admit, I will probably never come back here though.

Great place to visit if you have an hour or two spare. If you have an hour or two that you want to fill in while you are at Darling Harbour, the Chinese Gardens is a great place to visit. We visited here with our two boys, the cost to get in was $6.00 for adult and $4.00 for children. The gardens were well kept, and a great place to take photos, as we were walking around we came across an area where you can get dressed up in the traditional chinese costumes and then walk around the park and take photos with your own camera. We decided to get the two boys to dress up, and they loved it and so much fun pretending to be chinese warriors, it only cost us $10.00 total for them to do this.

Not worth the admission price. It seems really weird to charge $6 for admission to a garden to promote friendship. You can see into the garden area from several openings around it, and unless you have a real interest in seeing this particular Chinese garden, skip it in favor of a short walking tour of Chinatown, which surrounds it.

Please clean up spider webbs!. Garden is very pretty - you can see the part of it from outside. There is a free but it was close when we walked by. The building is covered with spider webbs - it lead me to belive it has not been cleaned for long time.
Peaceful and serene. Refreshing. Sit, contemplate, think of Confucius and his teachings. Recap what you have to do at work when you are back from your vacation ... just kidding.

Skip it, if you are short on time.. As gardens go, its pretty enough. You can hire traditional Chinese clothes for $15 and take pictures. Some beautiful water features. Walk from there to China Town is just 10 minutes.
Lovely. It was a nice surprise. Bigger than we thought it was going to be and very serene. Well worth a visit.

Peaceful place close to darling harbourside.. After lunch it s a Good place to visit.
There is entrante fées.
Nice Water false it remind me the country China full of thèse garden. There is cloches you can rent far pictures indire the garden, ifs a great expérience. There is seats and a Nice restaurant close to the Water. The lucky fish are Nice to watch.

Enjoyed myself even though chinese gardens are not my thing. It was well planned out, lovely views from each gazebo. Lots of water dragons to take photos of. Waterfalls, costumes, plants, rocks, ducklings. Cafe was good too.

Relaxing place to visit. A beautifull replica of a traditional Chinese garden. I've visited it a number times since it was first opened around 1988. A lovely place to just sit and relax. or you can spend ages just wandering around the garden. I've always enjoyed sitting and watching the carp in the mini lake. I don't know the current entry fee as I last visited in 2010, but its always been very reasonable.

Serene, welcoming haven in the heart of the city. Exquisite, very cheap entry fee. Really refreshing and energising after the usual sightseeing. Just beautiful. I came alone on my way to meeting rest of the family at Darling Harbour so was really able to enjoy the peace. This place warrants many more visitors than it receives. It will appeal to lots of people. Go there!

An oasis of calm and history. The Chinese Gardens, tucked away in the Darling Harbour precinct, on the edge of Chinatown, are beautiful, peaceful ad redolent of the culture of the Chinese people who came to live in Sydney in the 19th century. The garden layout is lovely, and a visit there is time out of time. A little gem for a visitor, or a Sydney resident!

Beautiful. I have been here several times, over several years. It never fails to impress me. The service is great, the place is lovely to look at. It is just wonderful. The food is a bit over priced, but still well worth it.

This is a tourise site. I passed by this Garden of Friendship a few times and would never have thought of it as a tourist spot or an area to recommend friends to go visit. I would not go about trying to seek this spot out. If you happen to pass it or be near it, okay. But do not spend time trying to find it...nothing to really see in my opinion.
Absolutely Lovely. A sanctuary within the hussle and bussle of Darling harbour.An absolute joy and well worth the visit.th

So peaceful and tranquil.. I love this place! It has a special something that relaxes me and is well worth a look. It has lots of small pockets of different garden areas and some interesting sculpture work too.There was a wedding there the last time I was there which just made it all the more special.

Fun at the Chinese Gardens. We visited the Chinese Friendship Garden near Darling Habour in Sydney with a group of friends we'd met on tour in China earlier in the year. The entry fee was $6.00. The gardens are extremely pretty and a nice relaxing oasis away from the bustle of nearby Darling Harbour. It was like being back in China. The best part was dressing up in full Chinese ceremonial costumes and having our photo taken. There were 10 in our group who dressed up - it was a hot day and the staff put ice packs on under the clothes, dressed us, took all our cameras and patiently took photos with everyone's camera. The cost was only $10.00 per person and everyone had lots of fun. Would recommend these gardens to everyone visiting Sydney. There is also a tea room in the gardens.

A haven in the city. I always recommend visitors to Sydney to venture into this little haven amongst the madness of the city. It's a magical garden full of lush plants and fish in the wonderful ponds. It has many little nooks and cranneys with beautiful vistas that can make you feel that you are alone in the garden even tho' others are there.You could spend hours just sitting and relaxing in this beautiful garden. To come to Sydney and not experience it would be a shame.

Fantastic Gardens. Went here on a hot hot day in Darling Harbour, it was a lovely cool place to be, lazed away a couple of hours strolling around, watching the coy carp and drinking chinese tea in the cafe.

Beautiful escape. These gardens are such a refreshing and calming experience in the middle of a city. Even though they could do with a little more maintenance, the gardens are spectacular...well worth the visit and take time to enjoy the stunning scenes no matter which way you turn.
Surprising find. In the middle of all the high rises and the cityscape was this garden. Very well designed, and pretty.

Noisy. After reading so much about the gardens it was very disappointing to discover that they are located in the heart of a busy and noisy area. The gardens are lovely and interesting to view. However, they are across the street from an open area that had bands and other activities every time we were near this location. This is very near Darling Harbour and the activities seem to spill over to this area. The gardens are worth a visit but do not expect a peaceful atmosphere.

Beautiful place to visit. I took my mum here and she and i both loved it. It was almost like stepping into China.. a nice stroll through the garden also leads to a cafe where you can get little nibblies. We also got some Chinese Tea and sat near the pond watching the carp swim by. It was so relaxing and the scenery was beautiful. Definitely something worth check out

tranquility amidst huffing-puffing city. I was waiting in between appointments and had few hours to spare, so I took my companion to this small, precious garden.It was beautiful and serene. We walked around the garden, read small notes here and there, and spied a Chinese princess in lovely pink dress. When we called her, but she only smiled and walked away. Definitely a immeasurable source of subject for camera enthusiast.If you are a camera-geek, bring a book and seat on any stone bench located in the crooks of the garden and enjoy the warm sun on your shoulder. Beautiful place for a siesta.

Oasis. This garden was such a welcome surprise. Beautifully laid out and maintained, it lent an element of calm to a busy weekend.Well worth a trip even in winter when we visited. In the spring and summer it would be even better. Take a while to wander around and sit in the secluded areas and watch the water and the fish.

Worth visiting twice. I visited this garden twice during the course of my trip. It takes approximately one hour to wander around all the garden paths. This garden is a testament to the principles it is designed upon. I challenge anyone to visit and not walk away calmer and more at peace then when the entered. I would have liked to have taken away some printed matter on the technicalities of the garden design but none was available which was a little disappointing. This is not an attraction children will appreciate. The koi (carp) in the lake were amazing.
Not too friendly. A great diappointment After reading all the praises we found out that is was not worth the trouble Unfriendly people and not too clean.
A hub of tranquility in this City. I could of stayed there all day, so peaceful, so beautiful

Well worth it!. Lovely oasis in Sydney, if you have the time it is well worth checking out.Beautiful water features and flowing gardens are so soothing. Economical as well.Not necessarily the first choice for the visitor but if you are in the Darling Harbour/Chinatown vicinity why not call in.

Spot of tranquility--don't miss this. With all of the activity in the area, this is a wonderful place to just relax. We actually stumbled upon it, looked a couple of times to decide if we thought that the admission was worthwhile from the view outside. Wow--this was really a bargain. My only regret is that I did not bring something to read in one of the very quiet sitting areas. This was such a great get away that we spent two hours there when we only expected a quick trip

Dont miss the chance to see this. Went here after i came across it in trip advisor Do not miss this opportunity . It was divine SO clam and right in the middle of Sydney Wont spoil it for you but if u are spiritual or just like tranquillity GO here

Couldn't pull myself away from here it was so pretty and relaxing.. Nothing more to say than my firm recommendation to go. Definitely allow a couple of hours because, though it may seem small from the outside it certainly isn't on the inside. Millions of photo opportunities so take that camera. Cheap entry fee, 6 dollars per adult at present. Good cafe on site. Can't think of any negatives or pitfalls. Just make sure you put it on your list. Enjoy.

City Oasis. After living in Sydney for 25years I'm ashamed to say it took me so long to visit the Chinese Garden of Friendship.This garden has out of this world beauty, it had me speechless.The staff at this Garden are very clued up on the history and the meaning of this garden.You could easily spend an hour or two looking around and there were plenty of tables and chairs hidden around the place so bringing your lunch would be a nice idea.I will definitely not wait as long for my next visit.

Peaceful Garden Close to Paddy's Market. We spent one whole morning there, taking the self-guided tour. This is a lovely place to visit as soon as they open, as one can see all the birds throughout the garden at this time of day. The Walking Tour Leaflet was a great help identifying the plants, as well as Chinese Buildings throughout. The garden is well-planned and one can take several different paths to the areas, sit on benches and admire the plants & birds.

Just Ok--except for the Jade chariot!. I was annoyed that I couldn't pay the student price because I'm not from Australia, but we still went in after paying $6 each. It didn't appear to be well kept. Still, the natural beauty of the plants and buildings were admirable. We took lots of pictures. I was a little bored until, out of nowhere, we find a Jade chariot in a small room. They should tell people where it is. Not only is it incredibly beautiful, but it is rare to see one. I enjoyed reading about the history from the Shang dynasty on the plaque.

A quiet space in busy Sydney. I visited the chinese garden at the end of feb 2010 . Very tranquil space but at that time very little colour as nothing much in flower. The garden is beautifully laid out with many scenic spots. I didnt think it was very pretty or well kept it is '''was it says on the tin" an oriental quite pretty but full of mossies. I was bitten every where within minutes.
Don't miss!! Absolutely beautiful garden, a place of tranquillity.. I visited the garden in the beginning of december and it was absolutely beautiful. Don't miss!!

These gardens were equal to, if not better, the the Yu garden and The Honourable Administrator's garden in China.. WE were very impressed with these glorious gardens. I have travelled to China but I thought these gardens in Sydney to be better than the Yu Garden in Shangai, and at least the equal of The Honourable Administrator's Garden in Souzou, China

one of the best days i've spent in sydney!. The Chinese Garden of Friendship costs $5 to get in ($3 for students, like me) and it is worth every cent! It was designed so that there is no point in the garden from where you can see the entire garden. There is always something around the next corner, up the next staircase, something hidden down a little footpath that is worth a look! It rained the day we went, which I thought would have ruined it, but it made it even more beautiful, especially when the sun came out and was glistening off all the water! My boyfriend and I huddled under our umbrella or under the lovely pavilions. It was very romantic. They have a little teahouse with decent prices, and you get a free Morning Herald with entry. Beautiful, fun, and well worth the time spent there. Advice, though: take it slow, relax, and take the time to really enjoy it. If you can, sit a while and just relax. Most of the garden is far from outside noise and very peaceful.

a great little place in a huge city. Right in the middle of Sydney city, sits this wonderful place, full of charm and chinese character. The ardens are very well maintained, clean, wonderful rock pools and a small waterfall. We were lucky to see a chinese wedding take place while we were there. Seemed to be quite authentic with all the trimmings. In all, a great way to spend a few hours away from this wondeful busy city.

Beautiful amazing wonderful. I went to the Chinese Garden last in my trip to Sydney. I am so glad I went. Beautiful waterfalls, plants, even a few lizards running around. They had big rock formations throughout the garden, very tranquil. For $10-15 you could dress up in Chinese clothing and take your own pictures, if I hadn't gone alone that would have been a lot of fun. In the end I sat and drank tea watching the koi fish and birds in the pond. Would highly suggest going, got some beautiful photos also.

A breathtaking oasis in Darling Harbour. A breathtaking oasis in Darling Harbour. Grab a picnic lunch on the way, and eat by the lake. Its hard to believe that you are in the middle of a bustling city. Great photo opportunities. Small entrance fee AUD6, I think.

Beautiful haven in a bustling city. This is one of the most beautiful places in Sydney. It's almost as if the trees and water block out the city noise. Many of the views are like paintings and the Koi are huge!
Worth a visit, but be aware that these gardens are enclosed and you do have to pay a small fee to enter.

peacful spot in busy city. The plants and design of this garden are beautiful, a sanctuary in the hustle and bustle of Sydney. The architecture is nicely done, if all you want to see if koi and lotus flowers, don't bother, but otherwise is was a wonderful retreat.

Now worth it!!!. I was just there on August 15. I know it is winter in Sydney, and really didn't expect to see any spectacular blooming flowers. The pond was so dirty that I couldn't even see the the koi fish. No lotus flowers in site. They really didn't do a good job of maintaining the place which was really disappointing! A couples of my friends opted to go to the Royal Botanical Garden instead and they love it!!

Chinese garden is a Sydney must-see. This was my favorite Sydney attraction. This traditional Chinese garden was a beautiful, tranquil place to visit. The garden was large and well done, with a number of signs explaining the design principles. It was uncrowded even in the middle of summer allowing me to get a number of great pictures, and to take my time wandering through the garden. Definitely worth the small entrance fee. A gift shop was on the premises.
